PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the recession that the Minister finally acknowledged at the end of last week. I ask the Minister: is this a recession we had to have?
—I represent the Treasurer in this place. As Senator Hill well knows, the Treasurer has said that.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. If that is an admission that this is a recession we had to have, I ask: why was it, if we had to have this recession, that during the last election we were so often told that the recession would be avoided, that there would be a soft landing-for example, the Prime Minister's promise to the Australian people that `there is no reason to fear a recession in any sense' and the Treasurer's indication that `we will not let there be a recession' on 22 March? Why, in such circumstances, did the Prime Minister and the Treasurer so mislead the Australian people? Will the Minister now concede that this key election promise has been broken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought it was indiscreet of Senator Hill to hark back to the last election because I remember what his Leader was saying about what members of the Liberal Party would do with interest rates if they were elected to government.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators opposite can object. People talk about a recession; I have a profound state of depression when I contemplate the lot opposite. They are the only group of people I have seen in the community whose performance could be improved by a nuclear explosion, in my view, in light of the level of Question Time in the Senate. They know perfectly well what was said by their Leader in the context of the last election campaign.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I do not know whether the Minister is actually belatedly going to get around to answering the question, but you have power to draw him into line if he is not being relevant. I think we are all aware that there are longstanding rulings from the Chair that relevance consists of answering the question. The Minister has made no attempt to do that to date. Can the Minister please avoid any diversionary tactics and face up to the nub of the question?
—Order! I think the Leader of the Government is entitled to deal with the answer in the way that he was. I am sure that he was about to get to the answer to the question.

—Senator Alston invites me to face up to the nub of the question. I am inviting him to face up to the nub of the answer, and this is what he is going to get. Let me say, persistently, that if Opposition members listened at Question Time and read their Hansards, they would know that the Government has consistently expressed the view that it had to set about the task of dampening demand in an overheated economy and that it did not wish to maintain a high interest rate regime any longer than was necessary in order to achieve that result.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is not alone in this. There have been plenty of similar statements from Opposition spokesmen, plenty of similar statements from economists in the banks who have said to the Government again and again, `Stick to your guns. Maintain your nerve'. Why do they say that? They do so because they knew that when the Opposition was in government it did not do it. It went to water and left us with a $10 billion deficit and 620,000 people unemployed. Opposition members get up trying to make fun, trying to get the very little pleasure they ever get at Question Time, from the fact that we now have a recession in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to be like tomorrow?

— By tomorrow Senator Short might get around to asking a sensible question and we will try to give him an answer. The fact of the matter is that we now have a recession for a variety of reasons. In so far as the question of a soft landing is concerned, let me just say that throughout 1990, in looking at economic indicators, one can read a variety of very conflicting signals and circumstances about the recession. As the Treasurer has said, it is very difficult to finetune a slowdown in an economy like the Australian economy. He said that on a number of occasions.
—You just stuffed up, didn't you?
—Order! There are too many interjections.

—Senator Crichton-Browne, with his Western Australian vernacular, said, `The Government just stuffed up, didn't it?'. He would know, because he was part of the Government that really stuffed up in 1982. I would have thought he would have been quiet ever since and hung his head in shame.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN DEFENCE INDUSTRIES LTD: PROPOSED CLOSURES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer the Minister to weekend reports of the proposed closure of defence establishments at Footscray and Maribyrnong in Victoria and St Marys in New South Wales. Can the Minister inform the Senate as to the accuracy of these reports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I should point out, firstly, that the facilities at Footscray, Maribyrnong and St Marys are not Defence Department establishments but are, in fact, owned by Australian Defence Industries Ltd (ADI). Honourable senators will recall that ADI is a government-owned company which was established some 18 months ago to take over the operations of the old Office of Defence Production, including munitions, army engineering works, the Garden Island Dockyard and the Australian Government Clothing Factory.

ANSWER.PARA: ADI is run by a board of experienced business people charged with the responsibility of operating modern, efficient and competitive defence industries in this country. While in the final analysis ADI is answerable to its owner, the Government, we do not seek to intervene in the day-to-day commercial decisions of the company. In this context, it is important to understand that the announced closure of the Footscray, Maribyrnong and St Marys facilities, and the subsequent establishment of one, state-of-the-art new ammunition plant, is an ADI proposal based on its commercial assessment of its future. It is not a Government decision. Having said that, I should point out that ADI consulted the Government and the Defence Force prior to last Friday's announcement. It has informed me that the restructuring program will be self-financing and that it will not be asking the Government for money.

The Government accepts that the ammunition and missile division of ADI is in a particularly difficult position, being faced with both outmoded Second World War facilities and a substantially reduced Defence demand due to our changed and technologically superior training methods. Put bluntly, ADI's options were to do nothing and face the prospect of going broke; close the facilities and have our defence forces totally dependent on imported ammunition; or, finally, to undertake a restructuring to enable the establishment of a cost-efficient industry with export potential.

While the Government supports the general direction of the ADI board, including this proposed reorganisation, we have a particular concern for the future well-being of the existing employees who will be affected. In that context, it is now appropriate for negotiations to proceed between ADI and its employees and their unions. Before the Government can give its final seal of approval to the ADI proposal, it will be necessary for us to resolve issues relating to funding of redundancy levels and any borrowing requirements that may be involved. The ADI announcement last Friday was a very important transitional step towards the establishment of a secure and internationally competitive munitions industry in this country and one which we trust can be brought to a successful conclusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Defence: in light of the demands by the parliamentary Left and, indeed, the Centre Left, does the Government now rule out the possibility of any further Australian military commitments to the Gulf, regardless of how a conflict may develop there in the next few months?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not pre-empt the Prime Minister's statement to be made later today, but I will say this as to the timing of the decisions: the decision as to our future role in the Gulf was discussed by the leaders of the Party-that is, Senators Button and Gareth Evans, and Mr Hawke and Mr Keating-as well as another Minister, being me--

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Richardson interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I very deliberately excluded myself from the leaders. Those discussions occurred on Thursday in anticipation of the United Nations decision. The decisions made then, which were taken to Cabinet, have not altered in spite of consultation or any other suggestions made to us. They were made on the basis of what is in the interests of this country. As I said, they were made on Thursday; they have not altered since then. Any future alterations will be made clear by the Prime Minister in his speech. The only point I reiterate is that if there were any alteration, the same procedures as indicated in the Prime Minister's previous statement would be followed.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women noted reports of an employee moved without consultation by the Australian Wool Corporation while she was on maternity leave? Has the Minister also noted the substantial compensation awarded to the employee by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the scathing condemnation of the affair by the Commission's President, Sir Ronald Wilson? What measures are in place, or are contemplated, to ensure such insensitivity by the Australian Wool Corporation does not occur in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Colston for his question. At the outset I must say that the Government is of course committed to the principle of social justice for all Australians. In regard to that commitment, I ask the Senate to note that the last seven years have seen the greatest gains for Australian women than under any previous administration. A particular aspect of these achievements and these gains in our delivery of social justice to women is seen in the way that the Government has addressed the issue of maternity leave and the question of return to employment.

ANSWER.PARA: As an employer, we have taken a responsible approach. In order to avoid possible discriminatory action against women returning from maternity leave, the Public Service Board, I think in 1987, changed the administrative practices related to the Maternity Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act so that women on maternity leave could be unattached from their substantive positions only if they had given their consent to such change. Those arrangements mean that a woman who goes on maternity leave has a choice of returning to the position that she occupied before she left the work force. I also indicate that consideration is being given to amendments to the maternity leave Act to give legislative effect to this requirement.

Also, on 2 August this year Senator Cook announced a new provision applying to Australian Public Service staff who retire to care for children. As from 2 August, those staff can apply for any vacant job in the Australian Public Service up to six years from the birth of the child involved and, in doing so, can retain their seniority.

The policy also applies to government business enterprises and those enterprises which have been covered by the provisions of the Maternity Leave Act 1973 prior to their incorporation, unless the parties agreed otherwise. The Australian Wool Corporation is one of four authorities for which the development of equal employment opportunity programs is included in enabling legislation.

The specific issue that Senator Colston raises relates to the movement by the Australian Wool Corporation of a Ms Margaret Gibbs to another position upon her return from maternity leave. In this case, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission examined the matter and found that Ms Gibbs had been discriminated against. The Wool Corporation has been formally advised of the decision and also of shortcomings in its management procedures. I am advised that the situation arose because of a breakdown in such management procedures and practices. I am further advised that the management will ensure that there will not be a repetition of these events.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Prime Minister confirm that one of the sponsors for today's Prime Minister's XI cricket match against the visiting England cricket team, which is being played in Canberra, is the Benson and Hedges Co. Pty Ltd? If this is the case, does that tobacco company's sponsorship have any bearing on the fact that the Government has not indicated that it will support my move to ban incidental tobacco advertising on television?

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister undertake to provide, before the end of Question Time, an answer to the first part of my question, to which he says he does not know the answer at this point, as to whether that tobacco company is a sponsor of that cricket team?

—Yes, I will try to do that. I do know some of the other sponsors, such as British Aerospace Australia Ltd, and Senator Powell may like to ask a question about that company tomorrow. It manufactures fighter aircraft. At that time, Senator Powell may care to ask whether that influences our decision on defence policy and our role in the Gulf. That may be a question for tomorrow. —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. My question concerns the commitment by the Liberal-National Party coalition in Western Australia to use its numbers in the Legislative Council of that State to block legislation enabling the application of the Australian Securities Commission Act. What will be the effect of this decision, if it is carried out? In particular, what are the implications for industry and commerce of rendering Western Australia as the only State or Territory not participating in the new national scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the National Party Opposition members have not made up their minds on the rejection of this proposal and an acceptance of the alternative proposal put forward by the Liberals, but the stance of, I understand, the Liberal Opposition members in the upper House in Western Australia is reprehensible and will create such a fracturing of the Australia-wide supervision of corporate activity in Australia that it could easily leave the way open for the type of corporate criminal activity which we are most concerned to combat. The fact is that governments of all political persuasions and all jurisdictions throughout Australia have accepted the need for an Australian Securities Commission operating throughout the various regions of Australia and taking sole responsibility for the administration and enforcement of the companies and securities law of this country.

ANSWER.PARA: Not only have all governments, of all political persuasions, come to that conclusion but also it is interesting that in the last few days both the New South Wales and Victorian parliaments, for example, where those governments do not control the upper Houses, have passed this legislation, as required, through all stages, through both Houses, with the support of all political groupings in those particular parliaments. This cannot be said to be a party political or partisan matter. It is one which I think should commend itself to the Liberals in Western Australia in the upper House.

Mr President, I think the matter is a bit more worrying than even suggested in Senator Beahan's question because when one looks at the situation in Western Australia, what one will have, if the Western Australian Liberals have their way in the upper House, is two sets of regulations and fees required. Any burdens therefore put on the business community of Western Australia will have been put there deliberately and knowingly by the Western Australian Liberal Party, using its numbers in the upper House. It would be an extra regulatory and financial burden on those companies which still wish to register and operate out of Western Australia and also, of course, which wish to operate in other parts of the Commonwealth.

I believe that investors, both domestically and from overseas, will look upon Western Australia as trying to retreat behind State borders in a way which raises very real questions about the commitment of Western Australians and the Parliament of Western Australia to the sort of better corporate regulation which is so evidently required here in Australia. The losers, I believe, will be the business community of Western Australia as investors look askance at this particular retreat from an Australia-wide approach. I would also believe that as far as investigations and related activities are concerned, corporate crooks will take advantage of any fracture whatsoever in an Australia-wide approach. This is, of course, a great danger in the proposal put forward by the Liberals in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the view of WA Inc.?

—The honourable senator mentioned WA Inc. I would have thought that, given some elements of that experience, one would want to have a very strong, forceful Australian Securities Commission enforcing this law in a way which has no fear or favour which can, of course, be brought to bear by local politicians, or is allegedly able to be brought to bear by local politicians.

ANSWER.PARA: One would therefore ask the very question which lies behind the honourable senator's interjection: what lies behind the Western Australian Liberals in not permitting the Australian Securities Commission to act as the Australia-wide administrator of companies and securities law throughout Australia? I would have asked Senator Campbell who, reluctantly-he has indicated his misgivings-is reconciled now to the scheme, to use his good offices with his colleagues in Western Australia in order to try to secure their support for the passage of this legislation. Certainly he would be in good company because Mr Greiner, the Premier of New South Wales, was reported on the radio this morning, as carried by 6WF news. The newsreader introduced the matter by saying:
The New South Wales Premier, Nick Greiner, has condemned as ideologically based lunacy the Western Australian Liberals' stand on corporate regulation.
This is a quotation of Mr Greiner:

The notion that somehow the rights of the Western Australian Parliament, sovereign and all that it might be, the notion that somehow those rights would lead one to the conclusion that Western Australia ought to have a separate form of companies regulations from the rest of Australia in the second century of our nationhood! That notion seems to me to be so far fetched, so far removed from reality, and most importantly so far removed from the national good, that simply to state it, suggests you ought to reject it.

I believe that the Western Australian Liberals should reject this notion that has been put around apparently and has some sympathetic hearers amongst their group. They ought to reject this particular notion which would fracture the enforcement of companies and securities law throughout Australia. I believe that Senator Campbell should use his good offices to ensure that rejection.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. In view of the Minister's knowledge of the contents of the blue file resulting from the six briefings he received from the Australian Federal Police, prior to passing it on to the Western Australian State Police, where it languished for two years, is the Minister aware of claims that items seized by the AFP did not appear on the property seizure record and that these items referred to what was in the file marked B.B.? If he is aware, why were they not on a property seizure record? If he is unaware, will the Minister investigate these claims-it is only one of many in the `Burkegate' saga now unfolding-and, in particular, whether these items related to the State Labor Government's abuse of office in monitoring Opposition members of parliament?

—I thought that I had made it clear to the Senate that my knowledge of these matters surrounding the so-called blue files is very limited. I have indicated my knowledge and I have certainly never had them in my possession nor read them.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I ask the Minister: after six briefings, is he trying to tell the Senate that he did not know the contents of those files, that he does not know whether they were complete or not, and that he does not really know anything about the matter at all, given that only last Sunday the `B.B.' was identified as Brian Burke?

—I am delighted to say that, as a Minister for justice in a democratic system, I do not undertake the work of the police in investigating particular matters. I am not involved in operational matters undertaken by the Australian Federal Police, and I accept that it has investigated this matter properly and has passed the material to the correct authority, which was the Western Australian Commissioner of Police.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. The Minister will be aware of the serious shortage of doctors and other health professionals in rural Australia. What incentives and support is the Federal Government offering State governments to upgrade standards of health care outside cities and large towns?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Reynolds for her question because, as a senator from and representing so well northern Queensland, I am sure that she is as aware as all of us have become, even over the past several days, that the oldfashioned country practice which was staffed by a general practitioner who took care of local members of the community in a way which went on for several decades is a thing of the past. That kind of country doctor is certainly a rare and declining breed. The multiple doctor suburban clinic is obviously providing greater attraction to new graduates from our medical schools, particularly, I guess, because of the roster and career paths to specialisation, which are clearer if one is a member of such a suburban practice. So few doctors are choosing to work in the country and I believe that in Senator Herron's State of Queensland, which no doubt prompted Senator Reynolds's question, 200 country doctors are required in order to provide a reasonable service of general practitioner activity throughout that State.

ANSWER.PARA: This is a matter of great concern and the Federal Government has been trying to revive rural health services in many ways. In particular the general practitioner program and support for rural GPs is a part of that Federal Government support. It is intended to build upon the vocational registration arrangements already in place by improving country general practitioners' access to training and support, quality assurance programs and continuing education. It is also intended that the program will encompass the wider range of health service needs of rural communities by including other health care workers, such as surgeons, nurses and physiotherapists, under the national rural health support education and training program. It is anticipated that the program will address all levels of training-undergraduate, postgraduate and continuing-and relevant professional groups and rural users of such medical services will also be consulted.

I understand that the Minister for Community Services and Health has recently approved funding for the Rural Doctors Association of Australia to organise a conference on these matters, which is to be held in Toowoomba from 14 to 16 February. As well as being part of the consultative process associated with developing a rural health strategy, this conference will provide a forum at which the program I have outlined can be further developed. It requires much consultation, but I believe that the Rural Doctors Association of Australia is to be commended for the work it has undertaken to make fellow practitioners and, indeed, the general community aware of this predicament in our rural communities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Can the Minister explain why the Kangaroo Island ferry company, which registered its name with the South Australian Corporate Affairs Commission as Kangaroo Island Searoad, has been singled out for harassment and threats of legal action by the Australian Government Solicitor when other companies in Australia, such as Searoads Pty Ltd based in New South Wales, have no trouble trading with the generic name. In view of the fact that an independent 45 person Japanese documentary film crew promoting South Australia is to start filming the company's vessels on Saturday, and yet the company with only four days to go has no idea whether it can use the name at present on the ships without being sued, what action will the Minister take to require the Australian National Line to desist from legal action and allow Kangaroo Island Searoad to continue to operate under that name?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I just say initially that under the legislation that governs the operations of the Australian National Line (ANL), I cannot take such action-even if I were minded to do so, which in fact I am not. I did note the comments made in an earlier debate on this matter by Senator Olsen and I understand his concern about the issue. He said that I was being rather difficult to contact on the subject. In fact, quite the reverse is the case. I have had an extended conversation with the South Australian Attorney-General on this matter. I made some suggestions to the South Australian Attorney that I was prepared to advance with ANL. But, of course, I did not see the point in doing so unless the company concerned was minded to accept them. I got a phone call at a later stage from the South Australian Attorney saying that in fact the South Australian company had rejected those suggestions, which were not satisfactory to it.

ANSWER.PARA: Could I just say that it is not an unusual case that is proceeding at the moment in the sense that legal disputes conducted with civil litigation on the question of trademarks are quite commonplace. But I am concerned about the predicament that the South Australian company is in. I am particularly concerned about the fact that the name `Searoad' was given protection under an Act of parliament designed to protect people moving in and using the name in the interim period between the organisation being run directly by the Government and becoming a government business enterprise. That legislation was never designed for that purpose.

I have sought advice from the Federal Attorney on this matter. I received that advice yesterday. I had a discussion yesterday in Sydney with the Chairman of the board of ANL, Bill Bolitho. I handed on to him a copy of the advice that I received from the Federal Attorney which is basically to the effect that he would not see it as appropriate, and neither would I, that this interim protection provided for in the legislation should be used on an ongoing basis to protect such a name.

TALK.START.PARA: —Generic name.

—Generic name, yes. If ANL is not minded to take note of my suggestions to the Chairman-and I received a phone call from him this morning saying that he would give me a response within 24 hours, because I did stress the urgency of this-that would still leave open to the company the option that any commercial company has of taking this matter to civil litigation under passing off and so on. Frankly, I do not think that is an appropriate area for a Minister to interfere with, if that is the course of action that ANL decides to take.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of the company operating in New South Wales under the trade name that Senator Olsen mentioned, the principal reason why ANL did not take any action against that company through the Government Solicitor is that it is a trucking company. Despite its name, it does not own a ship. For that reason ANL did not actually see it as being a direct threat to its shipping operations.

In conclusion, I assure Senator Olsen that I do have a close concern about this matter. I am in communication with the Chairman of the board of ANL and the company Secretary of ANL. I hope the matter will move to a speedy resolution and I will be happy to provide Senator Olsen with advice as soon as I get it from Mr Bolitho.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The Minister would be aware that New Zealand authorities have complained that the closer economic relations agreement is being affected by Australian quarantine regulations. They claim that these are non-tariff barriers. In particular these matters have been raised by New Zealand at joint meetings of parliamentary committees from both countries, which I have had the opportunity to attend. Therefore the Minister will recall that the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) has for some time been investigating the dangers, if any, of fireblight infection from apples imported from New Zealand. Has the Service completed its investigation into these matters? If so, can the Minister inform the Senate of the results of its investigations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has completed its consideration of the proposition to allow the importation of New Zealand apples into Australia. It ought to be acknowledged straight off that there has been considerable grower opposition to the allowance of these imports and a fairly high level campaign has been conducted. A number of questions have been asked in this chamber about the potentiality of fireblight to be introduced by virtue of that importation. In Senator Schacht's preface to the question I can see the mirror image of that being reflected in views expressed on the New Zealand side of the Tasman.

ANSWER.PARA: However, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has stuck to its task in carrying out a proper, scientifically-based study and it deserves to be acknowledged for doing that in the face of this controversy. It has stuck to it because our quarantine laws need to be open and transparent at all times, particularly when we are dealing with a country such as New Zealand, which is a member of the Cairns Group of free trading nations, as is Australia, so that it is quite clear that quarantine is a non-tariff barrier and that it is there for what it should be-that is, to screen out disease and the importation of disease into this country.

The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service's report considered the New Zealand proposal and the sources or locations in New Zealand from whence the apples would come. It has circulated a draft document for comment, and has received and analysed those comments. It has also received comments from the Bureau of Rural Resources and the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics.

AQIS has announced that it will not proceed with allowing New Zealand apples into Australia. It has done so because it has identified a number of scientific gaps in the knowledge. Given those gaps, the seriousness of fireblight and the potential economic damage if there were an outbreak of that disease in Australia, AQIS has decided not to allow the proposition at this time.

The gaps identified relate to the reliability of the orchard surveys conducted in New Zealand and the efficacy of the dip treatment used against bacteria in the fruit. AQIS has concluded that there are inadequate safeguards against fireblight and the proposal fails at this stage. That is a typical cautious approach in risk assessment by AQIS, and one that I applaud. AQIS is now producing a paper explaining the reasons for its conclusion for dissemination to grower organisations in Australia and for commentary by New Zealand quarantine officials as well.

I conclude by saying, since this has been a matter of high controversy, that the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service has been under the microscope by interested sections of the community during all this time. If its conclusions were the other way round they would be as well regarded by this Government as professional, scientifically detached and appropriate conclusions. The fact that they concur with the view adopted by a lobby group does not diminish the professionalism of AQIS as an organisation. But, given the level of attention to its procedures that this event has brought on, it has demonstrated that we have in Australia in the AQIS a very professional service. That is to be applauded by all sections of the community.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer the Minister to the second reading speech by Mr Kerin on the Wheat Marketing Bill 1989 and more particularly to the point justifying the elimination of the guaranteed minimum price on a four-year rotating average and replacing it with a one-year forecast GMP. I quote from Hansard of 13 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: I am aware that the averaging arrangements in the previous GMP scheme provided support to growers in circumstances of extreme market downturn such as in 1986-87. If such a crisis were to occur again the Government would need to give close consideration to special support arrangements for the industry.

I ask the Minister: seeing as the world selling price in 1986-87 was $A147 per tonne while the current forecast for this season's crop is $120 a tonne-$28 less than in 1986-87-does he consider that the time for `close consideration to special support' has now arrived?

I ask the Minister: seeing that the world selling price in 1986-87 was $A147 per tonne while the current forecast for this season's crop is $120 per tonne-$28 less than in 1986-87-does he now consider that the `time for close consideration for special support' has now arrived?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here is a good example of cooperation between the Liberal and National parties or at least an example of their thinking in the same vein, because Senator Boswell indicated to me by fax about 40 minutes before the start of Question Time that he would ask me an almost identical question. This may be an example of what, euphemistically, could be called great minds thinking alike, but I think that whole concept is derisory. I might say obligingly that, while Senator Boswell did indicate to me the question he would ask, he wrote on the cover of his fax that I had better give a good answer or I would end up on the front page of the Australian newspaper.

ANSWER.PARA: The decline in net returns for the current pool reflects the impact of the continued use of export subsidies by the United States (US) and the European Community (EC) on world market prices. The indicator or card price has held relatively steady at around $US124 to $US125 per tonne, whereas US subsidies have increased from $US35 per tonne in September to more than $US40 per tonne at present. The EC is paying about $US135 per tonne to exporters to match these prices. The Australian Government will not get involved in this subsidy war by giving growers a direct compensation payment, as called for by the Grains Council of Australia. The cost would be around $400m for the current season if we did so. The Government provides a significant benefit to the industry by its underwriting of the Australian Wheat Board's borrowings to finance advance and cash-out payments. The guaranteed limit of Australia-$1,052.6m-represents around 90 per cent of the revised pool returns estimate.

The domestic market for quality wheats remains strong and, under the deregulated market, growers have the option to take advantage of that. I am advised that Mr Kerin will meet with the Grains Council next week to discuss the possible means of government assistance. Earlier requests for accelerated payments to growers by increasing the level of past national interest insurance were not accepted by the Government at that time. Also, the Wheat Board has renewed its offer of $30 per tonne against the insured component of such credit sales, which will provide significant cash flow benefits.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COUNTRY RAIL PASSENGER SERVICES: SOUTH AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, concerns the closure of country rail passenger services in South Australia, specifically those to Whyalla, Broken Hill and Mount Gambier. Is the Minister satisfied that the demand for these services was sufficiently below that required to justify their continuation? Can the Minister assure the public that there are, to these areas, adequate alternative means of passenger transport which are no more expensive and no less convenient than the rail service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Regrettably, the use that was being made of these services was dramatically below the level required to justify their continuing existence. The Australian National Railways Commission has in fact recommended the closure of the three regional passenger services that it operates in South Australia between Adelaide and Mount Gambier, Whyalla and Broken Hill. Australian National advises that these services are very heavy loss makers, covering only one-third of their direct costs and little more than one-sixth of their full costs. Occupancy for the three services averaged only 38.5 per cent in 1989-90 and these services would not in fact have covered their operating costs even if they had been running full.

ANSWER.PARA: An independent study of Australian National's passenger services by the Bureau of Transport and Communication Economics found that there would be considerable economic benefits in the closure of these services, except in the unrealistic situation of there being no excess capacity on alternative means of transport.

The alternative coach services range between 60 per cent and 80 per cent full and average a 30 per cent excess of capacity. Bus operators have advised that they could accommodate the existing rail passenger services and perhaps assist further by changing some of their existing schedules to do so. It is not possible to provide a complete assurance concerning the cost and convenience of alternative transport for each and every person, but I can advise Senator Foreman that because of the significant lower capital and operating costs of road coach services, they are able to provide a significantly more frequent and in many instances cheaper service. There are 80 services a week each way between Adelaide and destinations served by Australian National, but only 13 are by the rail cars.

In conclusion, I add that the situation is, in terms of some of the suggestions that were made during the debate on the closure of these services, that perhaps the rolling stock could be replaced-because it was ageing rolling stock. Regrettably, were that to be done-as I said before, the services were currently returning only one-sixth of the cost of operation-that would in fact effectively have doubled the loss on the existing service.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Given the possible consequences following the 15 January deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, can the Minister advise the Senate of the preparedness of the military facilities in northern Australia, including Royal Australian Air Force air bases in Tindal, of the level of security at airports in northern Australia-particularly Darwin Airport-and the coordination between defence and civilian authorities? Can he also provide details of changes to stand-by or recreational leave arrangements for defence personnel and reservists during the festive season?

—I fail to see how the two things are directly linked, unless Senator Tambling is asking whether in the event of hostilities in the Middle East there would be increased security precautions taken; otherwise I fail to see the linkage between the two points in his question. There have been the normal procedures, as I understand, which have occurred in the past and which will continue in the future. Quite clearly, if there appears to be a likelihood of hostilities there would be a need within Australia at all military installations and other civilian installations for a higher security level than would exist in normal times. That is based on fairly clear evidence of links between Baghdad and terrorist groups-which have been remarkably quiet, the Senate will note, in the last few weeks-but I have no doubt at all that in the event of hostilities those terrorist groups would become very active. So the Government will make the necessary plans, not just in the north of Australia but at any vital military installations and other vital civilian installations, to make sure that security is heightened.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. The Minister failed to address the first and third points that I asked him in a three point question, and I appreciate that. —Not surprisingly, Mr President, I would not be totally aware of every leave arrangement at every base around Australia. But I will follow that up and give the honourable senator an answer. I am also somewhat bemused by his term `preparedness'. Preparedness for what?
—Logistic support.

—Logistic support, et cetera. If this is a very indirect way of trying to get to what the Prime Minister is saying later on in the afternoon, it may be more meaningful if the honourable senator pursues it tomorrow, having heard the statement of the Prime Minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. It concerns the severe plight of horticulturalists in the Murray Riverland; that is, those growing citrus and a range of other fruits in the preparation of dried fruits and juice. Does the Minister acknowledge the damage occurring to the horticultural industries of the Riverland caused by the free trade and deregulationist policies of the Government? Is the Government prepared to modify these policies to ensure the survival of a viable horticultural industry in the Riverland? Will the Government consider the removal of the sales tax on 100 per cent fruit juice-and I would interpolate here: the measure introduced by the Government, supported by the Opposition, and voted against by the Democrats? Finally, will the Government enact comprehensive legislation complimenting any passed by the States ensuring that consumers will be able to clearly identify, through labelling, the country of origin of all the contents and the percentage of Australian content in an item such as orange juice so that the Buy Australian program has some meaning in this industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course the Government is aware of the current difficulties being experienced by horticultural producers in the Riverland as well as in Sunraysia, the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area and other horticultural areas. The focus of much of the attention given to this matter has been the rapid fall in prices paid for oranges for juice. It is acknowledged, however, that the situation for other producers is also serious because of prices for dried apricots, grapes and so on.

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator Coulter will have seen, my colleague John Kerin has had special meetings with representatives of the citrus and other horticultural industries, as well as a special meeting on this subject with the agricultural Ministers from the three States concerned. Mr Kerin issued a press release on 13 November saying that he was prepared to take the matter to Cabinet. It is my understanding that that submission to Cabinet will be dealt with next week. I cannot, of course, canvass what will be in that submission at this time.

On the general question of free trade policy, which Senator Coulter raised in his question-if I might be anecdotal for a moment-I myself raised this issue with prominent representatives of the farming community only a week ago. They have perhaps a slightly different view in terms of the Uruguay Round discussions and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) than would be held by orange growers in the Riverland. Australia's main advantage in agricultural products lies in a freer world trade. Concern and interest has been expressed by successive Australian trade Ministers and is currently being advanced by Dr Blewett in the GATT round.

Senator Coulter asked about sales tax policy. The Government has been reconsidering this matter, although I am aware of continuing concerns regarding both the sales tax on fruit juice and the local content provisions, which are due to change next year. With regard to labelling, honourable senators will be aware that Senator Tate answered questions on this matter here last week. As I understand it, at least two of the three southern citrus States are intending to legislate for changes to the labelling requirements, and it is expected that all States will adopt uniform labelling requirements making it clear when juice is made up of imported ingredients or local content.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and concerns Cambodia. I refer to reports that Khmer Rouge military activity is escalating, especially in the western region, including Siem Reap province, and also directed to control one of the two major east-west roads in Cambodia. ANSWER.PARA: Many questions are raised by Senator Teague's multipronged question. I am proposing to deliver in this place on Thursday a major ministerial statement on the whole subject of Cambodia. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Minister seen press reports that Britain, the United States of America (US) and Japan are obstructing progress at the Special Antarctic Treaty Consultative Meeting in Chile in securing a comprehensive environmental protection regime for the Antarctic? Would the Minister comment on the prospects of success for the Australian initiative in the face of such opposition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the Special Antarctic Treaty Consultative Meeting which is entering its final days in Chile this week, Australia's initiative for a comprehensive legal instrument to protect the Antarctic environment-an initiative that has been co-sponsored not only by France but also by Belgium and Italy-is receiving very significant support. Finland, Sweden, Greece, Denmark and the Commission of the European Community, to name just some, have warmly welcomed the proposal.

ANSWER.PARA: Our draft instrument that has generated this degree of approval includes, of course, a permanent ban on all mineral resource activity-including mining, drilling and prospecting-in Antarctica. New Zealand, which formerly was a strong supporter of the minerals convention which would allow such activity in certain circumstances, has now proposed a draft instrument parallel to our own.

Moreover, we are very hopeful that the United States will move to a more flexible position which reflects the growing domestic mood in this respect in that country. That domestic mood has, in particular, been encapsulated in legislation recently enacted by the US Congress which specifically calls on the Administration to conclude international agreements for the protection of the Antarctic environment, incorporating an indefinite ban on mining.

However, I have to say that I can make no secret of my, and the Government's, regret that the United Kingdom, in particular, has so far failed to recognise this groundswell of national and international opinion which is building up in favour of the comprehensive protection of the fragile Antarctic environment and continent. The United Kingdom is supported in its attitude these days by only a few other countries and among them, I have to acknowledge, is, in particular, Japan.

Consensus is a necessary element of the Antarctic Treaty system and Australia does not seek to change that. The Treaty system will suffer if this procedure-one of the system's greatest strengths-is misused to oppose changes which reflect these broadly emerging concerns. It is only a matter of time before the views that we and many of our Antarctic Treaty parties are urging will prevail and developments at this week's Chile meeting are bearing this out. The Prime Minister said in his statement on this matter on 23 November:
. . . we will not be prepared to sacrifice principle for the sake of a short term solution.
The issues at stake in this respect are simply too important.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN COUNCIL OF TRADE UNIONS: GRANTS FOR FOREIGN AID

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 November Senator Kemp asked me a question about whether the Australian Council of Trade Unions received a management fee, contribution towards staff costs or other form of compensation to administer particular grants for foreign aid and about the method of assessment which my Department employs to monitor and assess the effectiveness of these grants and to ensure they achieve their stated goal. I have a long answer for him addressing both those matters. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

(1) The ACTU and its overseas aid agency, the Australian People for Health, Education and Development Abroad (APHEDA), receive funding from various AIDAB program areas in competition with other NGOs and interested parties.
* The ACTU does not receive any management fee for Commonwealth Trade Union Council (CTUC) or International Confederation of Free Trade Unions (ICFTU) programs funded by AIDAB.
* AIDAB does however provide funds to the ACTU to employ an executive officer for the South Pacific and Oceania Council of Trade Unions (SPOCTU) office, based in Brisbane.
* Under the AIDAB/NGO cooperation program voluntary agencies are permitted to apply for modest costs for administration.
- These costs must be clearly related to an individual project, be fully documented and separately identified.
- No costs additional to those directly related to the administration of a particular project are funded.
* The same conditions apply to voluntary agencies receiving funds from AIDAB's emergency and refugee and relief allocations.

* APHEDA uses some of the funds allocated to it by the development education and public information section of AIDAB toward staff and modest administration costs for their development education program.
- These costs ensure the delivery of a high quality program.
* APHEDA projects approved under the Special Assistance Program for South Africans (SAPSA) include provisions for project administration costs.
- On average these amount to 7 per cent of total project costs.
* APHEDA received $330,000 over three years from the Philippines bilateral assistance program for an occupational health and safety project.
- Funding included separately identified administration costs which were fully documented.
- These amounted to about 8 per cent of total project costs.
(2) All voluntary agencies receiving AIDAB funds are required to provide reports which indicate the effectiveness of the grants and the extent to which projects have achieved their stated goals.
* Guidelines for the operation of the AIDAB/NGO cooperation program require that voluntary agencies submit financial and operational reports on projects for which funding has been received.
- Final reports are expected no later than 12 months after project completion.
- For projects which require subsequent funding for on-going activities, approval is only recommended following the receipt of a satisfactory project progress report.
- Additionally, these projects may be visited by a joint AIDAB/NGO review team to ensure that they comply with the guidelines.
* Regular reporting is required for all funds allocated from AIDAB's emergency and refugee and relief programs.
- If the reports are not received in the allotted time follow-up action is undertaken.
- Periodic field visits are also made by AIDAB officers to monitor selected emergency and refugee projects.
- Such visits have been made to a number of APHEDA projects in the last few years.
* APHEDA has regularly reported to AIDAB on its development education program.
- They have demonstrated that funds have been spent in the manner and for the purposes agreed
- As part of our normal monitoring practice, I have decided that there will be a review of APHEDA's development education program during 1990-91.
* SAPSA funding arrangements include exchanges of letters which require voluntary agencies to provide detailed project reports, including financial acquittals.
- This process ensures that the funds provided are used efficiently and for the purposes agreed.
* In all cases voluntary agencies participating in bilateral programs are required to submit detailed reports.
- Financial and operational reports submitted assist AIDAB to monitor project progress and determine further project funding release.
* Reports provided by APHEDA indicate funds provided for their Philippines occupational health and safety project have been spent in the manner and for the purposes intended.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday, Senator Vanstone asked me a question in relation to access sought by certain honourable senators to the Hansard tape-recordings of the proceedings in Brisbane of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority last week.

INTERJECT.PARA: The responsibility for the transcription of the proceedings of parliamentary committees rests with Hansard. When a transcript is completed, Hansard forwards that transcript in electronic and hard copy form to the committee, which undertakes the printing and distribution of that transcript. The committee subsequently advises Hansard of any suggested corrections to the transcript. Any request to Hansard for access to a tape-recording of the proceedings of a committee or an unproofed version of the transcript is referred by Hansard to the committee for decision. Usually that decision is advised to Hansard by the committee secretary after consultation with the committee chairman. This is what occurred in relation to the matter raised by Senator Vanstone. The principle is that transcripts, both proofed and unproofed, are the property of the committee and it is a matter for each committee to determine access to that material and advise Hansard accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that, 11 sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Industry Training Agents' Guidelines No. 1, ITA 1 of 1990, made under the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990, be disallowed.
I seek leave to make a short statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the Committee is giving this notice because it is now at the end of the 15 days after tabling when such action must be taken. The Committee's concerns with the guidelines relate both to the parliamentary proprieties and personal liberties. In respect of parliamentary proprieties, the guidelines may not have been made in accordance with the parent Act. In respect of personal liberties, important discretions exercisable by public officials and affecting the livelihood of individuals may not be subject to review of their merits by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT).

SPEECH.PARA: Other possibly defective provisions affecting personal liberties empower officials to enter premises, inspect and copy records and require people to answer questions. The guidelines do not appear to include all the safeguards which are usual in such cases. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement of the concerns of the Committee with the guidelines and with another instrument of delegated legislation.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Industry Training Agents' Guidelines No. 1
ITA 1 of 1990

The Guidelines provide detailed criteria for qualifications and conditions for registration as an industry training agent under the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990. The Guidelines have important financial and commercial implications.

The Guidelines helpfully provide Notes in the body of the instrument. The Notes advise that where registration of an agent is cancelled under the Act that AAT review is available. There is no such assurance that an initial refusal to register is similarly subject to review. The Committee believes that review rights should not only be provided, but also notified as widely as possible.

There may also be defects in the drafting of the Guidelines which could affect their validity. It is an important function of the Committee to scrutinise delegated legislation to ensure that it is legally valid. In the present case the parent Act provides that the registration of an agent may only be cancelled if this power is granted under the Guidelines. There does not appear to be such a power, apart from where a person has requested cancellation. Several provisions are drafted as though such a power does exist. A Note in the guidelines also assumes that such a power exists. However, the actual drafting of the relevant provision does not provide expressly for cancellation.

Another provision empowers public officials to enter premises and inspect and copy records. The agent is required to make the records available and answer questions. The Committee always scrutinises closely such provisions and insists on appropriate safeguards. In this case the power in the Guidelines may duplicate a similar power in the Act which provides extensive powers of entry. Also, unlike the Act, the Guidelines do not provide that officials entering premises must produce written (preferably photographic) identification and that the official must leave on request if unable to produce the identification. The Act provides a penalty of $1,000 for an agent who refuses to allow officials to enter or otherwise fails to comply with the provision. There appears to be no penalty in the Guidelines. There appears to be no protection against self-incrimination in the questions which the agent is required to answer.
Determination under s.98c (1) (b) of the National Health Act 1953

This instrument does not appear to be subject to tabling and disallowance. However, it is clearly a legislative instrument, affecting as it does the rights and obligations of classes of persons. The Committee decided that it would scrutinise the instrument in the same way as it does other delegated legislation, although it may not be possible to give notice of a protective motion of disallowance.

The Committee decided to do this because it has often expressed the view that such instruments should be subject to tabling and disallowance. Also, the Committee receives such a high level of cooperation from Ministers that it is appropriate to raise possible defects in such instruments.

The Committee's copy of the Determination is neither signed nor dated. The Determination also refers to Schedules 2, 3, 4 and 5, none of which is attached. If the original instrument is purported to be made in this fashion it may be invalid. If the original was validly made then defective copies should not be circulated to the public.

The Determination was not numbered. The need for numbering is illustrated by several references to another Determination under a separate provision of the Act. If more than one such Determination has ever been made, or if one or more have been made and amended, there are problems of interpretation.

The Determination grants many important discretions. There is no indication on the face of the instrument that any of these are subject to AAT review. No criteria are provided for the exercise of many of these discretions. Other criteria are inappropriate. For example, one provision reads ``A computer software system is not, or ceases to be, acceptable to the General Manager if . . . the General Manager deems the system to be unacceptable.'' Another reads ``A claim is not of acceptable standard if . . . the General Manager deems the claim to be of unacceptable standard.'' The General Manager is not required to give reasons for these or other important decisions affecting the livelihood of individuals.

The Determination refers to ``operational testing'' and ``operational audit requirements.'' These terms are not defined. If they involve entry onto premises by public officials then the usual safeguards should be provided.

Some of the provisions of the Determination appear to affect privacy. It is customary to consult with the Privacy Commissioner on such issues. Normally the fact of such consultation is advised in the Explanatory Statement or other explanatory material. The Determination was not accompanied by such material.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) relating to the situation in the Persian Gulf and to move a motion in relation to the statement. I seek leave to have the statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In that circumstance, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.
I table the statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. My understanding is that the Minister sought leave to do two separate things. One was to make a statement; the other was to have it incorporated. We denied leave regarding the second of those, not the first.
—The Minister does not need leave to table the statement, and that is what he has done.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-It is unsatisfactory that the speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will not appear in Hansard, whether it is read in full by the Minister representing the Prime Minister or whether it is incorporated. We are not particularly fussed as to which of those mechanisms is used. We were prepared to give leave because all statements of this nature are made available some hours before debate. That gave us time to read it, and I cannot see how anyone could say that they did not have time to read it. Therefore, we wanted to allow more time for the debate on the statement to take place. I invite the Minister to reconsider the procedure that he has adopted because, although it seems that he can table it without leave and that is an option that is open to him, I think it is creating an undesirable precedent.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. Under what provisions of the Standing Orders does the Minister without leave move to take note of a tabled document?

—As I understand it, Senator Button sought leave to make a statement and to incorporate the speech in Hansard. He received leave to make the statement and leave was denied to the latter. When leave was denied by the Democrats and also by at least another senator, he tabled the document. I believe he is in order to use those procedures.
—On the same point of order, Mr President: I did not hear the Minister seek leave to move a motion to take note of a tabled document.
—Yes, he did, Senator Harradine. So, that is the motion before the Senate at the moment. We will hear the first speaker once we get over these procedures.
—I seek leave not to incorporate Senator Button's statement but to move that the document be incorporated in Hansard.

—Order! Senator Teague moved that the document be incorporated in Hansard and leave was denied. The motion before the Senate at the moment is to take note of this statement. I will call Senator Hill--
—That is a complete disregard of the Senate--
—Order! I am following the Standing Orders and, if there are no more points of order, the first speaker to Senator Button's motion will be Senator Hill.

—Mr President, I rise again to a point of order. Unless I am misunderstanding what you are saying, and I want to be helpful to the Senate, I do not want to see a situation where a precedent is established. As I understand it, Senator Button sought leave to do two things: one was to make a statement and to have that incorporated into Hansard; and the other was to move a motion in relation to that statement. Leave was sought to incorporate the statement in Hansard. The fact is that that document has now not been incorporated.
—It is no good reinventing the wheel. This is the first time you claimed to object.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Harradine

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not object. That document, which has not been incorporated in Hansard, is not the same document technically as the one which Senator Button sought leave to take note of. If we allow this practice to occur we will be able to do the same with second readings of Bills about which we may have had no notice at all. It is an important procedure to be followed. It is a defence by any senator to deny leave if that senator has not had the opportunity of considering the subject matter of the material about which leave has been sought for incorporation in Hansard. I fear that by proceeding along this line, we may well be creating precedence.

INTERJECT.PARA: In summary, the document about which Senator Button has sought leave to move a motion is no longer in existence because it is not incorporated in Hansard. He sought leave to incorporate the document in Hansard; he sought leave to move a motion in relation to that document. It is not in Hansard and, therefore, he needs to seek leave again to move a motion relating the tabled document. How do we know it is the same document?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on the point of order: the simple situation-which has got complicated but it really is very simple-is that Senator Button got up and did three things. First of all, he sought leave to make a statement on behalf of the Prime Minister on the subject of the Gulf; secondly, he sought leave to incorporate that statement in Hansard; and, thirdly, he sought leave to move a motion to take note of that particular statement of the Prime Minister's on the Gulf. He was denied leave on the second of those three propositions-the incorporation-but granted leave both to make a statement and to move the motion. That leave has been granted and cannot now be withdrawn. In the absence of leave also being given for the incorporation--
—The point is: he did not make a statement.

—I am coming to that. In the absence of being given leave to incorporate the statement, Senator Button tabled the statement. He does not need to seek leave from anyone to do that. Ministers can table documents at any time. He did so. There is in existence a tabled statement, in respect of which Senator Button has already sought and been granted leave to move a particular motion. He did not in his original language refer either to the statement as incorporated or the statement as tabled; he referred simply to the statement he was about to deliver on behalf of the Prime Minister. That is the order and sequence of events. The motion properly before the Senate now is to take note of the statement which happens to have been tabled, unfortunately, rather than incorporated, but it is a clear and straightforward motion. The whole point of this exercise was simply to allow the Senate more time, as the Opposition has acknowledged, to debate the substance of this, given that the thing has been circulated in ample time for everyone to be aware of it. I suggest that we get on with it.
—Order! To the point of order, I have sought advice and the procedures to which Senator Evans has just referred are correct. The motion before the Chair is that the Senate take note of the statement.

—I seek clarification, Mr President. Does this mean that, when a senator seeks and obtains approval to make a statement, he can make that statement in the form of tabling the document rather than incorporating it? Is there not a fundamental difference between the two?
—Order! No, that is not correct. Only a Minister has the right to table a document and not seek leave.
—My question was: does the act of tabling a statement constitute the Minister making a statement?
—All the Minister has done is lay the statement on the table of the Senate.

—As I understand it, this is setting a dreadful precedent. In future we would have to contend with the situation of the Minister who is to make the Budget Speech suggesting that it be incorporated. This has happened in the past and we have refused incorporation of the Budget Speech. Will this mean that in future the Minister can just table the Budget Speech? If so, we are setting a dreadful precedent. I am very loathe to allow this to occur.

—The Minister cannot be compelled to read the statement. I can only operate within the Standing Orders. Whether it creates a precedent or not, there is now a motion before the Senate which is in order.

—I realise, Mr President, that you cannot compel the Minister to read his statement, but I suggest it is in the interests of the Minister and the Government to read the document. Many senators have not had it available to them since 12 noon. The first they have seen of it is as it is being circulated in the chamber right now. If the Government is committed to the course of action which the Prime Minister's statement is about, surely a Minister needs to have the guts to get up and read that statement in this chamber?
—That is not a point of order either, Senator. It is a statement.
—That is possibly the more--
—If Senator Vallentine wants to make a statement, she must seek leave.

—I seek clarification from you, Mr President. Will the record of the proceedings of the Senate reflect the fact that, in a few moments from now, we will hear speeches to a statement which does not appear in Hansard? If this is to be the procedure of this place, I ask whether it will be the reality of how this place is recorded.
—It has been tabled, but it will not be recorded in Hansard.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. My understanding of your ruling on Senator Short's question is that, whether or not the Minister had been granted leave to make a statement, that is essentially the same thing as tabling a document. You have not ruled as to whether or not there is a distinction between those two things. The distinction that I am asking you to make is that, if a senator is granted leave to make a statement, that is something quite different from tabling a document.
—That is exactly right. Senator Short referred to two separate circumstances. The Minister has the power to table the document. He has done that and he has moved the motion, which is in order.

—On the same point of order, Mr President: perhaps you could rule on this. What follows from that is that we have the ridiculous situation in which the Minister has sought leave to make a statement, but now declines to make that statement.
—There is nothing to compel him to make the statement.
—No, but we should record that he has declined.

—Order! I have ruled on this. I think Senator Evans put it in clear and precise terms. I sought advice as to whether Senator Evans's procedures and the way I had ruled were correct. The advice I have received is that they are correct and that Senator Button has now moved a motion which is to be spoken to by Senator Hill.
—Mr President, can we then ask that Hansard record that Senator Button, having sought leave to make a statement, declined so to do?
—It will certainly be in Hansard now.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order.
—Senator Short, are you speaking to the same point of order that I have ruled on twice?

—I guess I am, Mr President. I seek a point of clarification. As has been said, the action of the Australian Democrats today-and that is what we are talking about-in refusing to let the normal processes go on in this place has led to what I would regard as a potentially very serious situation. We now have a situation where Senator Button-and I accept Senator Evans's three points-sought leave to make a statement and to incorporate that statement in Hansard. He was not given leave to incorporate it so he tabled it. As I understand it, the third point concerned a motion to take note of the statement. My question to you, Mr President, seeks clarification. Can there be a motion to take note of a statement if the statement has not been made? Are there three ways in which a statement-
—Yes. I have ruled on this. The Minister has tabled the statement and he has moved the motion to take note of that statement. He is perfectly in order.
—So tabling a statement constitutes making a statement, because if it does not--
—No, it does not, but it is in order.
—If it does not constitute making a statement, how can you have a motion before the Senate to take note of the statement, because there is no statement to take note of?
—Because the Minister has moved that the Senate take note of the statement that he has tabled. It is quite in order.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Short has stated that the Australian Democrats are failing to allow the normal procedures of this place to occur. I believe that we are acting entirely under Standing Orders and that that claim is incorrect.
—Order! That is not a point of order. Any other senator who wants to speak on this matter will have to seek leave to do so, because I have ruled on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to read the Government's statement. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) should read the statement. I am going to address the motion that the Senate take note of a statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that has been tabled in this place, notwithstanding that we are dissatisfied with the procedure and we might, respectfully, have some disagreement with your ruling, Mr President. But it is not the sort of matter that we would want to take any further. The statement is an important statement and we welcome the opportunity to debate it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's decision has taken Australian forces a step closer to involvement in armed conflict. The ships, of course, have been located outside the Persian Gulf-as you know, Mr President, in the Gulf of Oman-where they have been enforcing the trade boycott pursuant to previous United Nations (UN) resolutions. They have been challenging and searching those ships which may have been in breach of the boycott. However, the United Nations Security Council has now carried resolution 678 which in effect authorises the use of force to end the unlawful occupation of Kuwait by Iraq. The resolution calls upon states to consider their contribution and to use all necessary means to uphold and implement all previous Security Council resolutions.

We note that the Australian Government has, pursuant to the resolution, reassessed the military role of Australia-in particular, Australia's naval commitment. The ships will now operate in the upper reaches of the Gulf with American, Canadian and British contributions. They clearly will be training for the offensive action which may have to follow after 15 January. We support the expanded function-not lightly because of its gravity-after a great deal of careful thought and consideration. It is clear that Saddam Hussein will not withdraw from Kuwait until he is convinced that a failure to withdraw will result in the destruction of his regime. However, to convince Saddam of that consequence, the alliance forces must be prepared to take offensive action. Regrettably, that means an offensive action might have to be mounted. It is not possible to be assured that Saddam, even when faced with the most dire consequences, will in fact withdraw.

It must be recognised that having gone this far it is not practicably possible for Australia to pull back without an Iraqi withdrawal. I doubted whether it was possible when Australia took the first step of sending a force to enforce the boycott. In some ways we on this side of the chamber seemed to understand better than the Prime Minister what the Australian Government was getting into. That is why we questioned the ambiguity of his initial statement, which actually was in the form of a press conference. Perhaps he was aware of what he was taking Australia into and we were more honest. In any event, recognising the sequence of events which could follow, we accepted the consequences because we believed it was in Australia's best interests.

Resolution 678 should not be interpreted as the identification of force as a preferred means of resolving the crisis, but it confirms the resolve of the international community to use force if sanctions are incapable of forcing an Iraqi withdrawal. The specification of a time limit makes clear to Iraq that a strategy of delay to take the crisis past the point where the use of force will be a credible option will not work. It therefore helps produce a peaceful resolution, if such a resolution is at all possible.

It follows that a peaceful resolution requires the international alliance to keep its nerve; to consistently and persistently apply pressure; and, to use an American expression, not to blink. Any sign of weakness, lack of resolve or disagreement within the alliance gives strength to Saddam's hand. He will seek to outlast the alliance. Regrettably, his ruthless application of the hostage strategy has already won him time and enabled him to play off some of the alliance partners against others. The next delaying tactic will be a willingness to negotiate; to talk of a partial withdrawal; perhaps even a partial withdrawal. The hopes on the alliance side will be raised.

Saddam knows that whilst there is hope of peaceful resolution the alliance is unlikely to attack. In other words, Saddam Hussein is planning on the humanity of the alliance, particularly the Western elements. He senses that the values which we see as our strengths, our respect for the value of individual human life, is also our weakness. This is not an easy challenge for the alliance of nations that are facing him. There have been many who have already criticised the delay in bringing the matter to a head, saying that it only strengthens Saddam's hand. It is true that during this time he has been able to build fortifications, particularly around Kuwait. I am of the school that believes that all peaceful alternatives must be first exhausted, but these efforts must not be seen as an unwillingness to fight and sacrifice if ultimately necessary.

I commend the leadership of President Bush and the United States of America (USA) in this incredibly challenging situation.
