I am pleased that Australia is standing alongside the United States, Britain, Canada and others in a joint commitment to repel the illegal use of force. If this action is successful, I believe that it will establish the basis of a new world order in the post-Cold War era environment, an order that will be based on collective security, albeit for some time with the leadership of the United States and its other North Atlantic Treaty Organisation partner-and this is important. In our own region with a reduction of United States forces, stability and security will be harder to guarantee. We will all have to play an increased role, which further demonstrates how foolish and short-sighted has been this Government's very limited defence strategy. No doubt that is something that will be taken up either today or on other occasions by my colleagues Senator Durack, Senator MacGibbon and others.

To re-establish, at the outset of this new multipolar world, the principle of respect for international law and the sovereignty of nation states is vital. To demonstrate that the use of terror, threats and the taking of hostages is intolerable and will incur a massive penalty is important. Although some have dismissed this as a conflict over oil, for a dictator to control almost one half of the world's oil resources, which he would have done if he had taken the oilfields of north-eastern Saudi Arabia, and thus to hold the world to economic ransom is just as dangerous.

There are many lessons which should have been already learnt from this conflict. The regional political history is complex. It should be realised that Iraq's claims to Kuwait predate Saddam Hussein. Iraq's claims and its justification for its invasion are a mixture of anti-colonial rhetoric and appeals to national interest. To Iraq, Kuwait was an undemocratic relic from colonial days which needed to be swept aside in the name of decolonisation. Kuwait was further perceived to challenge Iraq's national interests. In particular, its policy in relation to the price of oil was said to be hurting the Iraqi economy to the point where it could no longer be endured. There was a demand for $2.4 billion in compensation for oil claimed to have been syphoned off from an Iraqi oilfield during the Gulf war, and the border dispute over the Rumeilah oilfields provided grounds for Iraqi claims of Kuwaiti indifference to their interests.

However, Kuwaiti credentials under the UN charter were quite in order. If one legitimises the historical challenge which Iraq seeks to make of Kuwait in this instance, then there will be no certainty in state sovereignty or the sanctity of borders. That does not mean that I do not see democratisation of the somewhat feudal regime in Kuwait as important, but that is another issue. One may argue that such reform is overdue in much of the region. In any event, Kuwait's credentials as a responsible member of the international community more than match up alongside those of Saddam's regime.

The West misread Saddam Hussein. He was seen for some time as the more moderate alternative in the war with Iran. He was seen as soft on pan-Arabism and he was seen as pro-West in Western disputes with Syria and Iran. His brutality was overlooked and in that lies a lesson-the lesson being not to overlook gross human rights abuses in search of short term political gain. Even if it is not possible for other countries to take decisive action to redress human rights violations, this conflict demonstrates that it is a mistake to allow this to obscure intelligence assessments or policy development.

With the benefit of hindsight, what seemed like a readiness to accommodate Western interests in relation to, say, Arab unity or the Palestinian issue now seems more like a complete lack of principles. Flexibility may be more dangerous than inflexible adherence to unpalatable principles. The Iraq experience has also demonstrated the danger of massive military support to help maintain a balance with another state-in this case it was with Iran-when what it does also is put the first state out of balance with others in the region. It is an important lesson because there is already talk of massive regional arms build-ups in an attempt to guard against further Iraqi aggression. It is now clear that Western nations should have paid more attention to the armaments programs in Iraq.

The scale of conventional armaments, as well as the gas and chemical warfare weaponry being amassed by Iraq, created a potential threat that should not have been ignored in favour of the short term expedience of assisting Iraq to wage war against Iran. The effect of this military capacity on the evolution of Iraqi intentions should also have been considered. Even if defensive motives alone had led Iraq to acquire such huge military capacity, the possession of military might on such a scale would itself inevitably become a factor in the equation. It would inspire fear in Iraq's neighbours and expand the options available to Iraq in dealing with its neighbours.

The armaments programs in Arab states now being proposed to guarantee the security of other Arab states against Iraq, if they go ahead on the scale being reported, have the potential to become a major destabilising factor in the whole Middle East equation. This would arouse fear not only in Israel but also internationally. There are other lessons which should have already been learnt from this conflict, not least the need for a more sophisticated understanding of the Arab world. There was, in fact, a lot of evidence that Saddam might invade Kuwait, but Western intelligence organisations, including our own, apparently misread it. The line was drawn in the sand to protect Saudi Arabia when there was much less evidence of Saddam's intention to attack the Saudis. Saudi Arabia has never been an historical claim of Iraq. In making that point, I do not criticise the decision because, having misread Saddam once, the West could not afford to misread him twice.

The conflict will inevitably change the balance in the region, and not necessarily for the better. Syria's power and authority, and particularly that of President Assad, will be enhanced by victory over Iraq. Syrian-Egyptian friendship seems to be blossoming following the restoration of diplomatic relations broken 12 years ago. President Assad is thought to be hoping that this will lead to financial assistance from Saudi Arabia and political favours from the West. Relaxation of sanctions imposed following Syrian association with terrorist activities would obviously be high on the Syrians' agenda. They have already achieved their objective with Britain. Pressure on Israel to return the Golan Heights captured in 1967 and a place at an international peace conference on Palestine would be further concessions that Syria may hope to achieve in the longer term with this new tack.

Events in Lebanon further complicate the regional picture. The overthrow of Aoun, barely noticed against the background noise of the conflict over Kuwait, represents a widening Syrian influence in the region. Clearly, its alliance with the United States in relation to Iraq has given Syria a new confidence, the full significance of which is yet to be determined.

Iran is another potential winner in the Middle East power struggle. It now has the opportunity to rid itself of its hated enemy, Saddam Hussein, at no further cost except the presence of the US and other non-believers in the region. That presence is unlikely to be tolerated for long after the conclusion of the conflict.

The Palestinians seem to have particularly suffered as a result of the conflict. Yasser Arafat has said that they should take side with the force that opposes their enemy most firmly and, therefore, chooses Iraq. That has lost him legitimacy in the eyes of the Western world as he has similarly lost the support of key Arab previous supporters, Egypt and Saudi Arabia. At the same time, the invasion has cut off the Palestinians from their valuable source of funds through their guest workers in Kuwait, and efforts by Saddam Hussein to link the Palestinian issue in an effort to divert attention to the common enemy, Israel, fortunately have so far proved unsuccessful.

Jordan has looked particularly fragile as it has wrestled to balance its beneficial interests in, and fear of, Iraq with its interests in the West. All of this demonstrates that there will be fundamental changes as a result of this conflict which go far beyond the consequences of the front line battle.

A security order in the post-conflict environment will be very complex. If Saddam maintains his military machine-and it is worth noting that the UN resolutions are limited to the invasion and occupation of Kuwait-the Saudis and the Gulf states, as I have said, are likely to want ongoing US or Western presence. As I also said, that is unlikely to be tolerated for long and efforts will be made to find an Arab security arrangement. Such an arrangement at the moment is difficult to envisage. The split in the Arab League is, in fact, likely to be an important, enduring effect of the invasion. Within the League, new alliances are being formed with unpredictable future consequences for the Palestinian and other regional issues.

Ultimately, Saddam will be forced from Kuwait, one hopes peacefully. But this conflict-the Gulf crisis-as a whole will not be resolved if he retains his chemical, biological and potential nuclear capacity. Whether Australia is becoming engaged in a conflict to achieve that objective has yet to be acknowledged. The conflict will further not be satisfactorily resolved without the achievement of regional stability. This will inevitably call for longer term negotiation and compromise.

Whilst the immediate conflict is the paramount consideration, it would be wise for Western interests now to be contemplating the post-crisis regional security arrangements. Even Australia, which has had a good record in peacekeeping and observer contributions within the region, should be contemplating the contribution it might make in the future.

In conclusion, therefore, Australia has vital interests in this conflict which require a commitment to preserve. We should not underestimate the potential cost of that preservation, as has been set out in the Prime Minister's statement. Our genuine thanks must go to those servicemen who are at risk for our benefit and to their families. We, as policy makers, must work harder and more capably in developing international relations in a way that ensures justice, peace and stability. It seems to us on this side of the chamber that that is the least we can offer to those who put their lives at risk to preserve our interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In normal circumstances when a significant statement such as this has been made, the National Party of Australia would allow the leader of the coalition, Senator Hill, to respond on behalf of the National Party. But because this is such a significant statement, I feel that I should support Senator Hill in his contribution-a very good contribution too, I might say-and also put down a statement on behalf of the National Party.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset, let me say that the National Party supports the statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on developments in the Gulf. Rarely has the world been so united in condemning the actions of one country oppressing another. The resolution was carried and supported by four of the superpowers, and significant countries such as Canada and Romania, showing that it has world support.

On 2 August, Iraq overran Kuwait and seized that country by force. Our response at that stage was to send three ships into the Gulf of Oman to enforce an embargo. The world was outraged and placed an embargo on goods leaving and entering Iraq. The ships that we sent helped to enforce that embargo. The United Nations ratified this action and has now authorised all member states of the United Nations from 15 January 1991 to use all necessary means to uphold and implement the resolution of the Security Council.

Accordingly, the National Party supports the Government's authorisation of the Australian Defence Force to deploy ships of our task force in the Persian Gulf to exercise and operate with our naval allies, in particular, the United States, Great Britain and Canada. We also support the participation of our Defence Force in allied military planning. The National Party commends the professionalism of the Royal Australian Navy and applauds the effort of our task force to date.

We extend our sympathy in this festive season to those families who will be separated at Christmas time-not only of the Navy personnel on the three ships of our task force but also of the medical teams which are there at present and the two other medical teams which are about to leave to serve as well on the hospital ships in the Gulf.

Our thoughts at this time must also be with the 30 Australian hostages still in Iraq who not only will be without friends or families at Christmas but also who do not even know when they will be able to return to Australia and be united, once more, with their families and resume their normal lives. We support the Prime Minister's statement because their future must be considered at all times.

The United Nations resolution made specific reference to serious violation by Iraq of human rights, especially in occupied Kuwait. I want to remind the Senate of the unanimity of the nations of the world in condemning the actions of Iraq.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I apologise to Senator Boswell but I draw attention to the fact that there is not even one Minister in the chamber.

—I also want to remind the Senate, in particular, of the wholehearted support for the United States by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR). Only yesterday the USSR issued a statement which welcomed the initiative from President Bush to hold talks with Iraq between now and 15 January. I believe everyone in this Senate, representing all sections of the Australian community, would wish that those talks would lead to peace without war taking place. (Quorum formed) I must point out that the Government is showing very little interest in this major issue. Only a few moments ago there was one person from the Government side in the chamber, and no Minister.
—No Government senators; there were plenty from the Opposition.
—Yes. Plenty of Opposition and Democrat senators interested in this most significant statement were in the chamber but there was only one Government member, and that person was not a Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: The USSR also supports the United Nations Security Council resolution authorising the use of force to expel Iraqi troops from Kuwait as a step forward in the quest for a peaceful solution in the Gulf. The USSR has firmly indicated that it is now up to Iraq, and Iraq alone, whether there will be peace in the Persian Gulf. This action by Iraq cannot be sufficiently condemned.

Saddam Hussein is a man who runs a bankrupt country of 16 million people; who fought with Iran for eight years, thus costing millions of lives; who has hostile relations with most of his neighbours; who uses poison gas on his own people; who executes his own colleagues; who overruns another country with unjustified aggression and continues a regime of torture, arrests, executions and abductions of helpless people; and who detains foreign nationals against their will and uses many of them as human shields by holding them near military and strategic installations. This man, who governs that country, will not be overcome by sanctions alone. This man must be forced to withdraw from Kuwait before he has time to build up even greater military forces. We cannot stand by and accept Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Therefore, we welcome and support the Government's move, which will bring us closer to a peaceful but definite conclusion to a situation which Iraq alone has created.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats welcomed the news, when it was conveyed to us via the mass media, as it was to other Australians, of the decision of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to inform the Parliament of the Government's approach to the Gulf crisis in light of last week's resolution of the United Nations Security Council, which authorised the possible use of force against Iraq after 15 January next year. But we deeply regret the fact that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) was not prepared to verbally deliver in this place that statement of the Prime Minister, which is probably the most important statement in this chamber and in this Parliament for decades. It is especially a matter of regret since it is only in this chamber that there is any dissent at all from the Government's position and from the position of the United States of America in this whole matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Before turning to the substance of the Prime Minister's statement, I express my extreme disappointment that the Government has failed to follow what the Democrats regard as appropriate democratic processes for authorising military action by Australian forces deployed overseas. The Senate will recall that the Government consulted Parliament over the deployment of Australian naval vessels to join the United States-led blockade in Iraq and Kuwait by way of a resolution put to both chambers. The decision to commit our naval forces to possible military action under United States operational command is clearly of even greater significance than the decision to join the blockade. It should have been possible only with the concurrence of both Houses, yet we do not even have a motion before us seeking the Senate's opinion.

I emphasise that the Democrats, who represent more than one million voters-a majority of whom gave their second preferences to the Australian Labor Party-were not consulted in advance of today's statement. The Government has clearly decided to consult only those who will agree with it or who can at least be neutralised by the consultative process. That was all the more reason why we wanted to hear the Leader of the Government in this place deliver this very important statement.

In addressing the substance of the Prime Minister's statement, I begin by acknowledging that the Democrats strongly agree with some of its premises and conclusions. Throughout this crisis we have attempted to play a constructive role in support of a peaceful outcome. In making what we believe are justified criticisms of the Government's stance, we have remained mindful of the fact that an act of international aggression which demanded a concerted international response was committed by Iraq against Kuwait.

There is no excuse for Iraq's actions. Despite the historical basis of Iraq's claim on Kuwait and its grievances against the ousted al-Sabah regime, the use of military force cannot be justified. We have never attempted to justify that invasion. It is for this reason that the Democrats fully support the comprehensive sanctions imposed, with humanitarian exemptions, by the Security Council so speedily after the invasion of Kuwait by Saddam Hussein. Those sanctions must remain in place until Iraq withdraws from Kuwait and releases all hostages. Indeed, mandatory sanctions banning nuclear, chemical and military cooperation should be imposed for a considerable period thereafter.

It is worth reminding the Senate that the sanctions are unprecedented in their scope and effect, partly because of the international community's determination to liberate Kuwait, and partly because of Iraq's unusual economic vulnerability. Ninety-five per cent of Iraq's exports and about 90 per cent of its imports have been cut off. Industrial production is thought to have dropped off by 40 per cent already, a trend which will eventually bring the Iraqi economy to an effective halt. It is at this point that the Democrats strongly contest the Government's judgment. I quote from today's statement:

Nor does the Government believe that further economic hardship . . . is likely to change the minds of Iraq's leaders. Sanctions . . . cannot force the hand of a dictatorial leadership which is willing to ignore the interests of its people.

We ask: on what basis has this judgment been formed? Surely, sanctions which have the capacity to cripple Iraq's economic activity will eventually lead its leadership into an impossible position. To make such a sweeping judgment as is made in this statement, that sanctions are guaranteed to fail, is excessively pessimistic and extremely premature.

In fact, if this judgment is correct, why did the Australian Government support the imposition of sanctions in the first place? Why has Senator Gareth Evans repeatedly called for sanctions to be given time to work if the Government could see that they were never going to work? If the Government genuinely supports this judgment-the judgment articulated in today's statement-the quality of its assessments must be seriously questioned. If it does not believe that sanctions cannot work but is simply grasping for a justification for a United States led war, and at a time which suits the United States, it stands condemned for its dangerous cynicism.

From the outset of this crisis, it was widely acknowledged that the sanctions would have to be given 12 to 18 months to convince the Iraqi leadership that it had no way to move but out of Kuwait. This point was emphatically reinforced by the former head of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff, Admiral William Crowe, when he told a congressional committee that the wait would be worth while as a means of avoiding war. The Australian Democrats would urge the Government in the strongest possible terms to allow this period to pass to give sanctions time to work or to bite harder than they are already biting.

We fear that Security Council resolution 678 is creating an expectation that war will commence soon after 15 January if Iraq has not withdrawn by that time. Those who argue for early military action point to the deteriorating situation in Kuwait; the impact of the sanctions on the economies of developing nations; the possible development by Iraq of further military might, including a nuclear weapons capability; and the possible loss of domestic support for President Bush's policies if the crisis drags on.

The military and nuclear arguments are furphies. The continuation of military and nuclear sanctions against Iraq, even after it complies with the Security Council resolutions, would constrain such developments. According to all sober assessments from outside the Pentagon, Iraq is still years away from acquiring the bomb. The impatience of the public of the United States is the single most important force behind the push for war and in the timetabling thereof. This of course is an entirely insufficient justification. It is also a double-edged sword. The United States people may be impatient but they do not want war. The awful situation in Kuwait and the economic impact of the sanctions, both of which are highlighted in today's statement, are of great concern.

The Democrats freely acknowledge that there is no easy solution to this crisis. The choice is not between good and bad options; it is between bad and worse ones. In choosing between these options, it is essential to look at both sides of the coin, to count the costs as well as the benefits of military action. Today's statement by the Government completely fails to count the costs. No attempt is made to assess the human impact of an attack on Kuwait and Iraq. The suffering caused by such an assault would, in all likelihood, exceed the suffering which has been caused by Iraq's occupation so far. According to yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald, the Office of the National Assessments has concluded that war would last just two weeks and cost only 500 lives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense. There is no such report.

—This is completely at odds with every other assessment that I have seen, including those of Senator Gareth Evans, which all conclude that thousands, perhaps tens of thousands, of people would die and that fighting would go on for months at least. If there was a good chance that suffering would be more alleviated by military action than would be caused by it, as was the case with Vietnam's 1979 invasion of Cambodia, for instance, the military option would have much more to commend it.

SPEECH.PARA: Today's statement by the Prime Minister fails to count the political cost, even though it more or less acknowledges that any war may effectively be fought between Third World Iraq and the Anglo-Saxon First World-the United States, Britain, Canada and Australia. The potential to divide the international community and, particularly, the countries of the Middle East is all too real with the resulting international tensions lasting for many more generations. While the Democrats do not believe that an Iraqi withdrawal should be contingent upon a resolution of the Israel-Palestine conflict or vice versa, we believe that the campaign against Iraq should not worsen existing problems in the Middle East. A non-military approach carries far fewer risks in this regard than the threat of war.

The statement makes no mention of the possible use of nuclear weapons by the United States. It should be appreciated that Australia would be directly implicated in any nuclear attack. The bases in Australia and our warships in the Gulf are firmly tied into US military strategy. The Government has already indicated that the use of nuclear weapons would not lead it to cease its military involvement in the Gulf. Brian Toohey pointed out in the Sun-Herald of 2 December that the Government's position will not enhance Australia's credibility on the issue of nuclear non-proliferation, a credibility which in any post-invasion scenario will be tremendously important.

The Prime Minister's statement emphasises the precedent that the campaign against Iraq sets for the post-Cold War international order. Does this mean, we have to ask, that military action should be taken against all big countries that are attempting to subjugate smaller ones? Will we see an assault on East Timor to drive out the Indonesian forces there? Is Tibet to be liberated by a massive US force? Should the Soviet Union and China have invaded Panama in response to the illegal US invasion of that country? Will troops be sent into the Occupied Territories to drive out an invader that clearly has no intention of leaving? The answer in each case is no. If the international campaign against Iraq is to serve as a precedent, as this statement before us today suggests, it must be sustainable under other circumstances. This is yet another compelling argument in favour of a non-military strategy built on patience.

In essence, the Democrats' view of the Gulf conflict is that Australia should not be involved in any military action in the region. We need long term solutions to pressing issues which exist already in the Middle East and, as I have suggested, in many other parts of the world. Early in the conflict after the invasion, the Democrats stood ready to support any measures of the Security Council deemed necessary to monitor and, if necessary, to enforce the sanctions.

TALK.START.PARA: —You supported the concept of a United Nations led force.

—The Government was not prepared to wait, even though the sanctions began to take effect almost immediately with the oil flow from Iraq drying up before the multinational flotilla assembled in the Gulf. We did support the concept of a UN led force, should the UN have determined so. The Security Council, by its authority, having been usurped by a fait accompli eventually, but half-heartedly, endorsed a blockade which was already in place.

SPEECH.PARA: It soon became obvious that the naval forces in the Gulf far exceeded the demands of sanctions enforcement. It is now clear that their presence was in preparation for a more offensive role. Australia's naval commitment is no exception and is part of that exercise. Australia's warships in the Gulf must be withdrawn. We must redouble our efforts to work for a peaceful resolution rather than blindly follow the United States into the abyss of war.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia is a country that has always taken its international obligations very seriously indeed, both in peace and in war. We are a country that has been very conscious of the need for principles of good international citizenship to be a central prevailing theme of our foreign policy. We are a country which has spoken out without fear or favour when questions of freedom and justice have been an issue on the international stage. We are a country that has been prepared, over the years, over the decades, to match our rhetoric with action in appropriate circumstances. We are a country that has given the strongest possible support to the United Nations (UN) since the very inception of that international organisation. We were present at its creation with the activities particularly of Dr Evatt being of pre-eminent importance in the measures embodied in the United Nations charter to protect the interests of small states.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been present at just about every peacekeeping operation that has been put in train by the United Nations over the 45 years of its existence. We are also a country and a government which is very conscious of the need to protect our own national interests and in particular our security interests. We are conscious of the volatility that has traditionally existed in our own Asian and Asian Pacific neighbourhood. We are conscious of the need to ensure-and it is very well understood in our part of the world, as elsewhere-that aggression and adventurism will be met by united and concerted international response.

Mr Acting Deputy President, all of those factors come together in the decision which has been announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) today in response to a specific request for assistance, for support, from the United Nations. Those factors have come together in the decision that has been made and announced that Australia is prepared to make our naval task force available to serve with allied forces in operations authorised by UN Security Council resolution 678, if that becomes-we all hope it does not become-necessary.

Together with the two additional small medical units that will also be sent to the Gulf, that is a specific and quite substantial contribution, meeting a very real need and constituting a very valuable addition to the available resources now concentrated in the Gulf. It is not a contribution that we propose to increase and it is not one that we would expect to be asked to increase. I appreciate the support that the Opposition has given to this response and indeed throughout this crisis.

There are some specific points that need to be made or emphasised at this stage of the debate, not least in response to some of the things that Senator Powell has just been saying. The points I want to make are these. First, the Australian response is pursuant to the United Nations request in what is now very much a United Nations exercise, not a United States one, whatever Senator Powell might be inclined to continue to assert. Secondly, I want to make the point that this is an eminently appropriate case in which the United Nations should be involved in the way in which it has now become involved. Thirdly, this is now the time to act in the way that the United Nations has done. Fourthly, there is every chance that the actions of the Security Council and others in support of it will bear fruit without there being a need for military action to actually occur.

So far as the United Nations itself is concerned, however people may have wanted to characterise the Gulf crisis in its early days, there can be no conceivable doubt whatsoever that the response to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait is something that has the wholehearted support and endorsement of the United Nations. We have seen a series of 12 resolutions passed by the UN Security Council-most of them unanimously, none with more than two states, usually Cuba and Yemen, opposed. Those resolutions have involved a steady escalation of response over the period since August, making clear what the world's objectives were so far as Iraq was concerned; initially seeking to achieve those objectives by way of economic sanctions and boycott; then supporting those economic sanctions with military backing; now proceeding to make clear that unless those objectives are satisfied by the middle of January, Iraq must expect member nations to take all necessary means, including the use of force, to ensure that they are observed. It is a carefully modulated, carefully developed systematic response by the body that was set up to do just exactly what it is doing.

The tragedy of the United Nations, of course, over the last generation, over the last 45 years since the War, is that it has not been able to do what we would all have liked it to do in terms of responding to situations of aggression or indefensible intervention that have occurred over that 45-year period. The Cold War has imposed its own discipline over that period on the capacity of the United Nations to respond, and it is only with the death at long last of the Cold War that that kind of capacity is now there.

Let it not be forgotten, overlooked or misunderstood that what the UN has now authorised, through the latest Security Council resolution, is something squarely within the contemplation of the Charter and squarely within the contemplation of the founders of the United Nations. There were four peace related roles explicitly or implicitly spelt out in the Charter or in the understanding of those who were present at its birth.

It was understood and believed that the United Nations would have a role in peace making, in conciliation, particularly through the efforts of the Secretary-General to anticipate problems, to mediate, to negotiate, to resolve them. Secondly, it was well understood that the UN would have a role in peacekeeping, in sending bodies of member nations, troops and officials, to implement, to monitor, to supervise settlements of disputes that were reached under UN auspices, and there have been many examples of such peacekeeping operations, in most of which, as I have already said, Australia has participated.

Thirdly, the UN had a role identified for itself, which it has exercised since, so far as disarmament is concerned. The Conference on Disarmament in Geneva is the standing UN body directed at achieving just those objectives, which we all share-again, crucial in the peace process. But there is a fourth peace related role for the United Nations and that is peace enforcement, peace enforcement of the kind that is anticipated, spelt out in outline, in Chapter 7 of the Charter itself, a peace enforcement role of the kind that Dr Evatt very articulately identified back in 1945 as something the UN had to be prepared to do. We have the quotes there, they are in the Prime Minister's statement, when Dr Evatt said in 1945 that if economic or diplomatic sanctions:
are deemed inappropriate to the situation or prove ineffective, the Security Council may take any military action necessary to suppress the aggressor.
He also said-I quote again from the Prime Minister's statement:

It must be made crystal clear that the nations seeking representation in the world organisation must be prepared to contribute their share of physical force to restrain the action of proved aggressors.

This is not a latter day invention; this is something that has been part of the whole fabric of the concept of the United Nations because most people around the world have understood, much better than the Australian Democrats seem to understand, that ultimately there are some situations of naked aggression, of indefensible exercises of military raw power, that can be satisfactorily responded to at the end of the day only by the threat of a similar response. Far better that that response come from the world body and its member states, acting through the world body, than for it to come individually.

The point that I am making is one that is particularly important to draw attention to in the present context when one reflects that Senator Powell herself and the Australian Democrats have been saying from the outset of this crisis that the UN must have a role; have been acknowledging from the outset that there is a role for the United Nations to play in a military enforcement sense. Senator Powell on 10 August in a press release said:
Without UN approval, Australia has no legitimate military role in the Middle East.

Now there is UN approval. Is Senator Powell going to eat those words? Senator Bourne on 17 August put out another news release in similar terms. Senator Powell on 21 August is reported in Hansard. Senator Spindler is reported on 22 August in Hansard again. Senator Bourne again on 9 October stated:

I believe that a peaceful solution is still possible through negotiation, and I am encouraged by the involvement of the United Nations (UN). I believe that stronger involvement by that body is desirable and probable.

She was right: it was probable, it had to happen, it was desirable. It has now happened and let us have a little less churlishness, a little more honesty and a little more consistency from the Australian Democrats. Let us have a recognition that the Democrats have now exactly what they said they wanted: not just a unilateral United States exercise or an Australian exercise, they have a genuinely international exercise led by the very body that they owe recognition and respect to and that they have already acknowledged in those earlier statements.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats are silent.
—Of course they are silent; they have nothing to say. The second point I want to make is that this is a very appropriate case for the exercise of this kind of response by the international community.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many circumstances of indefensible intervention by other countries in the past that would, I believe, equally have justified such a response. The fact that that response was not possible for reasons of the Cold War and the exercise of competing veto powers does not in any way make less appropriate the response on this particular occasion. Of course I accept the point that Senator Powell makes, that this must not be treated as one-off case; that, if we are serious about an international response to the exercise of aggression by one sovereign country against another, we must be prepared again in the future if these situations do arise-and one hopes to God that they will not-to react in a similar way. It is a point that is well taken. I believe in the virtue of consistency here as elsewhere.

It is important nonetheless to appreciate the particular enormity of what Iraq has done in this situation. Gianni de Michelis, the Italian Foreign Minister, made the point very clearly in a statement not so long ago when he said that there has been no analogy since Hitler of the total annexation of a weaker neighbouring state by another. There have been examples-Timor is one-of annexation of a weaker neighbouring territory by another. It may be that the moral difference is not very great, but one needs to appreciate that there is something very specially unsavoury about what has happened with the Iraqi annexation of Kuwait. It is an example, a precedent, that we have not seen in precisely these terms since the 1930s, and God forbid again that we should see any such example in the future.

It is an example that assumes a particularly alarming character when one bears in mind the nature of Iraq and the Iraqi regime. It is a country of only medium size but with a million people under arms. It is a highly militarist country, a country that has shown a demonstrated willingness to use chemical weapons against its own people and other countries. It is a country that is in the business of manufacturing nuclear weapons just as soon as it proves able to do so. Moreover, it is a country that is in a position to impose a stranglehold not only on its immediate neighbours but on the economies of the whole world because of the particular sensitivity of the Gulf region. But all those considerations, especially unsavoury and especially alarming as they are, do not change the fundamental nature of the problem in this instance. The thing that makes it so crucial that there be an international reaction of the kind that we have seen is that it is simply a case of naked, indefensible aggression by a stronger neighbour against a weaker one. It is the kind of thing that must not be allowed to succeed, if any of us are to have any confidence about the viability and stability of the post-Cold War world.

My third point is that this is an appropriate time for the international community, for the United Nations and for those acting pursuant to its decisions to act. We had all hoped that sanctions would bear fruit by now. The kind of timeframe we were all talking about within which we hoped that that would occur was six months. Twelve to 18 months was, as Senator Powell said, one of the outside suggestions that were being made, but certainly it was nobody's conviction that we could afford to wait that long for something to actually happen, other than on the most pessimistic assumptions. The unhappy truth is that nearly six months have now elapsed in the application of those sanctions and, successful as they have been in all sorts of ways, they have not yet borne fruit in terms of an evident willingness on behalf of the Iraqi regime to accept the logical consequences of those sanctions and to abandon its aspirations to maintain control over Kuwait.

Part of the problem, I suspect, is that sanctions always have at least as much a psychological dimension as a physical one. It was not really a matter for those of us who pinned our faith on sanctions of actually physically driving Iraq to its knees within that kind of timeframe. Rather it was a matter of demonstrating enough damage within that timeframe and demonstrating enough solidarity and persistence on the part of the rest of the world to make the inevitability of that damage apparent to the Iraqi regime. The point of sanctions was to make clear the inexorability of very real damage to the Iraqi people and the Iraqi economy, and to encourage on that basis a rational decision from the Iraqi leadership.

What was crucial if that psychological impact was to apply was solidarity in the international response. There has been solidarity in the application of sanctions to the extent that one could possibly hope for, but there has not been solidarity in terms, regrettably, of the bizarre experience that we have seen in recent weeks of the hostage envoys and the hostage negotiations. I fear that it has to be acknowledged that that has done something to create already, at least until the United Nations resolution of last week, a feeling in Saddam that if he only hung on long enough he could divide, confuse and weaken that international solidarity and make in due course the threat of that sanctions pressure upon him fade quietly away. This is only speculation and that may be an overstatement but, when one is talking as one so often has to in these contexts about the likely psychological reaction of a nation and of a leadership to the international pressure upon us, these points, regrettably, cannot entirely be pushed to one side.

Not only is the sanctions strategy not showing signs of bearing fruit within a reasonable timeframe but it is clearly bearing a very devastating fruit on the economies of the developing world. While the uncertainty persists and oil prices stay as high as they are, the economic damage to innumerable countries in Asia, in Africa and, indeed, in eastern Europe, is all too starkly evident. That is the discipline, as much as anything else, as was spelled out in President Bush's statement and in the Prime Minister's statement, that has made the world appreciate that an additional form of pressure should now appropriately be applied.

The final point I make is that following the decision that has been made by the United Nations Security Council to create the threat of military assault on Iraq, an achievement of the United Nations objectives by military means, the pressure that has been now so placed on Iraq has, I believe, every chance of producing a peaceful solution. There is no inevitability, no necessity, no compulsion about that particular UN Security Council resolution now being followed by military action. What was necessary, for all the reasons I have been trying to spell out, were some additional layers of very self-evident pressure, creating an appreciation, as nothing else could, of the overwhelming might and the unanimity of forces stacked up against Iraq. That pressure, there is some ground for hoping, will bear fruit in terms of an appreciation by Iraq that it has everything to lose and nothing to gain by persisting with its occupation of Kuwait.

At the same time it needs to be appreciated that the pressure inherent in the UN resolution itself has been accompanied by an expression of willingness to talk, to open up a line of communication and to explore the possibility of achieving a peaceful solution. The United States leadership has made it very clear that such a willingness to talk will not be a willingness that will put at risk in any way the unconditionality of the three basic UN articulated objectives-withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait, recreation of the status quo as far as the Government of Kuwait is concerned, and of course the release of all the hostages held there against their will.

But there is no doubt that talk of the kind that is contemplated in the statements of the United States leadership and which has now been accepted by Iraq will ease the way, will make it possible to define some areas where, without sacrificing those basic principles or attaching conditions to what must remain unconditional, progress can nonetheless be made. I am talking of the kinds of matters that were bilaterally in issue between Iraq and Kuwait before the invasion occurred, and I am talking in particular about the whole range of matters which go to the future security of the region about which Senator Hill spoke in his contribution.

I refer to questions about the presence or absence after the crisis is over of the United States and other foreign forces; questions about the presence or absence of Arab League forces operating as a buffer zone; questions about a possible negotiated conventional force reduction agreement in the region; and questions about a possible chemical weapons-and, indeed, even nuclear weapons-free zone arrangements for the region, all of which could well prove to be at least as much as in Iraq's longer term interest as everybody else's.

It is not part of the objectives of the UN, the United States, Australia or anybody else to demolish Iraq militarily. Some people would like to see that happen but it is not something that is necessarily required, I believe, by the situation if Iraq can be persuaded otherwise to peacefully withdraw. There will need to be some rethinking about the security arrangements in the region as a whole in the aftermath of such a withdrawal. There will need to be some guarantees that Iraq will not behave in this way again-not that it is likely to be minded to after experiencing the combined reaction of the international community in this instance.

I make that point because it is sometimes said-it has not been in today's debate-that Western or United Nations objectives will only really be satisfied if there is a military downsizing of Iraq, and that can only be accomplished by military action. That is not part of the objectives of this enterprise and, accordingly, a peaceful scenario is still very possible indeed. Certainly, as I have made clear, and as the Prime Minister and Senator Ray have made clear, the Australian Government hopes against hope that there will be a peaceful solution.

We are in no doubts about the costs of a military action. We have no doubt that any military action-however quickly it can be accomplished-will be brutal and bloody. There is no foundation for believing that as few as 500 lives will be lost in such military action and no basis on which that figure has ever been put before us by the Office of National Assessments or anybody else. That particular press report, to which Senator Powell referred, was a complete furphy.

We hope, as we always hope, that this will be capable of peaceful solution. But it is only capable of peaceful solution if Iraq understands the nature of the forces that are now amassed against it; if it understands the enormity of the breaches of international law that it has committed; and if it acts to avoid disaster for its own people. We hope it will.

We express that hope, too, from the point of view of our own hostages and the hostages of so many other countries that are still trapped in that country and in Kuwait. Our policy reaction cannot be driven by that consideration and we know that that is well understood by the hostages themselves. But that does not mean that we are in any way forgetful, heartless or oblivious to the continuing human tragedy-it is a tragedy in some instances-of the position of those people of ours and other countries in Kuwait and their families back at home. We will continue to do everything we possibly can to get them out.

Australia will go on acting as we have in this matter; we will go on holding together firmly with the international community; and we will go on supporting the United Nations in the kind of strategy that is now being mapped out. Simply, we believe that this is the best way of bringing this whole unhappy affair rapidly to an end. We believe that it is the best way of getting all our people out. We believe it is the best way of creating the conditions for a lasting peace-not only in the Gulf but, indeed, worldwide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 August this year this Parliament overwhelmingly supported a number of resolutions which condemned the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq as contrary to international law and morality; called upon Iraq to withdraw its forces unconditionally from Kuwait; affirmed the fundamental importance of the United Nations Charter as the basis for the conduct of international relations and the preservation of peace; welcomed the United Nations prompt and unprecedented action in adopting mandatory and comprehensive sanctions against Iraq to force it to comply with the United Nations decisions; and supported the Government's decision to send ships of the Royal Australian Navy to the Middle East to assist in enforcing United Nations sanctions against Iraq.

SPEECH.PARA: The only exception to the overwhelming support of those resolutions in this chamber and in the other place was a qualification by the Australian Democrats in respect of support for the decision to send Royal Australian Navy ships. But other than that, they had the overwhelming support of the Parliament. As Senator Evans has pointed out, all parties in the Parliament have given strong support to the role of the United Nations in this whole sorry episode since 2 August this year when Iraq invaded and very rapidly occupied the whole of Kuwait.

Prior to the debate in this Parliament on 21 August, the Opposition had supported the decision of the Government made on 10 August this year to send a naval task force to the Gulf region for the purpose of enforcing the United Nations mandatory sanctions which had been imposed just a few days before by the Security Council on 6 August. The Opposition has consistently supported that decision that Australia should play a role in giving effect to the stand by the United Nations.

It is now the responsibility of this Parliament again to take note of a further development in the Middle East. Last week the United Nations passed another most important resolution. It has passed a series of resolutions since 6 August when it imposed mandatory sanctions. The most recent resolution authorises members of the United Nations to use all necessary means to uphold and implement the Security Council's previous resolutions on the crisis which substantially call for the unconditional withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait and the release of hostages.

The Security Council resolution of 29 November is only the second resolution of its kind in the history of the United Nations. The first was in 1950 when the United Nations called for the use, if necessary, of armed force against North Korea when that country invaded South Korea. However, last week's resolution is really much more significant than the 1950 resolution which was passed only because the Soviet Union, which has a veto, absented itself from the Council meeting.

However, last week resolution 678 was sponsored, not just supported, by four of the five members of the Security Council. Never before has there been such international unity in opposing an act of aggression by one state against another. That is the important background to the decision made by the Government, which we are discussing in this debate. Resolution 678 also explicitly requested members of the United Nations to provide support and assistance for that resolution.

For that reason alone, I think the situation is very different from some of the other cases to which Senator Powell referred when she said, `Why are we taking military action to enforce the United Nations decision? Why wasn't it be done in relation to Indonesia and Timor or China and Tibet?'. In none of these cases, over a period of 40 years, did the United Nations pass a resolution specifically of this character, nor did it request members of the United Nations to give their support. For that reason alone-of course there are many other reasons, which have already been well expressed by Senator Hill and Senator Evans in this debate-the significance of last week's resolution of the United Nations cannot be overemphasised.

Not only is it significant in the sense that this is only the second time the United Nations has done this in over 40 years; it is also significant that the United Nations has so promptly in the post-Cold War era-as it is now referred to-taken the opportunity to achieve the purposes its founders had in mind at the end of the Second World War. By 1945, the world had experienced in the first half of the twentieth century the enormous convulsions of the first and second world wars. The determination of the world at that stage was to set up an international organisation to prevent, if possible, acts of international aggression or at least to minimise them as much as it could, to reverse the sorry history of the first half of the twentieth century and to reverse the whole history of mankind.

The world had been brought to such a crisis by the first half of the twentieth century that high hopes were held that by supporting the United Nations the world might be able to prevent the sort of naked aggression which had occurred particularly in Europe and in our own region during the Second World War. It also had in mind the prevention of such acts of aggression; if they did occur, action would be taken by the entire international community at least to deter such acts but, if necessary, force would be used against such aggressors.

Those were the hopes with which the United Nations was founded 45 years ago. It is only now, in 1990, that those hopes have some possibility of realisation because shortly after 1945 the world was plunged into the long era of the Cold War. As a result of the situation that created, it was impossible for the United Nations to operate in the way it was envisaged it would. The most important aspect of the present position of the United Nations is the fact that the United States and the Soviet Union were two of the five member nations of the Security Council which supported this resolution. It is by that agreement that now mercifully has occurred that the world can hope to see the fruits of the work done by the founders of the United Nations.

All the parties in this Parliament and in others around the world have been calling for the United Nations to have some effect. In this case the United Nations has taken action and it is absolutely vital that Australia play its part in responding to that action. The Government has made its decision in responding to that request, which has been outlined in the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) now before the Senate and which we are asked to note. We have not been asked to pass a motion supporting it, as we were on 21 August. It may have been better had the Government done that, as it did before. Nevertheless the Opposition supports the Government's decision and would see its response to this statement to that effect.

The decision taken back in August, which was supported by this Parliament on 21 August, to send a naval task force comprising at that stage two frigates and a supply ship, HMAS Success, was put into effect. In fact as we debated the motion in August the ships were already on their way to the Gulf. They have been deployed there since early September doing the tasks they were assigned to do; namely, taking part in enforcing the United Nations mandatory sanctions. They have performed that role with distinction and dedication. The frigates were scheduled to return to Australia in any event and to be replaced by one other frigate and a guided missile destroyer, HMAS Brisbane. Those ships have now arrived in the Gulf and are in the process of taking over the role of enforcing United Nations sanctions which the frigates performed successfully, as we would have expected them to do, over the past three months. Had it not been for the decision of the United Nations last week, that role would have continued to be performed by the new vessels in that task force.

On behalf of the Opposition, I take this opportunity to express its gratitude for, and acknowledgment of, the work done by members of the Australian Defence Force who have been deployed in that operation. Overwhelmingly they have been the officers and the crews on the ships themselves; however, there has been a small Army unit on HMAS Success and there have been two medical teams of 20 personnel which were also deployed in the Gulf in that capacity.

The Government has now decided to send two further medical teams to join their colleagues and give further assistance in this important work. It is really all of these members of the Australian Defence Force whom we must have in mind and whom we must congratulate and thank for their efforts. We confidently expect those people who have just arrived there to carry out their duty and perform their role with the same distinction as that given by those who are now returning to Australia. However, by the decision of the Government yesterday, which is set out in this statement, that role is now to change quite substantially. The role of enforcing a blockade was largely losing any significance as there were very few Iraqi ships left at sea to be the subject of that deployment. In light of the United Nations resolution last week and its request that, as a member of the United Nations, we take action, the Government has decided to change the nature of that deployment and deploy the new vessels in the task force in the Persian Gulf to exercise and operate with the other allied naval forces in preparation for the extended role which the Government sees as a likely and necessary result of the resolution of the United Nations last week. The ships will be there in their new role to prepare for and obtain the necessary training with the allied force.

Of course, the statement says that, if necessary, they will be available to participate in any action which may be required of that allied force in the Gulf. We all hope that that conflict will not occur and that there will be a peaceful resolution. But if, after 15 January, that does not occur, it is clear that the role of the allied naval forces in the Gulf will be very different indeed from the one which they have been performing to date. Our ships and our men on them will of course have a different and very much more dangerous role to play. But it is one which we have every faith they will perform well, as the traditions of the Australian defence forces indicate that they are capable of performing.

The ships will of course be protected by their own weapons system, by being a part of the allied force which has a very powerful weapons system and also by the communications system operating between all of the ships of that force. So they will have very substantial protection indeed as a result of their being a part of a carrier battle group of the United States. Indeed, that in itself will give them added protection which will be far better than if they were operating on their own.

I would like to refer to a matter which seems to have caused some doubt in the minds of many people, that is, what will be the nature of command of these vessels when they are deployed in this different and, indeed, more hazardous role. The Government has made it very clear that they will still remain under Australian command but that they may, in fact almost certainly will, operate in this allied naval force with ships of the United States, Britain and Canada and that that force will be under United States operational control. This is not a new experience for members of the Australian Defence Force. Indeed, as I have said, these Australian naval vessels have already had experience in exercising with United States and British ships. Of course, it will be a new experience for many of the sailors who, in the next few weeks, will be operating in the new portion of the Persian Gulf region.

At this stage, the ships will be exercising in this way and the Prime Minister's statement says that these steps need to be taken because of the need for the forces to be fully prepared to play this larger role if conflict should break out. It states:
They do not formally commit Australian forces to any action; ADF units will remain at all times under Australian national command.

The Minister may confirm this, but I understand that to mean that a further decision will need to be made by Australia or by the Australian command to commit our forces to any new form of action should conflict arise. If it does, their actual role, from hour to hour and minute to minute, will probably be under the control of the United States commander of that task force. This seems to me to be a sensible, perfectly workable and understandable arrangement, but it does of course mean that the Australian Government will have the ultimate say as to the particular tasks that our forces will perform, where they will perform them and for how long they will perform them. But I have no doubt that they will be performed as is required by the exigencies of any conflict in which they are engaged.
I also have noted another point in the statement. I raised this matter in Question Time today and the Minister gave me an answer. The Prime Minister said:
It is not proposed to make any other contribution to naval, air or ground forces.

It had already been stated that the Government would expand the role of the three ships that are already there and send another two medical teams, so the Prime Minister's statement is made in that context. I trust that that does not mean that the Australian Government is completely ruling out any further contribution that Australia may be called upon or may be able to make. Those questions all need to be debated further, but I hope that the Government is not now under the influence and pressure of its Left and centre Left factions and is totally ruling out that Australia may make some further contribution depending, as I said, upon the exigencies of any conflict. I understood the Minister's answers to me today to be to that effect but perhaps, as he is following me in this debate, he will further elaborate on that particular matter.

I conclude by reiterating how fervently we all hope that this troubling matter will be resolved without war and that a peaceful solution will be found. However, it is clear that the best chance of that occurring is for a firm action and resolution to be made by the members of the United Nations; for Australia to perform the role the Government has assigned to it, with our support; for our own forces to be part of that allied force; and to work with it and perform what is undoubtedly a most important role and one which is worthy of the long and honourable traditions of the Australian Defence Force.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Hill, Senator Boswell, Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Durack for their contributions so far. I will begin my speech today by paying some tribute and reference to the previous role that our ships have played. The earlier decision of Government was to deploy those ships in the Gulf of Oman, which proved to be a critical area when it came to interdicting Iraqi ships. In many cases it was not possible to interdict Iraqi ships in the middle of the Persian Gulf-for obvious reasons, not the least of which were environmental concerns. Those ships that we, in our task force, committed to the Gulf of Oman were very active in the interdiction process. Many ships were interrogated. Several other ships were intercepted and searched to make sure that the naval blockade was effective.

SPEECH.PARA: We also found that the cooperation in the area, in which we were operating with other naval forces, was enormous. The cooperation between those ships proved that international action could work effectively. Just before I visited the Gulf region, many of the people ironically noted that the Argentinean and British ships were exercising together in the Gulf of Oman. At this stage, there were virtually no Iraqi ships trying to run the blockade. Most of the ships have in fact been laid up in other ports. Most of the ships have had their crews flown home. So that particular era in this saga is over. I would like to pay tribute to the efforts of our sailors on the Darwin, the Adelaide and the supply ship for their efforts in this regard. They have performed well. They have performed particularly well in terms of their interoperability with other navies in the area, and I believe they are to be thanked for their efforts. I appreciate Senator Durack's comment in regard to this.

But the situation has changed. We now do have a direct request from the United Nations (UN). The decision of this Government was to authorise our naval task force to operate in the Persian Gulf. It was made very clear to the Chief of the Defence Force (CDF) on his recent visit to Riyadh and Bahrain, in discussions with various military people in that region, that there is a shortage of escort ships in the naval build-up. It is in this particular role that Australia can make its most valuable contribution.

The Australian ships are highly suitable for operation in the Gulf. This is for a number of reasons. Firstly, we fit into the integrated air defence system. The type of missiles and the type of phalanx fighting system that exists on our ships makes it ideal for their presence in this particular part of the Gulf. The second reason why they are particularly suitable is the compatibility of communications. I am not going to go into a lot of detail, but I was very impressed with the real-time intelligence that our ships receive at the same time as every other ship from Canada, Britain and the United States in this area. This is a remarkable achievement of technology. I will not go into the details, but it does reinforce why the United States (US), the Canadians and the British will find our ships most welcome in the region. The third reason for the compatibility between the ships is that we regularly exercise with the US, the British and the Canadians, and many of the other naval assets in the Gulf have not been through that experience. Overall, this interoperability of the ships is absolutely crucial. For its staff it reduces the possibility of blue on blue; that is, taking a hit through friendly fire.

I also want to say at this stage that it is not just the frigate and the destroyer that are playing a vital role here. It is also the supply ship, the Success. The Success has managed, not necessarily through Government regulation and direction, to be one of the most effective supply ships in the Middle East. I will not detail the intricacy of the deals that the captain has done on this particular ship to make sure the whole operation works well in the Gulf other than to say that he is now famous right throughout the Middle East for his methods that have achieved results.

I believe that an early decision in regard to this matter, following the United Nations request, is absolutely crucial, both for planning and exercise purposes. Australia will be involved in the planning process and it is essential that our ships, if they are to operate in the environment of the northern Gulf, should exercise there rather than elsewhere in that region because the air environment and the sea environment are quite different from anywhere else. It is essential that they train and get used to that particular area.

We have the situation, to which Senator Durack asked me to allude, that the ships will remain under Australian national command. We will be amending the rules of engagement and the operational guidelines, and these will be forwarded to the naval task force. Ships will be under the operational control of the overall task force commander-almost certainly to be someone from the United States. If there is any conflict with the rules of engagement and operational guidelines, this will be referred immediately to Australia. I do not expect that to be the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wouldn't the rules of engagement be the same for both the US and RAN ships?

—Almost. We do work along those lines, to answer the honourable senator's question. Again the operational guidelines would almost be the same. It would be in exceptional circumstances that our operational guidelines would not cover most contingencies. I do not mean this to be a harmful example, but if the operational commander suggested we fire on a neutral country, I would expect our commanders to seek our response to that particular request. I will, of course, make available to my colleague Senator Durack, the shadow Minister, for his perusal the rules of engagement and the operational guidelines. Operational control, however, is essential for both the purposes of coordination and the safety of ships.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that one of the big counter attacks on this particular arrangement is that we are simply the lap-dogs of the Americans; that we are placing our ships under US operational control. I say to those critics that if you believe in the safety of the ships, and if you believe in having a decent integrated air defence system, then you go under the coordination of the people best suited to do so. I know that in some quarters-I have not heard it here today but no doubt we will-it is said that these should be under some UN commander. I can tell the Senate now that if some Ruritanian commander is going to be put in charge and he does not understand these systems, we will have to seriously rethink that commitment to that particular region of the Gulf. So it is for the safety of the ships and decent coordination that we must have operational control.

At no stage has the Government tried to mislead the public about the hazardous nature of this deployment. Whilst I am confident that our ships will return home, there is no invincible weapons platform in the world. What we have sought to do as a Government is to provide the necessary equipment to make those ships as invincible as possible.

On the question of a further commitment of medical teams, this derived very much from the CDF's visit to the area where, in discussions with both British and US military people there, they made it clear to him that there were some shortages in this area. The Senate will note that Australia has responded by sending two more teams to serve on one of the hospital ships where two teams currently serve. I also note for the record that New Zealand is making a contribution to medical teams in the Gulf region.

I stress that I believe that our commitment is about right. It is commensurate with our military size and our role in international affairs. I think to do less than we are doing would not do justice to the United Nations. To do a lot more at this stage would place us in a position of being far more heavily involved than other countries that could make an equal or greater contribution. Our actual contribution is tailored to meet two areas of major shortage; that is, in the medical area and in escort ships.

Some people will probably ask, either in this debate or outside: why not other defence assets? I might address those arguments when they actually come to me. Essentially, the Australian defence forces in recent years have been configured for the defence of this country and not as expeditionary forces. To some extent there are not as many alternatives available now as there may have been in the past to use forces in an expeditionary sense. Rather than that being seen as a sense of failure, I take it as a sense of success. It indicates that the way we have configured our defence forces for the defence of this country is the right policy.

Let me turn to the contribution of Senator Powell. It did not take much prescience by me to remark after Senator Powell's speech here in August that, if the United Nations were to sanction the use of force in the Middle East, the Australian Democrats would change their minds. We have seen exactly that happen here today-they have changed their position. I want to give two quotations, but there are numerous quotes on the public record. In a media release on 10 August, Senator Powell stated:
Without UN approval, Australia has no legitimate military role in the Middle East.

I will hold her and the Australian Democrats to that statement. They are now saying that we have a legitimate military role in the Middle East. If not, I want to know why they have changed their position. I refer to Senator Powell's speech on 21 August 1990. She stated:

The Australian Democrats believe that as with the economic sanctions, so in the event of any military intervention the United Nations is the appropriate body to enforce that sort of action and to implement, indeed, that sort of action. We would place on the record the fact that, should that have been the case, then we would see it appropriate for Australia to fulfil its international obligation . . .

This is the same person who, in this chamber 1 1/2 hours ago, called for us to withdraw the ships in the Gulf region. Senator Powell went on to say a few other things. Firstly, she said-and this really did stun me-that the Democrats support the sanctions. I am not sure what she meant by that-whether she meant that in theory each country should apply a sanction to Iraq with no interdiction or anything else, or whether she has finally come on board three months late to support interdiction in the Gulf region. I would like the Democrats to make that clear because at no stage have they ever endorsed the multinational naval force which has enforced the sanctions. We then went on to have described to us that resolution 678 was, in fact, a matter of war expectation and that it was pushed by countries in expectation of going to war. Frankly, that is a ridiculous statement. If anything, resolution 678 has been more likely to crystallise the thinking of the Iraqis and more likely to bring about peace than any other single action so far.

The Democrats tell us that there is no easy solution. That is true, but what is their solution? Their solution is to withdraw the ships and negotiate for peace. If the Democrats had been in government in 1940-41 we would have finally concluded our negotiations when Hitler was holidaying on the Gold Coast. At some stage the Democrats must have some understanding of realpolitik. Good intentions and the Father Christmas philosophy do not apply in the real world. I will come back to that point later.

We also had the furphy introduced here, clutching at straws: what about the report in the Sydney Morning Herald that only 500 people would in fact lose their lives in a two-week war? I have never seen such a report; I believe that it is simply an invention. I do not normally comment on security matters, but when something seems to me to be a total invention by the press, I think I am at least, from a credibility point of view, able to rule it out entirely.

We then have the next introduction, as a distraction, of the nuclear weapons issue. This was introduced as a means of scare tactics in some way to weaken our credibility in the community. Guess what? Guess who was inserted into the debate as a credible witness in this matter? One Brian Toohey, the most embittered journalist. Brian Toohey has nothing on those opposite in terms of hating this Government, and he is introduced as the evidence in this regard.

At least I can say to the Australian Democrats' credit today that they have not introduced two other matters: they have not re-run the conscription furphy that they got on their bike about a couple of weeks ago, and I must say that in terms of a distraction in the community it got a lot of mileage; and they have not argued about neutral, peace-loving New Zealand not wanting to help in this regard. The reason is that the previous Government and the current Government both had plans for some deployment to the Middle East. Once the writs were issued the previous Government could not take any action, but it was planning to do so. To its credit, the current Government of New Zealand has made-it does have very limited military resources-a valuable contribution in this regard.

The most offensive thing that Senator Powell said, and I have to correct her on this, is that it was always intended that our ships have a more offensive role. I do not know how she has become a mind reader, but I can tell honourable senators that that is absolutely untrue. It is incumbent on every government to develop every potential scenario to meet every particular circumstance, but when the original commitment was made there was no intention for an offensive role in my mind, neither could I gather that from the intense conversations I had at the time with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans).

In the end Senator Powell says that we should withdraw our ships and pursue peaceful means. What does that entail? Does that not entail negotiating with someone who will come to the table with good credentials? I will conclude on that basis.
