What are the credentials of the person in the other country with whom we are dealing? First of all, he invades a sovereign state and annexes it. That is a real nice guy to go and negotiate with!

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a treaty with Indonesia.

—I said a sovereign nation. If Senator Powell cannot see the difference between her analogy and that, I feel sorry for her. He incorporates a country. What Senator Powell is now interrupting to say is that because something may have been wrong in the past we never right a wrong; we never intervene.
—I am not saying that.

—The honourable senator is saying that. She has changed her position from August to now. I wonder what the motive is. In terms of the border dispute, the fact is that on three occasions in the last two decades Iraq has recognised the borders of Kuwait, the same as it recognised the border with Iran in 1975, went to war in 1980 and conceded the same boundary in 1990. That is the sort of consistency of negotiation that we are dealing with. The only cost on that switch of border position was one million lives! The other factor involved in this is Saddam Hussein's duplicitous behaviour days before the invasion of Kuwait, assuring Mubarak and everyone else that his intentions were peaceful. This is the person Senator Powell wants to go and negotiate with without any sort of strength behind her. He would just laugh her off like he laughed ex-Senator Haines and the rest of them off.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter I want to mention in regard to Iraq is that it does have a disproportionate military presence, much more than it would ever need for self-defence. It has an arsenal of ships, planes and missiles; it has one million men at arms compared with Australia's 100,000 servicemen, including reserves; for a country of the same population, it has 10 times our military personnel and it has only half our gross domestic product; and it has an arsenal of chemical warfare that is staggering. No-one is sure when it will realise its nuclear arms ambitions. I would not want to take a risk on that on Senator Powell's assessment that it will be in a few years time.

When one looks at Iraq's internal organisation, one sees that it is a military dictatorship where opposition is never tolerated. Dissidents are routinely killed. Dissidents in the army and dissidents in the Government are never given a superannuation scheme-they are given a bullet in the back of the head. We know that this is a country capable of genocide. We know that this is a country capable of gassing its own people, as we saw with the treatment of the Kurds in Iraq. Nothing draws this to our attention more explicitly than the taking of civilian hostages and the sorts of scenes we have seen coming in and out of Baghdad in the last three months.

I believe that Senator Evans laid out to this Senate that what we are seeing now is a possibility of a new world order; a world order, post-Cold War, where the United Nations original intention can be revitalised and revived. What we may be seeing now is a pretty tough investment but we may be seeing a far more peaceful world for it.

In conclusion, I wish those who are representing Australia on the Success, the Sydney and the Brisbane well. I wish very much that they will not be involved in any conflict and that they can return to this country and be reunited with their families. But I know, from having talked to the crews of the three existing ships there, that they are all willing to do their duty to this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleagues Senators Hill, Durack and Boswell have already addressed themselves today to the wider issues of our commitment to the United Nations force in the Gulf and to the need for free nations to stand shoulder to shoulder together to face the tyrant. Sadly, that seems to be missed by our Australian Democrat colleagues. It is very sad today to hear them talk as they are.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleagues have already made it clear that the Opposition supports the Government's statement today on the Gulf commitment. My purpose today, as shadow Minister for defence personnel and veterans' affairs, is somewhat different-that is, to talk about the impact of the Government's statement on our defence personnel. While the Government's statement says that the Government has committed ships, in actual fact it has committed our men and women-Army, Navy, reserve and regular-to serve in the national interest and in the international interest for the sake of peace. The statement says:

. . . the decisions we are taking are onerous indeed. Should it come to conflict, Australians may be involved in combat for the first time in nearly twenty years . . . This is a heavy responsibility, but the Government will not shirk the exercise of that responsibility.
I hope that the Government really means what it says because it has a very poor track record when it comes to responsibility towards returned servicemen.

While the Opposition supports the actions of the Government in sending and keeping our ships in the Gulf, we do have some serious personnel concerns which we have raised and which the Government, to date, has failed to answer. The Government, when speaking of the Defence Force, means an integrated force, that is, both regulars and reservists. That is the Government's own policy. Therefore, one would assume that any reserve allowances or conditions of service would have been worked out at the same time as those of the regulars.
In an interview on the radio program PM on 14 August, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) said:
We've decided that the servicemen who are going to take part in the Gulf force, will be entitled to the highest level of service benefits which it is possible to give.

That is simply not true because the Government, it would appear, has not even thought about the benefits to reservists. Minister Bilney, speaking in response to an Opposition member on the Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement (Service Personnel) Bill in the House of Representatives on 14 November, said that it was his advice that the situation of reservists called up for service in the Gulf will be the same as that of regular servicemen in the Gulf. But then he said that that is only if they are fulltime reservists.

This raises two interesting questions. The medical reservists have not been officially called out in terms of the call-out legislation. Does this mean that because they are volunteers and have not been legally called out, they will be treated the way in which the Minister has indicated? Secondly, what is the definition of full time duty for this situation in the Gulf? In normal circumstances, a period of one year's full time duty is required for reservists to be eligible for regular conditions of service such as Defence Force retirement and death benefits compensation. The majority of reservists in the Gulf will not have one year's full time duty and, therefore, will not be eligible for such compensation.

To the best of my knowledge, the only supplement available to medical officers to compensate them while they are rendering reserve service during a period of their absence from their civilian practices is the locum tenens allowance. Defence public relations told me only today, `We may be looking at that'. I would certainly hope so because it has not been updated since 31 March 1983 and it provides the princely sum of $22 a day to a medical officer in order to help put a locum into his or her practice.

When one reads the qualifying service one sees that that allowance is only payable for attendance at a reserve camp or for continuous training at a military school, course, bivouac, naval ship or establishment during the year provided that the periods claimed do not exceed a total of 10 days in that year. So it does not even have a provision for reservists who are operating in a conflict or war situation.

In the Committee of the Whole on 13 November I questioned the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) about medical reservists who stood to lose up to $10,000 a month by way of fixed costs and overheads that they have already committed on their practices. I asked whether the Government intended to reimburse these reservists for those costs that they will have to meet, whether or not they are in their practices. The Minister did not have a satisfactory answer and none has been announced since. I find this lack of preparedness totally unacceptable and I challenge the Government to act on this issue immediately to set in place some clear guidelines.

The new Defence Force (Home Loans Assistance) Bill 1990, which will soon be before the Senate, waives the six-year initial service period for those regular servicemen serving in the Gulf. Yet, this does not apply to reservists unless they have had one year's period of full time duty. As I said before, this will not apply to reservists in the Gulf. Further, this legislation contains reversionary benefits allowing the surviving spouse of a regular serviceman who is killed still to be eligible for the loan calculated on his prospective service had he not been killed. This, it would appear, does not flow on to reservists in the same situation. Why are they so different in what is supposed to be an integrated force?

This is compounded further by the fact that currently only female surviving spouses are eligible for benefits. If it is a woman who is killed while serving, her husband gets nothing. We have five women medics serving in the Gulf on the American hospital ships. What will happen if one of them is killed or disabled?

Another issue relates to the Sex Discrimination Act which indicates that women are not to serve in combat zones. The Persian Gulf, being determined a combat zone, will have Australian women serving in it. What legislation will or will not cover their being there? This is yet another question the Government does not seem to have an answer for.

Life assurance companies are indicating that they are reluctant to extend their cover to those who go to the Gulf. Has the Government addressed itself to this question? If so, what can be done about it? These are serious concerns. The fact remains that the Government has said nothing and done nothing about these issues despite calls from the Opposition and letters from reservists who are directly concerned.

On 9 August the Opposition issued a press release wishing God speed to naval personnel and welcomed the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that the Government had faith that the equipment and training of the Australian naval personnel being sent to the Gulf would enable them to deal with whatever confronted them. In that same press release, I called on the Government, as a matter of urgency, to determine the allowances for the force and asked for clarification of the eligibility status for entitlements under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. Problems have arisen in the past and I was very concerned that they be cleared up at the outset.

The current crisis in the Gulf has highlighted to Australians the fact that war is never as far away as we might like to believe. Australian men and women who are currently serving in the Gulf will be feeling this more than anyone else. In serving their country in a crisis situation in the interests of all Australians, it is essential that they be secure in the knowledge that when they return to our shores they will receive full and proper recognition of their service.

If any personnel are injured, they must be provided with full compensation and medical care. If-and it is to be hoped that such a tragedy does not occur-any service personnel are killed, their dependants must be properly compensated; that is, proper recognition of the debt all Australians owe to such servicemen must be accorded to their dependants.

The question which confronts this Government and which must be answered immediately is: what does it intend to do to ensure that current serving personnel on their return are not subject to the same anomalies and irregularities that veterans from previous wars have found themselves having to face? A question Gulf personnel will be asking themselves is, `If I should require help of any kind, how will I be looked after when I return home?'.

Veterans around this country from previous conflicts are worried that this Government, over the last seven years, has been continually whittling away their entitlements and benefits. In addition, there remain significant anomalies in our repatriation system. The current Gulf crisis makes it more important than ever that these concerns be addressed and resolved.

We have received assurances from the Government that if any Gulf personnel are seriously injured they will be fully compensated under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. If, for example, a Defence Force member were totally and permanently incapacitated, he or she would be eligible to receive the TPI pension and associated benefits.

Obviously, such a devastating disability could mean years of special care being required of the spouse. If the member is a man, then subsequent to his death, under the Veterans' Entitlements Act, his wife will be automatically entitled to a war widow's pension. This is only fitting. However, as I have already said, in the Gulf there are currently five women serving as part of a medical support team. Under the Veterans' Entitlements Act as it stands, spouses of deceased female veterans who receive special disability rate pensions are not eligible for war widowers' pensions. These present legislative provisions relating to war widows' pensions obviously are derived from principles which were generally accepted at the time of World War I and subsequent operations, but this is 1990, and such sex discrimination is now unacceptable.
In a letter to a constituent dated 30 August this year, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Humphreys, said:

. . . the question of extending the equivalent of war widows' pensions to husbands of female veterans where death was related to war service was considered at the time of drafting the VEA. The Government considered that, in view of the climate of financial restraint, no new categories of pension were to be created.
He finished his letter with:
I am sorry that I do not have better news for you.
Is this the Minister's message to the women risking their lives in the Gulf?

I now move to the hospital care which personnel returning from the Gulf can expect to receive should they require it. In the past they could have been confident of high quality health care being delivered through their own repatriation system. At the very moment that Australia is committing further personnel to the Gulf the Government is seeking to have repatriation general hospitals integrated with the State health systems and their long queues and waiting lists. The Government has said that the veteran population is an ageing one and the numbers are dwindling rapidly. This is spurious because demand on hospital services by veterans will not peak until 1995-96. But returned personnel from the Gulf or indeed any other veteran should not be faced with the prospect of joining long State queues and receiving less than top quality health care, given the service they have rendered for their country. With the threat of war in the Gulf, it is now more important than ever that the Government recognise this.

Gulf personnel would also be concerned at the very recent tabling by the Government of the third edition of the guide to the assessment of rates of veterans' pensions, which will restrict the ability of wounded veterans to have both medical impairment and the effects of this impairment on their lifestyle taken into account in the determination of a disability pension.
The Prime Minister, in his statement today, said:
. . . we cannot deny that the decisions we are taking are onerous indeed. Should it come to conflict, Australians may be involved in combat for the first time in nearly 20 years.

Twenty years ago Australia was committing troops to Vietnam in the interests of all Australians. On their return soldiers faced hostility and a lack of acceptance from their own people. Today Vietnam veterans are still fighting for recognition and compensation for the effects of agent orange. Twenty years later they are also seeking recognition for exposure to asbestos while serving on logistical support vessels such as the HMAS Sydney. We must ensure that returned service members from the Gulf are not fighting for their entitlements 20 years from now.

The concerns that I have highlighted here are just some of the more important personnel issues facing the Government as a result of the statement made today. Personnel returning from the Gulf must be reassured that they will be accorded recognition and access to entitlements commensurate with the sacrifices they have made in serving their country. We in the Opposition salute these men and women who are serving our national interest. We also salute their families back home and recognise the worry and the strain that these months ahead will bring. We also welcome the news from the Minister for Defence that our New Zealand neighbours are sending a medical team. The size of its contribution is not what is important. The recognition that the nations of the world are standing shoulder to shoulder for the sake of world peace-that is what is important.

The Opposition agrees with the Government's decision to commit ships to the most recent development of the Gulf conflict. But, as I have said before, we have committed Australian men and women and it is most important that that commitment carry with it the responsibility of looking after the personnel that have been sent, whether they be regular or reserve, male or female. In 1946 Prime Minister Chifley said:
Upon this national Parliament rests the responsibility of seeing that the right thing shall be done for those who served this nation in a time of war.

I hope, with all my heart, that this commitment that we support today will not end up as a commitment to war. If it is, this generation of Australians will not accept a lesser responsibility from this Parliament towards today's service men and women.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, what we have seen today in the chamber and in the other place is the Government and the Opposition joined together in this debate. This is another example of the `Laborials' at work. There is little or no difference between them except that the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) would like Australian ground forces to go to the Gulf as well. Thankfully, that has been resisted. No wonder the majority of Australians are deserting the major parties. Their structures and decisions are increasingly irrelevant in the community. They are desperately serving up tired old rhetoric, which is increasingly unacceptable. Ask ordinary Australians now whether they want Australia to go to war in the Gulf and mostly they will say no.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with Senator Newman, however, that, if this awful statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that we are debating here today results in Australians being engaged in combat in the Gulf, our service men and women there should be looked after. We should not be creating another generation of veterans who are not cared for by a careless government which is only too willing to commit the services of our young men and women to fighting foreign nations' wars.

Senator Ray finished his speech with the amazing gobbledegook of a new world order. There is nothing new about the use of military force against an aggressor; there is nothing new about the threat to use the military. In fact, it is the same old world disorder that we are seeing played out on the world stage at the moment. There is nothing new or creative about it whatsoever. This is not the way for sane nations and sane people to solve disputes in these days of chemical and nuclear weapons, which have such devastating force and such devastating impact. It is absolutely outmoded to talk about war as a way of resolving this crisis and to say that war may bring peace.

It is quite distressing to hear the negative arguments being put forward in support of the Prime Minister's motion and the illogical attempts by the Government and the Opposition to justify a war effort. Senator Robert Ray said that the multinational force is short of operational escort ships, that our ships fit into an air defence system, that we have compatibility with communications, that that is very impressive, that Australia regularly exercises with the United States, et al or, in other words, how jolly important we are and how jolly useful we are, how ANZUS has prepared us well for a war role, and how the United States plans to ensure that our warships have interoperability with theirs and will serve the US led force in the Gulf very well indeed.

Senator Ray also said that the rules of engagement and operational guidelines will be amended but that it is likely that the overall task force commander will almost certainly be from the US. If we want some expertise, that is probably the best place to find it. To ensure the safety of our personnel there, that is probably the sensible thing to do. I will finish, as Senator Ray intimated somebody might, with the suggestion that this should be under the control of the United Nations (UN) military command.

So far in the debate today I have not yet heard, either in the Prime Minister's statement or in the statements of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), any suggestion that United Nations military command committee is operational or that there is any intention to make it operational. It may well choose, if it becomes operational, to have a United States commander at its head. But it has not even gone through the process, not that I would sanction it even if it did. We have no justification for the Prime Minister deciding to upgrade the Australian contribution. No good reasons are given in his speech. I need to go through it and look at the more ridiculous things that the Prime Minister said in his speech, such as:
In passing Resolution 678, the Security Council is not seeking war.

We could say that, in not seeking war, we are just making it possible, that we are making it internationally palatable and that we are providing a framework for war, a legitimacy for killing. That is what resolution 678 is all about, and it is wrong. I do not care whether the United Nations Security Council agreed to it with two negative votes and one abstention. It is wrong.
On page 3 of the speech, the Prime Minister said:
Sanctions can be very powerful instruments of persuasion-as they have been in South Africa . . .

Right, Prime Minister, let the sanctions work. It took 12 years to find that the sanctions worked in South Africa. In the meantime, the black South African people have suffered and continue to suffer. The sanctions finally worked there without a military blockade to back them up. Why could not time have been allowed in the Gulf for the sanctions to work? The international community did support economic sanctions with humanitarian reservations against Iraq because nobody supports-well, very few support-the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. I certainly do not represent anybody who supports it. That sanctions path has not been allowed time to work. The Prime Minister said:
. . . the Resolution not only authorises all necessary means;-
to use force-
it explicitly requests that member states provide support.

We are already doing that with the economic sanctions blockade. The United States military staff has not requested any further support. No request or any mention of any request has come from the United Nations military command-because it has not met-for member nations of the United Nations to upgrade their support or to be ready to fight under a United States command. It is still very unclear. Even if the United Nations did that, there would not be any sane person on the face of the earth who would want the type of war that might be unleashed in the Middle East-United Nations permission granted, or not. The Prime Minister continued:
The passage of Resolution 678 clearly requires us to consider whether we should extend the operational role of our task force . . .

I disagree. It does not. No way. In the light of the direct Australian interests which are engaged in the crisis, the only direct Australian interests engaged in the crisis are the lives of the Australian hostages, which this Government seems to be quite willing to put on the line. At a time when it was very possible that the hostages might have been released, the Prime Minister decides that it is time to upgrade the Australian engagement, the Australian forces, by putting our naval forces into the Gulf area. That could well jeopardise any chances that the Australian hostages have of getting out. That is absolutely deplorable. There is a total contradiction on page 7 of the Prime Minister's statement:
Our ships will remain at all times under Australian national command.
Yet, in the next paragraph:
Our ships will operate principally with troops of the US, Britain and Canada, under US operational control.

For goodness sake, which is it? Finally, there is the admission I have been waiting for since 10 August when the Prime Minister first indicated that the Australian ships would be there. I knew that that admission would be made. I have been asking questions about this matter and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Minister for Defence have repeatedly said, `Oh, no, the ships will not be under US command'. Finally, they have had to admit that that is exactly the case.
The slide towards war has been very obvious to those who do not think that war is an option in this situation. What a cheek the Prime Minister had to say, on page 9 of his statement:
The Australian Government and people have no ill-will to the people of Iraq, and wish them no harm.

How dare he say that we wish the people of Iraq no harm when we are prepared to engage in a military force which will unleash all types of terrible weapons and terrible suffering on the ordinary people of Iraq, who are not responsible for what their leader has done? How dare the Prime Minister make such a statement? It is cant and hypocrisy of the highest order.

The Prime Minister is like a little bully trying to elbow his way into the big league. Is he determined to slavishly support his mate in the White House to the extent of spilling Australian blood? Is this another test of nationhood like the slaughter at Gallipoli? That is how it is appearing. Mr Hawke knows full well that, to remain Prime Minister, he has to be in the good books of the President of the United States, whoever happens to be in the White House. He has demonstrated that consistently since day one of his Prime Ministership.

I feel great sympathy for the families of Australian servicemen and women and fervently hope that all of those people, rushed to the Gulf at the Prime Minister's request, will return home safely. It is a sad scenario when we have old men, politicians, playing with the lives of young men and women. If the Prime Minister, the President of the US and others had to sit in the Saudi desert for months on end, the massive forces would not be there now. They blithely send young men and women off to do their dirty work.

I refer to the United Nations, its role and the sanctions. I have already said that the sanctions should have been given time to work. The latest resolution is very distressing. I take issue with the Foreign Minister when he says that some people, who have opposed the slide towards war, have said, `It would be all right if the United Nations were in charge'. We have not said that at all. The United Nations can make mistakes. I think resolution 678 is a grave mistake.

I am disgusted at the hypocrisy displayed by the United States and Australia over the United Nations resolution 678 which authorises the use of force. The UN has lost a great deal of credibility because of the manipulation by the United States which wields considerable powers of influence over that body, leading to the view of it as a toothless, international watchdog. Of recent years, the UN had been reclaiming its international reputation as a peace broker. Unfortunately, this resolution damns that, but I hope not totally.

Australia has had a hand in supporting the United States at various times in history when it has vetoed resolutions on issues such as disarmament and peace, international law, terrorism, the Middle East and South Africa. They all add up to a record that is less than impressive. The Soviets and others have also used the power of veto regularly throughout the history of the United Nations. This is what is different now: they are not using the power of veto.

The Prime Minister piously quotes the United Nations resolution today in his speech and refers to the Korean war as a precedent in justifying Australia playing a competent role in the Gulf crisis. There are those who argue, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics among them, that the UN resolution to send forces to Korea in 1950 was illegal. They did not recognise it then and they do not recognise it now. United Nations analysts now say that this resolution is also illegal.

Ironically, the United Nations was suspiciously silent during the US historic forays into Indo-China, which certainly did not represent the liberation of people or the creation of democratic statehood. I will mention just a few cases of the US history of vetoes relating to the Middle East, going back just two years, to refresh the minds of my colleagues.

In early 1988 the US vetoed a series of resolutions that condemned Israeli attacks on Lebanon, proposed a UN role in peace negotiations, and called on Israel to abide by the Geneva conventions. In October, the General Assembly condemned Israel for killing and wounding defenceless Palestinians by a vote of 103 to two. Guess which countries were the two who did not support that? Of course, they were the United States and Israel. In June 1989, the United States again vetoed a resolution deploring Israel's violation of Palestinian human rights. The US has vetoed 23 of 66 Security Council resolutions on these matters.

To mention a few other important Middle East resolutions, the US was alone with Israel in opposing the General Assembly resolution calling for an end to hostilities when Israel invaded Lebanon in June 1982. The United States vetoed the Security Council resolutions condemning Israel for ignoring the United Nations demand for withdrawal of its forces and calling for simultaneous withdrawal of Israeli and Palestinian armed forces from Beirut at a time when Israel was saturation bombing Beirut.

More recently, the Security Council resolution on 23 December 1989 condemning the invasion of Panama by the United States was, of course, vetoed by the United States with British and French assistance, and that was the one which I may need to remind honourable senators about in which our Prime Minister intervened. The Australian Government delegation was going to support the condemnation of that aggression against Panama and Bob Hawke rang the Australian delegation and said: `No, we will vote with the Americans on that one, thanks very much'. That probably followed another phone call from George Bush.

The United States performance in the United Nations has been less than impressive historically and could be noted for the blatant hypocrisy of its bleatings about maintaining democracy and sovereignty with regard to invasions of lesser powers. For example, the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan was bitterly censured, but the United Nations never took on the US after its forays into Indo-china. The US uses the United Nations when it suits and treats it with contempt at other times, to the extent of not paying its dues during the Reagan Administration, which nearly crippled the organisation.

Australia should be more cautious about associating itself with UN resolutions gained through manipulation by the US considering its less than democratic performance. It is a sad day for the United Nations when it allows itself to be bullied, to be used in this disgraceful headlong rush towards war. It is as though the United Nations has set a date for World War III to begin if Iraq does not do what it is told.

Of course, we then have the words of the Foreign Minister that the response to the naked aggression has been carefully modulated-an escalation of response towards aggression-and he keeps on using this ridiculous phrase about naked aggression. Is clothed or slightly less obvious aggression all right and more acceptable to the Australian Government? It would appear so, if we consider the Government's vote in the United Nations about the US invasion of Panama. It had some `excuse', some `justification'. That was clothed aggression, was it?

The United Nations Security Council is wrong in this decision, and I am quite happy to say that. The United Nations will be constantly at war if it is seen as appropriate to allow the use of force in any resource disputes. There will be many of them in the future. Are we going to resort to the use of force every time? We will be constantly a world at war. That is why I cannot accept any notion that this is the heralding of a new international order. Finally, the United States is beginning to negotiate with Iraq. I suppose that is the only good thing that has happened in the last couple of days. This should have been happening since August; that is when it should have begun. Where is the United Nations mediating team in all of this? That is its role, to get in there and to mediate, to ensure that we do not slide into a war, instead of passing resolutions which legitimise war.

I think the role of elected representatives in this country has to be clarified. This decision, which is the most important and far-reaching decision made in the life of any sitting parliamentary member, should be acknowledged for what it is: it is putting Australia onto a war footing. I do not think it is good enough for the Australian Labor Party to hide behind its factions and its caucus debate, which I gather this morning was pretty much a set piece because the decisions had all been made in the various factions yesterday.

It is not good enough for the people of Australia who voted for the Labor Party to have individual members hiding behind the Prime Minister and not coming out and saying what they think about it. Every one of them should be individually accountable. This is Australia on a war footing. I appeal to members of the Labor Party to do that for their own personal integrity. It is that which is on the line. The Labor Party's integrity has been shot to pieces long since, but the individual integrity of many members of the Labor Party may be redeemed if individual members have the guts-and I acknowledge that it would take a lot of guts-to say how they feel about Australia being put on a war footing by the party which got Australia out of the Vietnam morass. The biggest irony is that this is the same party which could be taking us into the most devastating conflict that the world has ever known.

What we do not hear about is that war means death; it means death to ordinary citizens, probably hundreds of thousands of them. It is not going to be over in a matter of a couple of weeks. It is not going to be an easy victory for either side. There have been reports that one of the United States' latest shipments to the Gulf was 100,000 body bags and 10,000 units of blood plasma with a shelf life of 60 days. This was at the end of November, so their blood plasma units will be unuseable by the end of January. I think we have to take these things into account.

Various people in the United States, senators included, have been asking for a confirmation of that from the Pentagon and of course they get the neither confirm nor deny treatment. They are not being told. I think it is pretty serious. There is also a dispute about the disposal of bodies. From a good source, I understand that the Saudis would not initially allow either burial in their country or export of bodies in body bags, that they would permit only cremation of non-Muslim casualties.

This, of course, creates a big problem for the United States military. The disposal of bodies was being negotiated between the US and Saudi Arabia and a resolution was expected by the end of the year. Without this resolution, a war could not proceed. The American public would not stand for it; their boys not only dead, but also burnt in the deserts of Saudi Arabia. This is the kind of information that we really need to think about. It is dead bodies that we need to think about in a war. We should not be allowing this to be countenanced any further.

The human cost would be terrible; the environmental cost would be huge. We should remember the lessons of Vietnam on both counts, and the costs of war in the Gulf are being ignored. Vietnam is still a mess environmentally, to say nothing of the social and psychological status of the people there who were abominably misused in that conflict. Their environment is unable to produce food for the people to live because it was so devastated by the chemical weapons that were used by the United States. Yet all we keep hearing all the time is about the Butcher of Baghdad who used chemical weapons on his own people. I admit that and I am not condoning it for one moment, but we must remember that it is not only the Iraqis who have used chemical weapons, the Americans have too and the Americans are the only ones who have used nuclear weapons as well, and they have 400 of those ready to go in the Gulf.

There are many actions around the world; ordinary people are speaking out against the possibility of war in the Middle East-thank goodness. From the Netherlands and Spain there are ships heading for the Gulf region. From Italy there is an Italian team presently in Iraq. From the United Kingdom the Gulf peace team has gone there and they are setting up peace camps on either side of the conflict zone. Whether that will help at all when the politicians make their decisions, I do not know, but I would hope that ordinary citizens who do not want war, placing themselves literally on the line, would have some impact on the decision making of the leaders, if it comes to the showdown.

I think we have to acknowledge that there is also a lot of domestic opposition in the United States. The President's first gung ho approach, the first military response, was very well received by the American people, but not so as time wears on. His support is decreasing rapidly. That is one reason why there is a 15 January deadline being imposed. It is too expensive for the Americans to keep people there indefinitely, and we do not know whether that is their intention, to have a United States permanent force there to monitor the oil wells and to have control of that region. I do not know the answer to that, but certainly United States domestic opposition to the war option is growing. George Bush knows that. If it comes to a debate in Congress, he may not have the permission of Congress to declare war. Of course, that will not stop him. They did not declare war in the Vietnam situation either.

The Vietnam Veterans Association in the United States, which is a strong lobby, has made a very strong plea to the President. It has said, `Don't create another generation of veterans when the last generation has not been dealt with'. In the United States more Vietnam veterans have committed suicide since the end of that war than casualties in the war. A total of 60,000 of them have committed suicide because they were in such a mess after that war-an unpopular war. Those veterans were not well treated when they got back home; many of them were on drugs by then. They were social, psychological and physical wrecks, and 60,000 of them have committed suicide, which is more than were killed in combat in Vietnam. If that is not a lesson for the world's leaders when they think about war, I do not know what is. But it is a very strong plea for an alternative path to be taken-a very strong plea for a negotiated settlement.

On Sunday, 2 December in many of the countries whose military forces are engaged in the blockade at the moment people gathered at war memorials to express their concern about the slide towards war. That happened in Perth where 100 people participated in a silent vigil at the Kings Park war memorial: `We do not want to see more dead people as a result of politicians' decisions'. It happened here in Canberra as well and probably in other parts of Australia which I have not heard about yet. The plea came from people at the Aldermaston peace camp in the United Kingdom and from the Greenham Common women's camp. They called on people in the countries that are participating in the military blockade not to allow their governments to go ahead with the United Nations legitimisation of the killing in the Gulf. They said, `Not in my name'. This was the plea of ordinary people, saying, `No, I do not support this war. I don't think that it should go ahead'. I quote from a poem by Justina Williams which was distributed at the vigil in Kings Park, Perth, Not in my Name:
Not in my name,
my woman's name,
not one drop of blood
be shed for oil
that makes some billionaires
and sets the Middle East aflame.
Not in my name,
my name and yours
should frightful weapons of our age,
nerve gas and plague, the nuclear bomb
sweep life from earth-
this fragile earth of ours.
Not in my name,
my woman's name,
another Vietnam, Korea, the same
skulduggery
that made invasion just.
Dear God, if god there be,
not in my name.
But in my name,
in every woman's name,
send home great armies
of the black and dispossessed,
warships and frigates turn around.
Peace in my name!

With thanks to Justina Williams. The opposition in the United States grows from the churches. The Catholic bishops conference in the United States has come out strongly and publicly against this. What about the church hierarchy in Australia? What are those people to say? I have not heard a word from them. Let them speak out, too. But the ordinary Christian people are speaking out very strongly, and I quote from a letter by Peter Akerman to the Archbishop of the Anglican fraternity:

I don't believe the Christian criteria for a `just war' can be met either, mainly because the conflict is not winnable, and because of the huge slaughter of innocents that would ensue once the conflict escalates.

I accept that the church as an institution, particularly the hierarchy, has to compromise its position to some extent with the established power of the privileged, if it is to survive in the temporal world, but this was not Jesus's way to victory as you are well aware.

I believe we have a very clear message to offer in this crisis and the only message that will matter in the end, which must be loudly proclaimed. We should support a position of containment, rather than violence for as long as it takes to achieve a fair and negotiated settlement in the Gulf.

TALK.START.PARA: —But, Jo, you are a pacifist.

—Yes, of course. That is not contradictory at all. I am just saying that this is an ordinary Christian's point of view. There was a very strong and powerful action in Perth yesterday morning from Christians also. They dug graves on the causeway on the lead-in to Perth in peak hour traffic. They had white military crosses laid out and put into the ground. Two big graves were dug and the police did not quite know what to do about it. They stood there and watched while this was going on. One bus driver leant out of his window and said, `It shouldn't be you blokes digging the graves; it should be Bob Hawke digging them'. I concur with that sentiment. But the human cost, the human casualties, are never mentioned by the Government or the Opposition. I want to mention them loud and clear.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, a war will not solve the problem in the Middle East. Anybody who has looked at the history of the Middle East should understand that. A jihad-holy war-will rage, and not only in the Middle East. There could be terrorist attacks globally if this thing gets going. War is legalised, government-backed killing on a massive scale. The idea of it is anathema to a civilised society. We degrade ourselves totally, utterly and absolutely by killing, even in response to violence involved in the unacceptable aggression committed by Iraq on 2 August. Violence begets violence. We do the same to innocent Iraqis and Kuwaitis. We continue to commit heinous crimes if we allow that war to go ahead. It will not be in my name. We would be showing that we are no better than the Iraqi Government aggressors. Ours is a calculated and callous response, with the most damning consequences. Two wrongs do not make a right-they never have, and they never will.

All the invading forces in the Middle East should be put on the agenda. Let us get everyone to a peace conference, as that is the beginning of the way to solve this crisis. That is what Saddam Hussein has been calling for for several months, and he has not been heard. Now, finally, the United States is willing to talk to the man and I think that is high time. We could cut out the killing phase and get straight on to the peace talks, because after a war there have to be peace talks anyway. After a war it is victor and vanquished discussing who will get which bit. Why not cut out the slaughter in the middle and get straight on to the peace phase? Otherwise another monster will be created. Wiping out Saddam Hussein will not stabilise the Middle East.

I make a plea for restraint, not further confrontation. It will not solve the problem. Australia should have no part in the killing. How much more difficult it will be to withdraw later if and when the fighting starts. We are meant to be glad that the Prime Minister is not committing ground troops or substantially increasing Australian personnel there at the moment, but I think that is a very small mercy. This is the slide into war. It is how we began in Vietnam with just a few advisers, with the view, `Oh, no, we will not get involved in the fighting'. If the fighting goes on now, there is nothing surer than that Australia will be involved, and there will be Australian casualties.

This is a tragic decision of the Prime Minister's to send Australian ships into the war zone, ready for fighting. It comes hard on the heels of Senator Evans's deplorable statements about nuclear weapons: `No, we do not advocate their use; no we don't support their use--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take no joy or comfort in standing here this afternoon in the Australian Parliament speaking to the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) about events in the Middle East. In fact, I wish that I was not here undertaking this task. But I am an elected representative of the people in my State, and that brings with it some responsibility. It brings with it a responsibility for me to represent the electors or the people and their dependants in my home State and with it, in turn, I have to be a representative of this nation. I do not take a narrow view of my role on this earth at the moment. I try to confine my thoughts to what is happening in my home State of Western Australia, but I think what happens outside the borders of my State and of this nation has an impact upon me and my family, my constituents and, indeed, all humankind.

SPEECH.PARA: We are speaking this afternoon on a very serious statement, despite some of the comments and criticism that have been levelled at it. It relates to a very serious issue which has the potential to lead to a major conflict, a major armed struggle. That is not something I would welcome. Indeed, I will do whatever I possibly can to avoid it. I have had some small role as a member of parliament in trying to bring about a peaceful resolution to a potential conflict. It is only a minor role, but nonetheless it is a role I have taken together with my colleagues on all sides of this Parliament. It is a role that we have got to build on.

Unfortunately, what we have done to date collectively has not borne fruit. We still have naked aggression taking place in the Middle East. We have seen one nation move in and take over another nation. As politicians and members of Parliament, I do not think any of us can stand idly by and allow that to happen or continue. We cannot be silent and acquiesce in that happening. This is irrespective of who initiates the action or which country the action is initiated against.

We have enormous responsibilities. This Parliament has debated this conflict on many occasions. But, as I said earlier, we have not yet reached a peaceful resolution to the conflict. Our Government, in some cases with the support of other political parties and in some cases with perhaps criticism of some of its actions, has played a role in it. It has ensured that Australia has honoured its international obligations to bring about world peace and a direct resolution to this conflict.

The Government has run into some very great difficulties, none the least of which is the leader of the aggressor nation, Saddam Hussein. Over the four months since the occupation started, he has proved by his actions that he is not going to pack up his bags and move out of Kuwait. To ensure that he is not going to be pushed out, he has collected innocent human beings who have done no harm to him or to his fellow nationals, and he has held them as hostages.

What brings it right home to us, as members of the Australian Parliament, is that some of these people are actually Australian nationals with family, dependants and loved ones here in Australia. And yet, they are being held by Hussein and his army to further his aim of becoming a major power in the Middle East. Indeed, his actions of a few years ago proved that he has aspirations in that regard. After realising that he could not win the useless war that was waged against Iran and in which there were over half a million casualties, he decided to settle and turn his attentions in another direction. I now quote from the Prime Minister's statement:

Australia has been deeply concerned by the consequences for the Middle East as a whole if Iraq's aggression was allowed to stand. Who could doubt that having swallowed Kuwait, the stronger Iraq would not then turn on its other neighbours? Who will explain how Iraq could then be prevented from establishing a hegemony over the entire region; a hegemony backed not only by chemical weapons, but sooner or later by nuclear weapons as well?

As Australians, whether we are in the Parliament or not, we cannot ignore the record of this particular man and the fact that his Government has obviously given him the authorisation to do what he has done. I do not think we can turn our backs and not do anything.

Australia has done a number of things. One of the areas in which Australia as a nation has acted is the United Nations Security Council. The United Nations has been oft times criticised for not being the effective organisation that perhaps it could have been. Indeed, perhaps senators on all sides of the chamber could cite particular areas of criticism. However, the United Nations exists and we have sought to use it.

The United Nations acted very quickly in this conflict. On 2 August, the United Nations Security Council condemned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and demanded that Baghdad withdraw its forces. The vote for resolution 660 was 14 for, nil against with one country not participating. This was then followed by a further resolution on 6 August; a further resolution on 9 August; yet another one on 18 August; others on 26 August, 13 September and 16 September; and so on. Resolution 678, which is not a resolution of war or a declaration of war, states:

(1) Demands that Iraq comply fully with resolution 660 (1990) and all subsequent relevant resolutions and decides, while maintaining all its decisions, to allow Iraq one final opportunity, as a pause of goodwill, to do so.

That resolution was carried on Friday of last week Australian time and already it has shown some results. An offer of negotiation was issued and, thankfully, that offer has already been taken up. We know that the Foreign Minister from Iraq will next week visit the United States for negotiations. We also know that the United States Secretary of State, James Baker, will visit Iraq in the week preceding Christmas-it might even be Christmas week. If resolution 678 is going to show such immediate results, I think the United Nations is now fulfilling the role for which it was established.

We have a very important deadline of 15 January next year, which is all but six short weeks away. A lot of work has got to be done. The greatest regret-and there are a number of regrets that we should not be doing this at all-is that if there were not an aggressor in the Middle East we would not need to be involved. Another big regret is that it has taken the threat of force, war or aggression to bring one very belligerent party-a man who is willing to hold innocent human beings as hostages to facilitate his quest for immortality, power, wealth or whatever his particular aims are-to the negotiation table. It is something that I do not enjoy. Indeed, I do not believe that any of the nations who were involved in the Security Council will take great joy from this success.

The real success will be when Iraq withdraws from Kuwait and when other matters that are in dispute in that region are settled through a peaceful process. We all know, because we are all adult and grown up, that we have to act sometimes by cajoling, sometimes by the use of force and sometimes even by threatening to use force in order to achieve objectives. It is a pity that it has reached this point. I am certainly hopeful that our efforts will be successful.

In the interim, we wish the Australian personnel who are playing their role by serving on those Australian ships well. We also wish their worried families in Australia well. We certainly hope for an immediate peaceful solution.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in supporting my colleagues on this side of the chamber in the National Party and the Liberal Party in their support for the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the Gulf crisis, which was tabled this afternoon. I am personally very conscious of the importance of that statement. I am also very conscious of the grave implications and consequences that can flow from it. I do not shrink from them. The nations of the world are faced with as blatant an act of gross lawlessness as we have seen in recent times, and through the United Nations they are taking the correct approach to resolve that problem. The Prime Minister's statement is upholding the charter of the United Nations, which is the rule of international law. Beyond that it is support for the United Nations and those great and noble ideals which led to the United Nations being founded in 1945.

SPEECH.PARA: Like the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), at the outset I would like to praise the crews of the Australian ships that have been on service in the Gulf for the past l7 or so weeks. The crews of HMAS Darwin, HMAS Adelaide and HMAS Success, and the medical teams, have served in the exemplary manner that we have come to expect from Australian service men and women. They are there because at 2 o'clock on the morning of 2 August Iraq chose to invade, without any provocation at all, its peaceful neighbour, Kuwait.

At 2 o'clock three armoured divisions of the Republican Guards Force crossed into Kuwait and some hours later four Republican Guards Infantry divisions followed up. The Iraqi Air Force bombed and rocketed Kuwaiti airfields; helicopter gunships attacked Kuwait City and landed at least a brigade of Republican Guards special forces with light armour in an assault against the palace and main government buildings. The forces employed exceeded 100,000 soldiers with 1,250 tanks plus armoured personnel carriers and artillery. Their only opposition was the Kuwaiti Army which was numerically around one-tenth of the Iraqi force. The Kuwaiti forces were not deployed defensively at the time of the attack.

It is estimated now that the Iraqi forces in Kuwait exceed 450,000 men, with between 2,000 and 3,000 tanks. For the past four months they have been assiduously preparing defensive fortifications in strategic areas in Kuwait-pouring concrete, building tank traps and digging ditches they can fill with oil to set alight in the event of an attack.

Without provocation, one country invaded another and seized its entire territory and incorporated it into its own state. It expelled the legitimate government ruling that country and set up its own puppet regime. Since then it has systematically plundered all the assets of that state. It has harassed and quite probably murdered many hundreds of its citizens. In addition, it has resorted to the most barbaric of actions by holding as hostage any national of a third country who was present in either Iraq or Kuwait at the time the invasion took place. It has held those hostages as a bargaining chip, as terrorists do, to try to justify and maintain its position as the usurper of the seized territories. Above all, as I said before, it is an act of unprovoked aggression. There are no shades of grey about this. Very often disputes arise in history where both parties contribute to them, but in this case the issues are black and white. It was an act of unprovoked assault on a peaceful neighbour.

It is relevant to consider a bit of history here because Iraq claims that Kuwait is part of it. The border between Kuwait and Iraq was drawn up in 1923. All of that part of the world was part of the Ottoman Empire and was ruled for hundreds of years by the Turks. The British and the French were given administration of that area by the League of Nations nearly 70 years ago. Britain's involvement with Kuwait goes back centuries before that; it goes back to the eighteenth century. Of course, the al-Sabah family, whose descendants were ruling Kuwait when it was invaded, have been the legitimate rulers of that territory since the time Australia was settled over 200 years ago.

Iraq itself was created by British fiat in 1932 as an independent state. Kuwait remained a British protectorate until 1961 when the British withdrew. Iraq then moved opportunistically to seize Kuwait; it was deterred because the British very promptly moved back in military strength. The British stayed there only so long as it took for the Arab League to come in with its own military forces and Iraq was dissuaded from proceeding with its claims against Kuwait at the time. In 1963 Iraq formally recognised the Kuwaiti border.

Among the many statements being made by Saddam Hussein is the claim that somehow or other Kuwait is an illegal state because its borders were drawn up by a colonial power-that is, Britain-some years ago. That same argument applies to every state in the region. If it is a valid argument against Kuwait, it means that the borders of Iraq are also illegal and illegitimate, of Saudi Arabia and all the Trucial States in the area. However, that is not the point at law, which is beyond dispute and which is that Kuwait is a sovereign state, Iraq is a sovereign state, and Saudi Arabia and all the other countries, however their borders might have been derived, are legal entities and are entitled to enjoy their own sovereignty.

In 1980 war broke out between Iraq and Iran. It was a particularly brutal and bloody war. No wars are pleasant but that one took us back to the horrors of earlier centuries in the way the carnage mounted and because of the fixed defences, the attacks of one army against another, the poverty of medical attention and the general lack of hygiene and resources to look after the injured. It is estimated that nearly one million citizens and soldiers of Iraq and Iran died in those terrible eight years.

Throughout that war Kuwait made loans to Iraq as its neighbour. In 1988 Iraq sued for peace with Iran and later took up talks with Kuwait about repayment of the loans. It did not want to repay the billions of dollars that it owed Kuwait and it also wanted to increase the price of crude oil so that its financial position could be improved. Kuwait, being a much bigger oil producer, had a very much bigger share of the world market than Iraq.

Those talks, as the Minister for Defence accurately pointed out, were under way when the invasion took place. Prior to the invasion on 2 August, Iraq had given explicit and categorical assurances that it had no intention of invading Kuwait. A matter of weeks before it invaded its neighbouring territory Iraq had given these undertakings to Egypt and Syria.

It is against this background that the present actions of the Government and the United Nations have to be considered. Two things happened after the invasion: the first was that the United Nations responded with very great rapidity. For four months in 1983, I had the privilege to serve in the United Nations as one of the parliamentary delegates to the General Assembly. There might be difficulties in embarking on the normal course of diplomatic activities where one nation talks to another but, where multilateral negotiations are involved-something like 168 nations were involved in the United Nations when I was there and there would be more now-it is extraordinarily difficult to move anything along quickly because of the differing points of view of all the nations that are represented. It takes time, and it is very hard to get agreement on anything. But to its credit, the United Nations responded on the same day that the invasion took place. It passed its first resolution condemning Iraq for invading Kuwait and called for its withdrawal from that territory and the restitution of the Kuwaiti Government. A series of resolutions passed through the United Nations leading up to the one that was passed at the end of last week, which initiated the statement from the Prime Minister.

Those resolutions from the United Nations Security Council reiterated the position that it took initially, and firmed it up. It provided for the sanctions to be applied and for a blockade to be put on supplies to and from Iraq. It provided for the provision of humanitarian aid-food supplies in the event of starvation and medical supplies-but with the proviso that the United Nations was to decide whether or not it was a humanitarian case. Finally, we reached the stage last week where resolution 678 was passed which gave the Iraqis an ultimatum to withdraw from the territory and to free the hostages by 15 January or face the consequences of military intervention.

The two senators who have spoken so far in this long debate and who have been opposed to the Government's action seem to hold the somewhat misguided view that the United Nations resolution somehow lacks the authority of law. That simply is not so. It is perfectly within the charter of the United Nations and perfectly within the legal system in every sense. It is quite a proper exercise of the United Nation's power for it to have taken this action.

Parallel to the United Nations actions, the United States responded to an appeal from Saudi Arabia and from Kuwait for military support. The Americans, again perfectly legally, operated on their own, initially to guarantee the security of Saudi Arabia in that area and, as well, have complied completely with the legalities of the United Nations determinations. I would suggest to those people who do not understand it that they should get a copy of the United Nations Charter and look at chapter 7, which I have with me. It deals with action with respect to threats to the peace, breaches of the peace and acts of aggression. That chapter starts at article 39. Article 51 reads:

Nothing in the present charter shall impair the inherent right of individual or collective self-defence if an armed attack occurs against a Member of the United Nations, until the Security Council has taken measures necessary to maintain international peace and security. Measures taken by Members in the exercise of this right of self-defence shall be immediately reported to the Security Council and shall not in any way affect the authority and responsibility of the Security Council under the present Charter to take at any time such action as it deems necessary in order to maintain or restore international peace and security.

Article 51 covers the initial actions with respect to the Gulf emergency and, later, as the Prime Minister points out so lucidly in his statement, the Charter provides that military force shall be used in the appropriate circumstances, and the present circumstances are clearly appropriate.

We have to have a rule of law. Every nation on earth has internal laws for its own operations. It also has a police force to enforce them because laws without the means of enforcement and punishment are held in contempt. Just as every nation has an internal set of laws for its own affairs, we ought to have a set of international laws governing the affairs of the nations of the world. I do not want to live in a world where the strength of the military machine in one country dominates my country. I do not believe that that is the goal that citizens want extended into the future. That has happened through the centuries-through the millennia-and we now have the opportunity, with the ending of the Cold War, for the United Nations to uphold the rule of international law with respect to sovereignty, without the threat of the veto, and to see that the relationships and disputes between nations of the world are resolved peaceably. That is what this motion is all about-the peaceful resolution of conflict, being able to put a system in place which will avoid a resort to armed force in future disputes. That is why it is so important that Australia support this motion and get right behind it in every way that it can.

The actions taken by the present Government have been impeccably correct all the way along the line. The Government was correct initially in responding rapidly and meeting the need at the time, which was to dispatch ships to enforce sanctions on Iraq, and it is correct in what it does today in recognising that the interdiction phase for those ships has now passed, because there is very little sea traffic going into or out of Iraq. It commits the Royal Australian Navy to a far more active role. In the words of Paul Jones, the father of the United States Navy, they are going in harm's way when they go as part of a carrier battle group into the Persian Gulf.

We are very conscious of the dangers that those ships and their crews will face there. They will face real danger from air attack and a real danger from mine warfare, but I am quite confident that they will discharge their duties with all of the skill and dedication that the Australian services have shown in previous generations. The arrangements that the Government has outlined for command and control also seem to be perfectly appropriate. Australia will maintain a national overall control of the ships and define their general operational tasks, while the specific operational control will rest with the American battle group that they are with. It really cannot operate in any other way.

I was very pleased to hear the Minister respond to my interjection during his speech and say that the rules of engagement for Australian ships would be almost the same as the rules of engagement for the American ships because, if one is operating in a battle group, it is absolutely essential that there are not mistaken views as to what is and what is not the situation with respect to self-defence or opening fire.

That brings me to the United Nations' strategy. The United Nations, quite simply, is seeking to force Iraq to withdraw its forces by demonstrating both overwhelming military power and a clear and unwavering intention to use it if the deadline is not met. By doing that, it will avoid the use of force and having to put its powers which it has resolved to use into effect.

We can see some results of that already. Saddam Hussein has been one of the most intransigent of leaders, not prepared to talk to anyone despite what Senator Vallentine hallucinates about. Yet since the resolution passed through the United Nations last week there has been agreement that the Iraqi Foreign Minister will go and talk to the American President and that the American Secretary of State will go to Iraq. I hope that leads somewhere. I would hope that leads to further and more productive talks by 15 January.

I recognise that the policy the United Nations has embarked upon is highly dangerous. But we now have to see it through. We are adults, and as adults we know that life cannot be lived without risk or danger. Certainly risk and danger are very much part of the course we are following at the present time. Of course, what we try to do is minimise, by all means that are open to us, the dangers that are inherent in it. None of us can foresee the outcome of the path we have embarked on. We all hope that hostilities will not take place, but if hostilities do take place there is certain to be a price to be paid. It will be a very high price, because it will be in human lives, and they cannot be measured. But our strategy is to avoid war, the use of armed force. We do that by being absolutely determined in the path that we are going to follow and to be there with as much military force as we can at this time.

My criticism of the Government action is that since the strategy of the whole exercise is to put as much show of force as possible into the situation to compel Iraq to withdraw, the Government should find more resources to commit to the Australian component of that force. The sad part, of course, is that the Minister conceded that we do not have much more to give. For a nation of 17 million people, which spends about $8 billion a year on defence, that is a tragic confession for the Minister to have made here this afternoon. He tried to gild the lily by saying that he took it as a compliment that we could not send more because the forces now were designed for Australia's self-defence and, therefore, they were not applicable in other theatres.

TALK.START.PARA: —We need to spend more, not less.

—As Senator Newman has said, we certainly need to spend more because the reason the forces cannot be committed is that the defence vote has been too low for too long; for so long that we have designed scenarios to fit what the Government has been prepared to pay for defence. We now have an army that we cannot use in war-although it is the largest of the three services-except for limited incursions, light scales. We do not have one army unit trained which we could put into the field, effectively, in a conventional battle. It is a fatal tragedy to be training defence forces for roles rather than training them professionally as an army, a navy and an air force with the range of skills that they must have.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Navy we have only four ships that can be safely dispatched to that area. Two more could be brought up if money was spent on them. But there are only six ships at best-four in reality at present. It is incredible. I have already dealt with the Army. There are simply no suitably trained and equipped troops to take part in land operations if they take place in Kuwait.

It is only in the air that we can make a contribution. It is there that I think we ought to be sending some of our own forces, because the one place where Iraq is vulnerable is in the air. We can make a very real contribution there. The naval forces are important, supporting the carrier battle group in a defensive role, but it is the air wing of the battle group which is the critical part of the naval wing. With No. 1 Squadron, with its pavetack equipped F111 aircraft, we could make a very tangible contribution to the American strike capacity in the air in that region. In my judgment there is a very sound case to be argued for the commitment of at least one Royal Australian Air Force squadron there to support the already large air strike capability that is in the region.

One of my other concerns is that if it does go to the use of armed force to resolve this issue, there must be no political interference at all in the military operation. Critics of what the Government is doing talk about another Vietnam. That is absolute nonsense. But if we get politicians trying to tell generals what to do in the field, we could end up with the same sort of situation that we had in Vietnam, where certain targets, for political reasons, were declared off limits. I have a fear that politicians may say that since the object of the exercise is to get Iraq out of Kuwait, operations will have to be confined to land operations in Kuwait itself. Nothing could be more bloody, more protracted or more disastrous than an assault on the well prepared, well defended Iraqi positions that have now been four months in preparation in Kuwait. The principal objective must be to gain air superiority in the short term and then to go around, isolate and let any forces of the Iraqis in Kuwait that have not surrendered wither on the vine. Let me deal with the case that has been raised in this chamber against the Government's action. First of all, we have had the far Left which has been trying to extract promises from the Government -fortunately they have not come from the Government-that there will be a cap on the Australian commitment. The Government, quite correctly, has resisted this because no-one knows what is going to eventuate. I have to say on this point that the Left has been morally incoherent, because if its members can justify supporting the present operations, they can justify seeing it right through.

As for the Australian Democrats and Senator Vallentine, I think that Senator Ray dealt with them quite adequately. All I could say about the plea from the honourable senator who spoke for the Democrats, who said that we ought to wait for four or five years, is that justice deferred really is justice denied, and justice needs to be seen to be done in this circumstance. It really is a variation of the old theme that he who feeds the crocodile thinks that he will never be eaten, but history shows that that is not true.

One of the points I want to deal with is one that I have met when interviewed by the media. They ask the question, `How many Australian lives is Kuwait worth?'. That is putting the question around the wrong way because the cost is in relation to the value. The value that we are seeking here is the upholding of an international rule of law, respect for the sovereignty of nations, and if we can make the United Nations Charter work the way the founders of it anticipated 45 years ago, then whatever the price we pay now is well worth paying.

When I was at the United Nations, in 1983, I was privileged to hear an address by General Carlos P. Romulo, who at the time was the only surviving signatory to the group which signed the original United Nations Charter in 1945. He spoke of those ideals that led them to form the United Nations in those years. I believe that he would approve enthusiastically of what the United Nations is now doing.

The final point I want to comment on is the rather specious argument of Senator Vallentine about Christians. Some while ago, in September, I was in the United Kingdom Parliament for the emergency debate on the Gulf crisis and the Archbishop of Canterbury had this to say:

The scriptures speak of our responsibility for seeking justice and the well-being of creation in the world as it exists. The hard fact is that the use of force is caused as much by human virtues-our sense of justice; our belief in the difference between right and wrong; our readiness for self-sacrifice on behalf of others-as it is by any of our failures.
There is a nobility in what the Government is doing here for the human race and that is why my colleagues support the motion to take note of the Prime Minister's statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the interests of time, the Australian Democrats were to have only one speaker on the motion to take note of the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Unfortunately, having listened to various speakers and having been invited by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) to respond on various issues which he raised, I would like to make just a few points. I will not take much of the Senate's time.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, it is obvious from most of the early contributions that few of those speakers actually listened to Senator Powell's outline of the Democrats' position on this statement before condemning the Democrats on that stand. One could be forgiven for concluding that most of the gratuitous and paternalistic statements about the Democrats' attitude were written before Senator Powell made her statement, because they bear little or no relation to what she said. I recommend to honourable senators that they read the statement in Hansard if they want to know what the Democrats' stand is.

Senator Gareth Evans claimed that the Democrats' support for a United Nations (UN) role in the Middle East crisis was inconsistent with our stance against war. There is no doubt that United Nations Security Council resolution 678 authorises the possible use of military force after 15 January next year, but there is also no doubt that the resolution sets no timetable for military action. To wait a further 12 months or even six months for sanctions to work would be completely consistent with the UN's wishes on this matter.

The Democrats do support a role for the UN. However, the UN's resolutions on sensitive issues such as sanctions enforcement and the use of force have been open to a range of interpretations to suit national preferences. There is nothing in resolution 678 which compels Australia to follow the United States interpretation.

Senator Ray criticised the Democrats' unwillingness to support the enforcement of sanctions as evidence that we support sanctions in theory but not in practice. This is based on the entirely false assumption that, in the absence of naval enforcement, the sanctions would have failed completely. Do we need to remind Senator Ray yet again that the sanctions began to take effect before the naval force assembled in the Gulf? Do we need to point out that the Prime Minister himself conceded that South Africa did respond to sanctions? There was no naval blockade there.

In the early stages of the conflict, diplomatic pressure was successful in persuading countries such as Yemen from breaking the sanctions. There may have been some extra leakage in the absence of enforcement, but there is no evidence that this would have been significant. But if it had been, then we have no doubt that the Security Council would have been capable of initiating and coordinating a small naval force to enforce sanctions, and we would have supported such a move.
