The fact that this did not happen suggests that there was simply no need. I should reiterate that the Democrats support the continuation of nuclear, chemical and military sanctions against Iraq after it withdraws from Kuwait to make doubly sure that there is no repetition of this act of aggression.

The last point I would like to make is that Senator Ray was particularly offensive in claiming that the Democrats would have supported a policy of appeasement towards Hitler. Our support for the most comprehensive sanctions in history in no way equates with appeasement. It is blindingly obvious that Iraq is on the road to economic ruin. No such straitjacket was applied to Hitler's Germany, which in any case had a far greater domestic industrial base on which to support its military expansionism.

The issue is not whether we should appease Iraq; it is whether we should kill tens of thousands of foreigners, Kuwaitis, Iraqis and Western service men and women rather than wait for sanctions to work while exacting a much lower toll. The issue is whether the prospects for a long term Middle East peace would be enhanced by a more patient and a more peaceful approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few remarks tonight on the Government statement that was tabled in the Senate. First of all, I clearly indicate my support for the statement. I have been involved in many of the discussions in the Australian Labor Party and in the Government over this issue since Iraq invaded Kuwait in early August, and I have been supportive of the measures the Government has taken at each of those stages.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that Australia responded correctly initially in deploying a naval force in the Gulf of Oman, and I think that was a very successful deployment. It indicated that we, as a middle sized power, were willing to indicate our support for the United Nations (UN) resolutions that existed then and that we, as part of the Western democracies, would oppose the naked aggression of one country against another. I certainly support this so-called second deployment, this upgraded or advanced deployment where naval ships will now be placed inside the Persian Gulf. Quite clearly, if there are hostilities the naval ships would be at much greater risk than if they had stayed in the Gulf of Oman, but I think that risk is commensurate with the role that Australia has played in this issue and with our international role as a middle sized power not just in our region but in general world affairs.

Many people have commented that we should be playing a similar role to that which we have been playing in Cambodia in promoting a peace agreement and putting forward a proposal to get peace in that unfortunate country. I do not find what Australia is doing in the Gulf in any way contradictory to what it is doing in Cambodia. The situation in both places is different, but in both places we are supporting a settlement that guarantees the security of a sovereign country. In Cambodia it is Cambodia, and in the Gulf it is Kuwait. I believe that the decisions taken by the Australian Government are entirely appropriate for the role that we have taken for ourselves and which we should be playing as a middle sized power. We should not be shrinking violets in stating that position and we should not overstate our influence in world affairs, but I think we have the measure about right.

I certainly believe that there is no need for Australia to increase the size of its deployment in the present circumstances. There would have to be a substantial and dramatic change in circumstances for Australia to contemplate any further extension of its present forces in the Gulf. When one compares Australia's response with those of most similar countries in the world, ours is about right and I think other countries should take our lead. If middle sized countries like Australia and the world responded as we have across the board, I think there would be an even stronger presence in the Gulf against the aggression of the Iraqis.

My main comments tonight concern the role of the UN. I know that in the initial stages, in the first month of this crisis, there was much comment to the effect that the response from the West was totally inspired by the United States Administration and that this would lead us into an incremental arrangement whereby step by step we would fall into a war similar to the way in which the Americans involved themselves, Australia and other countries in the West in the war in Vietnam. I do not believe that the analogy in any way is correct, for one very simple reason: at no stage in the whole history of the sorry Vietnam war did the UN ever carry a resolution supporting the involvement of the Americans, the Australians, the New Zealanders, the Koreans, and so on. It never declared its support for such an involvement.

In the Gulf crisis over the last 3 1/2 months we have had a number of UN resolutions-I think there are now about 10-which are all absolutely clear-cut in their total opposition to the aggression of Saddam Hussein and the Iraqi forces in invading Kuwait. They have been unequivocal in their denunciation of the invasion, calling for the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait. Last week we had a UN resolution-only the second time in its history, as I understand it-enabling member states to take all necessary action against Iraq if by 15 January it has not begun to withdraw its troops from Kuwait.

Many people say that this is a declaration of war and that we should not be involved in war. I do not think that anybody in his right mind, in the pure sense, would ever support war. But occasionally the hard and tough decisions have to be made. It is better to bite the bullet early rather than let it pass by and find that we are in a much more difficult situation. The 1930s show, again and again, that if the Western powers had not kowtowed but rather had stood up to Hitler when he marched into the Rhineland, Austria and Czechoslovakia and especially in the Munich crisis of 1938, the Second World War probably would not have occurred in the way that it did.

I know some people say when I use that analogy that that is what the Americans used to justify their involvement in Vietnam. I believe it was a totally false analogy that the Americans used to justify that involvement. The situation in Vietnam was a civil war which had undercurrents of nationalism and anti-colonialism. It was not an aggression from an outside country against another; it was an internal matter which, in my view, the Americans totally misread and, unfortunately, convinced our country-our government of the day-to be involved. I do believe the analogy of the 1930s and the way the West did not stand up to Adolf Hitler is, in a number of ways, applicable to the Gulf situation where one country, without hesitation, marched in, invaded, occupied and annexed another country to its own territory.

I think in the longer term the great hope of this crisis is that for the first time since the United Nations was founded it is acting as the founders hoped it would act-as a force to stop aggression by recalcitrant countries. I note that the statement of the Government quotes on two occasions the remarks of Dr Evatt, the Foreign Minister of the then Chifley Labor Government and also the first President of the General Assembly of the United Nations. On page 6, the Government's statement says:
Dr Evatt, who as Australia's Foreign Minister played a leading role in establishing the UN, said in the House-
that is, the House of Representatives-

in 1945 that if economic or diplomatic sanctions ``are deemed inappropriate to the situation or prove ineffective, the Security Council may take any military action necessary to suppress the aggressor.''
The statement further says:

Dr Evatt recognised not only that aggression must be resisted, wherever it occurs, and by armed force if need be. He also recognised that all nations must be prepared to contribute to that task. As he said in 1945:

``It must be made crystal clear that the nations seeking representation in the world organisation must be prepared to contribute their share of physical force to restrain the action of proved aggressors.''

There is no doubt that aggression has been proved against Iraq. It has been proved against its leader, Saddam Hussein. There can be no argument-and I do not even find comments from the Australian Democrats or anybody else, disputing the fact-that overt aggression has occurred. The dispute seems to be from some people in Australia about the response we should make.

Dr Evatt, who helped draft the charter of the United Nations, makes it quite clear that there is a military response appropriate to aggression, and that is what the United Nations Security Council carried last week in its resolution. It called on the member countries, in conjunction and consultation with the Government of Kuwait, to take all necessary action to overcome that aggression. It was made quite clear that, if need be, that includes military force.

No-one wants war. Certainly I, no more than anybody else, do not want to see war and the consequent casualties that would occur. I have no doubt that if war breaks out in the Gulf the casualties will not be light. They will be significant and they will be horrible. With hundreds of thousands of soldiers on either side and the array of modern weapons that both sides have, one can only anticipate that the number of casualties will be severe. Unfortunately, there is a risk that some of those casualties could be-and I say could be-Australians who are on the Royal Australian Navy ships in that part of the Gulf.

The real point is that at long last the United Nations is acting as we, Dr Evatt and most middle powers wanted it to act when it was established in 1945-as a basis of protection for one country against the aggression of another. Now that the Cold War is at an end after some 45 years, in some senses we should cheer the fact that the United Nations Security Council was able to make a decision to, if necessary, invoke the military option without a veto being used by one of the P5 in the Security Council. It has happened only once before. This was when the Korean War broke out and the Soviet Union at that stage was boycotting the Security Council meetings. If it had been in attendance it would have vetoed the resolution to commit forces to defend South Korea.

This time all the P5 were present. One country abstained and the other four clearly voted in favour of this final option. This means that the UN is again becoming the relevant force we all hoped it would be in world affairs. It will be a great example to any tin-pot dictator in the future who chooses to try to use aggression against another country that the UN is capable of taking action. That will be the great deterrent-a great deterrent based on the combined actions of the nations of the world. I believe we should welcome that development even though the circumstances which have brought it about are very sad and do, as I say, risk the loss of life in any subsequent military action.

Of course, it may be that Saddam Hussein realises that, with the world arrayed against him through the United Nations Security Council and its resolution, the only option he has got is to withdraw his troops and negotiate a settlement. A peace settlement will only be achieved because the UN carried the resolution it did last Thursday which was, if necessary, to invoke the military option. One cannot imagine Saddam Hussein responding to the pleas-the pitiful pleas in some cases-of people asking him to be nice. The man does not have that record. He is probably the only world leader who has used poison gas against his own people-the Kurd minority. I believe that the circumstances that have arisen in the UN are to be welcomed because, in the long term, they give us much greater hope that the world will be able to manage its affairs more effectively.

I know that some people take a very cynical view about the United States of America's use of the UN. I suppose people have a right to be cynical about the way superpowers over the years have used, misused, abused or ignored the United Nations. But America has committed itself to using the UN forum. I believe that it will be very difficult for the United States, in the future, to invoke its own veto in the Security Council on such issues as the Middle East. On a number of occasions during the Reagan years it invoked its veto on resolutions which condemned or criticised Israeli action in the Middle East and the occupied territories.

I believe that, now, the United States will find it much more difficult to use the veto in that or any other area as would the other superpowers-the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France-because it would bring upon their heads world condemnation that they were acting without consultation with the other members of the United Nations. In fact, we may see out of this dispute in the Gulf the end of the veto which was used as an instrument of Cold War tactics and that, again, should be welcomed by all countries, particularly countries such as Australia.

We should also take note of the fact that the Soviet Union and the United States, the two world superpowers-though one of them may be a little sicker than the other economically at the moment-both agreed, as difficult as it was, to vote for this United Nations resolution. Again, that sets a new tenor, a new atmosphere, in the operation of the UN and in world affairs.

In my remarks I have tried to explain how Australia's role has been correct and moderate and in line with our role in world affairs. We have not been afraid to stake our position early in our decisions. I think they have been correct. The subsequent events since the invasion of Kuwait in early August have proved that the Australian Government's judgment has been overwhelmingly correct on these issues.

In the long run, the events in the Gulf crisis can prove overwhelmingly that the United Nations is, and will be in the foreseeable future, the appropriate forum not only to negotiate peace but also to enforce peace and to tell those would-be tin-pot dictators that aggression in the world is no longer tolerated. Also, it will set the stance of the UN; it will give it the credibility in a number of other areas to take decisions and influence actions in other countries, such as Burma and those that I and other honourable senators have an interest in.

The UN, as a result of its new credibility, will be able to make decisions to influence the military regime of Burma to realise that the days of its operations are numbered and that it must support the return to democracy in that country. All members of this Parliament would welcome that step forward. We are all committed to the development of democracy in all parts of the world. Though the situation in the Gulf is now severe and difficult and there is a real risk that there will be substantial casualties if war takes place, in the long run, the concerted action of all the world's nations, through the United Nations, will make the world a better and safer place, just as Dr Evatt envisaged when in 1945 he made those remarks referred to in the Government's statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 August Iraq invaded Kuwait. Four months later Iraq did not look like moving from Kuwait, that is, until a few days ago, when the United Nations adopted resolution 678. Last Thursday the Security Council met the five permanent members of the Council and 10 others and, by a large majority, with one abstention-only two opposed-a representative of world opinion adopted the phrase `to use all necessary means' to achieve the goals that the United Nations set out in the first week after that aggressor, Saddam Hussein, took the Iraqi forces into Kuwait.

SPEECH.PARA: Accordingly, the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is timely. It sets out Australia's response to the United Nations resolution. I happily support the Prime Minister's statement. I believe it contains the right set of decisions for Australia at this time. I commend my colleagues Senators Hill, Durack, Newman and MacGibbon and the others from the Opposition who have spoken. Genuinely, I commend the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, and indeed Senator McKiernan and Senator Schacht, who have spoken for the Government.

It is correct, when that small group of Independent or Democrat senators make the reflection here, that the Government and the Opposition have the same considered view about what Australia should do in concert with the world to resist the aggressor, Saddam Hussein, and to see the best pathway, even if it promises not to be painless, to achieve a solution to the situation in the Gulf.

The Opposition supports resolution 678 of the United Nations. The Opposition supports the Prime Minister's statement. The Opposition supports the announced modified deployment of our ships. This is bipartisan and it is correct to observe that it has been bipartisan from the beginning. It is a set of conclusions which have been arrived at independently. Indeed, the Opposition called for the Government's response in early August. That was eventually announced. Similarly, in thinking through the need for resolution 678 over the recent month, we have readily come to an independent conclusion that happens to be that which has been announced by the Government today.

By the expression of considered support in this chamber and in the House of Representatives for the Prime Minister's statement, this Parliament, by an overwhelming majority, is expressing to three particular groups a message of clear support for what is intended by us and our allies towards a solution in the Gulf. First, we are engaging in dialogue with the Australian people. We are listening to the Australian people. The highest priority in our considerations is what we conscientiously believe to be in the best interests of Australia and the Australian people.

Secondly, we are expressing these views in dialogue with those Australians who represent us all in serving their country in the Gulf-in the ships, in the medical teams to be deployed and those individual Australian servicemen who at the moment happen to be serving other allied military units that have been deployed by other countries to the Gulf region. We are highly conscious of each Australian involved in those three groups. We want, by our strong statements in the Parliament today, to give them a clear message of support. We appreciate what they are doing for Australia and for the world. Thirdly, we are clearly confirming to our allies, and indeed internationally, where we stand in regard to resolution 678; we support it.

There are four matters in the Prime Minister's statement to which I shall refer. The first concerns the naval operations arrangements that have been announced on page 7 of the statement. It is appropriate that our task force of ships be integrated into the Persian Gulf and that it becomes part of the allied defence operation that will provide a sound air defence in the Persian Gulf. It is very clear that were our ships to remain further out they would be isolated, they would not serve with the same military capability and they would be considerably less safe than in the integrated deployment announced today. Similarly, we note that the Australian Defence Force will also now participate in allied military planning. This is appropriate. The details of that one sentence in the statement have not been given, as is appropriate, but it will be a matter that we, on the Opposition as well as on the Government side, will watch most carefully.

I note, too, that the command for deployed Australian forces remains entirely with Australia, which is a sound tradition that should never be transgressed. An integrated operational command involves the deployed forces of the United States, Canada, Britain, Australia and other allied nations. As is clear in the statement, in all circumstances Australia will retain priority over the assignment of our ships. There is no debate about that. Had those statements been lacking, there would have been debate.

In relation to operational arrangements, it is also clear from the statement that it is not proposed to make any other contribution of naval, air or ground forces. It is very clear from the Government's decision that there will not be additional personnel or forces deployed to this region without a completely new round of consultations and a completely new basis for a decision in the future, should that ever be necessary. In the same way as the Opposition has been consulted, and in the same way as the Parliament has now been given a clear statement, one would expect similar consultation before there is need to consider any further contribution, and let us hope that that is not necessary.

The second matter I wish to refer to relates to the hostages. It is an appalling evil that Saddam Hussein has not only kidnapped and held totally against their will persons of foreign nations, who happened to be in Kuwait or Iraq at the time of his invasion on 2 August, but also, against all humanity, against all the codes of international law, and against even the conduct of any military operation, is using such hostages as human shields to try to deter any possible attack upon military assets in Iraq or Kuwait, and to use the hostages as bargaining tools to try to gain some military or political advantage for Iraq.
This Parliament is appalled at this evil. I am sure that members of parliament from all sides-certainly we in the Opposition-uphold this part of the Prime Minister's statement:
We have all heard in the last twenty-four hours of suggestions-including from Iraq's Ambassador in Australia-that Australian hostages may soon be released.
Of course, we know that about 30 are detained in this evil way. The statement continued:
We hope that is true. We say to Iraq, as we have said continually over recent months-let them all go.

We have not, in the consideration of this statement, in any way overlooked the human needs of the Australian hostages in Kuwait and Iraq. We will not stand with those former Australian members of Parliament who have, I believe, let us down in terms of their own association with this Parliament by luxuriating in self-publicity at everyone else's expense. I fear that that action, at everyone else's expense, may even be at the expense of some of the hostages. As we all do, I still call for Iraq to stop the evil and let the hostages go free without any negotiation other than that plain moral request. I have been sickened at the parading by individual former members of this Parliament in a way which has been to their own self-publicity and at everyone else's expense, even at the expense of the bona fides of the Australian Government, the Opposition, or the people of Australia. Who do they think they are?

My third point relates to those parts of the statement that clearly address the need to restrain aggression. Parallels were made today and have been made at other times with the events of the 1930s which, with hindsight, were the preamble to the Second World War. Our own children ask -I ask, as one who was born during the Second World War-why did the allied nations that eventually came together to fight the evil of Nazism in Germany not act sooner to resist the aggression of Hitler and the Nazi army in the Ruhr, in Austria or in Czechoslovakia before the line was drawn at Poland?

TALK.START.PARA: —Because they disarmed.

—Yes, they had disarmed, they hoped, in some flowery notion for peace. There was a height of pacifism in Europe more than at any time before or since, there was the painful memory of the First World War, and some felt there was some consolation in drifting away from any military response. The 1930s remind me of the speeches made by three senators today. The first was Senator Powell. I heard her speech. I did not make any notes about what the Australian Democrats might say until I heard her speech and the notes I have are entirely of what she said. Similarly, I heard Senator Vallentine and, very briefly, Senator Bourne.

SPEECH.PARA: Not to place labels on it, but for accuracy of analysis, I have tried to place the arguments that those honourable senators have put, and one or two other arguments that have not been put here but have been put in the community, especially in the United States, into three categories: the pacifists, the isolationists and what I will call-making up a word-the `painlessists'. There are genuine pacifists. I thought that Senator Vallentine, who is a genuine pacifist, was ranting and raving without credibility in her speech today. I have listened to Senator Vallentine on a number of occasions when she has spoken about matters of peace and war, and she has made much more sense because she has used evidence and logic. Today, she tried to win her point, which was entirely isolated, just by shouting louder. Those fellow travellers of pacifism, such as the flower power advocates who want to negotiate in a rose garden or the like, are deluding themselves.

I am not a pacifist. It must be conceded that the majority of honourable senators in this chamber are not pacifists. We do concede that there is, for the benefit of the nation and for the benefit of the people, the need to use force to safeguard the peace. That is why we allow our police within our own domestic community to be armed, why we have gaols, why we take security measures, why we put locks on our doors and why we have a Defence Force. The goal of all of us in having a provision for defence is to be so strong, so professional, so capable that those military forces would never need to be used because they act as a deterrent against any that would trespass upon us.

I do not have time to go into a philosophical or, even in the case of Senator Vallentine, a theological debate about why I am not a pacifist. The great majority of Christians in Australia are not pacifists. We seek peace even where the steps along that road require force. Let me make it entirely clear to Senator Vallentine, in relation to her statement that we do not want to see more dead people as the result of politicians' decisions, that that is what moves both the Government and the Opposition, as I see it. By taking action, such as is supported by the United Nations resolution 678, we want to minimise the pain, the evil and even the deaths that would be predictable in the event of a 1930s escalation of military might in the hands of a Hitler or a Saddam Hussein.

The situation is not as the honourable senator describes, too cynically, too insensitively, in her speech here today. I recognise that the second group are isolationists; that is, they are mostly from the hard right which wants allies not to be involved in a small country at the top of the Persian Gulf because that is apparently, on first look, too far away. Isolationists are wrong because there will be repercussions even from a long way away eventually, if aggression is not resisted.

Thirdly, there are the painlessists, those who recognise the illegality of the action of Iraq. Sure they want Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait; they even support sanctions, especially if there are not any naval deployments, planes and military that have to go there and make sure the sanctions work. They want a completely painless solution, where there is no military deployed so there could be no possibility of a person in that deployment being killed. They are living in a dream, in a fog.

I do not believe that any of these three positions are tenable. It is in order to gain peace that we come, as in the Prime Minister's statement, to a support of all that is involved in United Nations resolution 678. The fourth matter I wish to refer to is the statement on page 3 asking whether now is the time:
The question is, whether now is the right time to contemplate this further and graver step.
The Prime Minister continues:

The answer is plain. The aim of the sanctions has been to prove to Iraq, both through the seriousness of the action itself, and through the great sacrifices which the sanctions have imposed already both on Iraq and on its former trading partners, that the world would not accept Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
The statement is correct when it says:
And yet they have not succeeded in persuading Iraq's leaders to withdraw from Kuwait . . . it is therefore timely . . .

I support page 3 of the statement. As I started off, I said that it was on 2 August that Iraq invaded Kuwait. It is more than four months since then. The sanctions have been in place for more than three months. Had anyone at all put forward a view that Saddam Hussein looked like withdrawing or was even thinking about withdrawing before last Thursday? United Nations resolution 678 was the first thing that led to any movement in Iraq, and that led to the Foreign Minister of Iraq preparing to go to Washington for discussions or indeed to Secretary of State Baker preparing to see Saddam Hussein in Baghdad.

I believe that this whole decision, that is bipartisan between the Government and the Opposition, is looking firstly to peace through a direct and complete withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait. In the event that there is not that withdrawal, and the deterrent, or the threat, of the use of force after 15 January is not heeded, then they will be forced from Kuwait.

I wish to refer at this stage to two or three paragraphs of an article written by David Pryce-Jones entitled `The Conquering Hero', which was published 10 weeks ago, in mid-September, in the New Republic. I quote it at length because I think this concept needs to be understood in Australia. I know that parallel statements, to a minor degree, can be made of any culture and indeed of any military organisation, but I think that there is a particular carefulness in the choice of words by this Arabist scholar that ought to be understood. The article states:

Refusal to reflect upon the reality of the Arab world leads time and again to being disagreeably surprised by it. Anwar Sadat's crossing of the Suez Canal in 1973, the use of the oil weapon, the collapse of Lebanon and its invasion by Syria, the intifada, Saddam Hussein's attacks on Iran and Kuwait-all are presented in the West as unpredictable as acts of God. Their perpetrators are thought to be irrational or suicidal. Yet all are a natural part of the Arab social and political order. The violence is systemic, therefore self-repeating. So strong is the logic of Arab behaviour that Westerners are obliged to fall in with it in a crisis like the present one.

According to Arab culture, power belongs to whoever has the will and strength to grasp it. Victory goes deservedly to the strong, while the vanquished and the weak are to be despised. Force is therefore a necessary instrument, the means by which the would-be leader eliminates his rivals. Once he has become an absolute power-holder at home, he finds some pretext to extend his reach by attacking abroad. Far from being considered a crime, the use of force establishes credentials in a leader and determines the primacy of his status. So it happens that Arabs come to applaud a leader who is very obviously endangering them.

Western societies are based upon free association, government by consent under the rule of law-in a word, contract. Contract is incompatible with the Arab concept of absolute power sanctioned by status. The gap between status and contract was perfectly illustrated in the way the invasion of Kuwait was answered by the legalities of the United Nations.

This refers to the decisions that were made in August by the United Nations and that, by inference, are being criticised by this author for lacking the kind of decisiveness, the kind of analysis that is now reflected in last Thursday's decision:

To Westerners, the use of force indicates social or political breakdown, and they can hardly conceive it in any positive connection with leadership and honor. It seems paradoxical that what looks like disorder and violence is actually a form of stability, a constant Darwinian testing of internal and external relationships. What puts an end to the ambitions of a leader is the arrival upon the scene of another who is more than his match. Communism in its heyday offered an approximation. The Party deemed that the promotion of its ends justified violence. The alleged class struggle of Nicolae Ceausescu resembled the careerist struggle of Saddam Hussein. Ceausescu's downfall is said to have jolted Hussein.
I read this final paragraph:

Needless to say, Arabs are no more and no less disposed than other peoples to war and cruelty. The historic formula that ``force is the only language they understand'' is not a racist ascription of innate bad character, but a comment upon the absolutism built into their culture. No institutions or political mechanisms, such as genuine representation or free speech, exist to temper or moderate the use of force in a leader. ``L'etat c'est moi'' is the total philosophy of every Arab ruler. Hussein put it clearly when he said recently that in Iraq the law is two lines on a sheet of paper with his signature below.

I believe that statement is pertinent and I believe that it immediately is a preamble to the kind of analysis that has led to the statement the Prime Minister has brought and which the Government and the Opposition support.

In the two minutes remaining to me in this debate I wish to draw a parallel between the end of the Cold War and a solution in the Gulf. The end of the Cold War did not come about this year as a result of pacifism or as a result of living in a flower power world of hippies and peaceniks. It did not come about through isolationism. It came about because the West was committed to peace through strength, to deterrence, to having such a military force that was so understood by potential disturbers of world stability that they never did disturb that stability in a serious way. What brought about the end of the Cold War was a commitment by us to peace through strength.

I am not a militarist; I support a strong military capability in order to have a deterrent that can win peace through strength. In the same way as the end of the Cold War has allowed the United Nations to work as it was originally intended, as first described in the words of the United Nations constitution in the year that I was born, I believe that will provide the solution in the Gulf. Even putting aside the analysis of Arab cultural leadership to which I have referred, peace will be achieved through strength. There will need to be a full commitment to the need to use force again. We all hope that force is not needed, but it is the commitment and the potential of the use of that force that will lead to the withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait and to peace and a genuine solution to the problems in the Gulf that we all wish to see achieved as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The subject matter of this debate could hardly be more important to a national parliament. It is of concern to me that the speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that was to be presented to the Senate by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) will not now appear at the beginning of this debate. I am not questioning the right of any of my parliamentary colleagues to deny leave. I was not one of those to deny leave, but I believe that the matter was serious enough for the Minister to deliver his statement to this chamber. That would have set the tone of seriousness which this debate deserves. Despite the fact that the Minister did not deliver the statement, I believe that by and large the debate has been conducted in measured terms, as the subject deserves.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had the statement for some time and have studied it. Over the past two or three months I have considered this question deeply, as have others. I have agonised over the issue and asked myself, `Is Kuwait an area of such strategic interest to us as to warrant deployment of our forces?'. That question is being asked throughout the length and breadth of Australia. It is a question with which each one of us has had to come to terms and to which each one of us has had to come up with a personal response. We are dealing with a very grave situation indeed. We are dealing with the lives of our own people as well as with the lives of hundreds of thousands of others.

On a narrow interpretation of our strategic interests, the answer to the question as to whether Kuwait is of such strategic interest to us as to warrant deployment of our armed forces is no. The supply of Gulf oil to us or to our trading partners so far as it relates to oil from Kuwait or from Iraq would not of itself demand such a response. But, even on this narrow interpretation of our strategic interests, the question must be raised as to what happens next if Saddam Hussein is allowed to get away with what he has done.

The statement raises the possibility-indeed, it seems to infer the likelihood-of Saddam Hussein extending his actions further in the oil-rich region. It talks about the possibility of Iraq extending its hegemony through very crucial areas of that region. I wonder why the statement raised these as questions without giving very substantial information to the Parliament as to why they were being raised. I refer to the following passage on page four of the Prime Minister's speech:

As well, Australia has been deeply concerned by the consequences for the Middle East as a whole if Iraq's aggression was allowed to stand. Who could doubt that having swallowed Kuwait, a stronger Iraq would not then turn on its other neighbours? Who will explain how Iraq could then be prevented from establishing an hegemony over the entire region; an hegemony backed not only by chemical weapons, but sooner or later by nuclear weapons as well? And who could doubt the brutality of that hegemony?
These are not scare-mongering speculations. They are serious assessments of the regional consequences of allowing Iraq's aggression to stand.

That is a statement made by the Government. Presumably, the Government has a very sound reason for stating that serious assessments have been made of the regional consequences of allowing Iraq's aggression to stand.

One, of course, has heard and read of those possibilities. I assume that the Government has intelligence information against which it has made such an assessment. Even under the narrow interpretation of the term `strategic interests', it seems that there needs to be an affirmative answer to the question, `Is Kuwait of such strategic interest to us as to warrant deployment of our armed forces?'.

But there is a broader, far deeper and more meaningful interpretation which needs to be placed on the term `strategic interests'. In short, it is world peace. World peace surely is of ultimate strategic interest to Australia. Action is surely needed to tell those who use brutal force that their actions will not be met by appeasement and that there will be a response based on the principle of defence of human rights, including the rights of people of all nations to be protected from unprovoked aggression.

It may be said that there are a whole range of areas in this world where peoples have been denied that right and where unprovoked aggression has taken place. Indeed, in this area of the Middle East, how often have we heard in this chamber the true story about what has happened in Lebanon over the last 15 years? It is tragic. I believe the Western world has not faced up to that issue. There are other areas in that Middle East region where there is aggression and denials of human rights.

Last year, we saw the results of years of violations of human rights in China manifested almost symbolically in the killings in Tiananmen Square. There are examples of the denials of this right. But just because we have not faced up properly to those violations and denials of human rights and national integrity, does that mean that we should not face up to the situation right here and now? Does that mean that we should let this aggressor, Saddam Hussein, get away with his invasion of Kuwait and with his hostage led terrorism at this time? In my view, certainly not.

Therefore, the answer to the question as to whether it is in the strategic interests of Australia to warrant the deployment of our armed forces in the area is in the affirmative. But the questions remain: to what extent should that occur? Should we continue with the measured limited response that has taken place heretofore? Can we, as has been done by many speakers, laud the United Nations for its actions? Quite frankly, Mr Acting Deputy President, dealing with the latter question first, I am yet to have my faith restored in the United Nations. I am very concerned at the possibility that blind eyes have been turned to violations of human rights in other areas in order to get this vote through the Security Council without veto.

I noted a report only last Friday from an international news service that the West, it appears, will be toning down its response to the violations of human rights in China. It is denied that this has anything to do with the fact that China did not use its veto power in the Security Council. But there is a worrying question in the back of my mind about that. Time will tell. I certainly will be looking at the actions of this Government as to whether its views on the violations of human rights in China have been mollified.

To what extent should we commit our armed forces? The Prime Minister's statement indicates that we will continue with the strength of the task force but that it will be placed into a more strategic and effective position in the Gulf area. At this point I would like to congratulate the members of the armed forces in the Gulf area for the actions that they have taken on behalf of the people of Australia. They deserve our congratulations and support. The same goes for the crews of the other vessels that are making their way to that region.

Are sanctions going to work? It appears that sanctions are not working in the sense that they have not resulted in Saddam Hussein changing his tack. The statement goes into that question and makes an assessment that it appears that the current level of sanctions is not sufficient at this stage to change the view of Saddam Hussein. President Hussein is a dictator; he is not particularly concerned about the pain suffered by the people of Iraq. I agree that, as was implied in the statement, Australians have had good relations with the people of Iraq. Nothing that I say and indeed nothing, as far as I can see, in this statement reflects on the people of Iraq. This is a clear message being given to Saddam Hussein and as such it is my view that it deserves the support of this Parliament and the people of Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON VIDEO MATERIAL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table the Government's response to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows-
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON VIDEO MATERIAL
The Government has either implemented or set in train many of the recommendations made by the Joint Select Committee on Video Material which reported to the Parliament in 1988.

The Committee produced 29 recommendations dealing with the method of classification of films and videos, the type of material which ought to be in those classifications, the organisation administering the legislation and the public and industry perception and observance of the classification categories.

The administration of censorship in Australia is a complex system which depends upon a great deal of co-operation between the Commonwealth and each of the States and the Territories to achieve uniformity. The power to censor is shared between the Commonwealth, the States and the Territories. The Commonwealth, under its Customs powers, controls the importation of censorable goods. The States and Territories control the sale and exhibition of film, videotape and printed matter through `point of sale' and `public exhibition' powers. The Commonwealth, through the Office of Film and Literature Classification, provides the co-ordinating body which classifies material, by arrangement, under State/Territory law.

The implementation of many of the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee therefore are not matters on which the Commonwealth can act on its own. The consideration of the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee has been done in co-operation with the States and Territories with a view not only to improve the existing structure but also to maximise uniformity throughout Australia. Some of the recommendations of the Committee extended beyond Commonwealth and State participation. The Committee recognised the important role that the film and video industry plays in the community both in the censorship/classification process and its pivotal role in the entertainment industry throughout Australia.

The consultations with the States and Territories and with the industry have been most productive and results are not apparent in video stores, in advertisements for films, and on posters advertising both film and video releases.
IMPLEMENTATION OF RECOMMENDATIONS

The Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments have welcomed the recommendations made by the Joint Select Committee. A majority of the recommendations have either now been implemented or are now in the process of being put into legislation. Some were put to the State and Territory Governments and were rejected because of resource implications and some were discarded because of the difficulty in implementation.

The Government has wholeheartedly supported what it considers to be the two most important recommendations made by the Joint Select Committee. These are the improved labelling of films and videos with the provision of more information to allow members of the community to make a more informed choice, and a public awareness campaign to inform people more precisely about the classification categories assigned to films and videos and to heighten the awareness of people in the community of the kinds of films that they and their children might see in each of the categories.
UNIFORM MARKINGS AND CONSUMER ADVICE

Legislation is not in place in the Australian Capital Territory, Victoria and Tasmania, and is in the legislative programs for other States and the Northern Territory, to improve the labelling on video cassettes and on films. Members and senators will be aware of the changes which have taken place in video outlets since May 1989, when the new requirements were announced. Although the new requirements do not have legal effect until the legislation is passed in each State, the distributors of video cassettes have co-operated with the Office of Film and Literature Classification by implementing changes in anticipation of the new laws. If members and senators survey the latest video releases in any of the video outlets throughout Australia, they will find clearly set out along the front bottom cover of the video cassette the classification symbol, an indication of the age group of the audience considered appropriate to watch the video, and a description of the category.

All videos classified after the 1st of May 1989, which are beyond the `G' category, have been assigned consumer advice by the Film Censorship Board. This consumer advice appears clearly marked under the classification description on each video.

Similar advice is also being provided with the classification of theatrical films and this advice, together with the classification description similar to that required on videos, will appear on all film posters and in all large newspaper advertisements for films. In smaller advertisements, the classification symbol will be more prominently displayed. A sample copy of the new markings is set out in Attachment `A'.

As a result of decisions taken by the Standing Committee of Censorship Ministers, the description of each category is now the same across Australia. The film and video industry has been involved in the application and design of the new requirements and has co-operated with the States, Territories and the Office of Film and Literature Classification in the final result. All of the these matters were canvassed in Recommendations 3, 4, 5 and 6.
PUBLIC AWARENESS CAMPAIGN

Recommendation 28 of the Joint Select Committee has been implemented by funding a public awareness campaign. The campaign is oversighted by a Steering Committee with Commonwealth (through the Office of Film and Literature Classification), State, Territory and industry representation. The campaign objectives include informing the community about:
* the meaning of the classification symbols and categories
* the role of parents in the selection of material to be viewed by minors in their case
* the process by which films are classified
* the factors influencing the classification given to a film.

The first stage of the campaign is to establish present levels of community awareness to enable uniformed design of a campaign communication strategy. This stage is nearing completion and it will provide the information for the campaign proper.
TIGHTER GUIDELINES FOR VIOLENCE

New guidelines were approved by Censorship Ministers in June 1988 and adopted by the Office of Film and Literature Classification. These guidelines accommodate the concerns of the Committee, especially in relation to violent material. In addition to the guidelines, the Ministers requested the Chief Censor and the Chairman of the Films Board of Review to tighten up the application of the guidelines to films which contained violence and were in the top end of the `M' and `R' categories. The new guidelines implement the suggestions in Recommendation 25.

In addition to incorporating the suggestions made by the Committee, the new guidelines were rewritten so that they could be more easily understood by members of the public and by the film and video industry.

The guidelines contain a preamble which sets out the context in which they operate and the general principles which apply when making classification decisions. The principles are drawn from the legislation of the States and Territories, all of which have some bearing on the final classification decision. A copy of those guidelines is also attached marked `B'.
RECALL PROVISIONS

The Government has provided the Film Censorship Board with the power to reclassify its own decisions after a two-year period. This enables the Board to vary previous classification decisions which do not accord with contemporary community standards. The Board has reassessed 13 videos. The results of the reassessment will be made known when all States and Territories have altered their legislation. The changes to the legislation incorporate existing appeal provisions and provide time for video retailers to take material from shelves if the reassessment results in the material being refused classification. All steps will be taken by the Office of Film and Literature Classification to inform video retailers of any revised decisions by advertisements in the national press and notification through trade papers.
NOTIFICATION OF CLASSIFICATION DECISIONS

Recommendation 18 sought the preparation of regular up to date consolidations of classification decisions that would be available to the public. Such a consolidation, incorporating video classifications from February 1984 (the commencement of the video scheme) until June 1988, was produced in conjunction with a private printer in December 1988.

No further such publication has taken place but, in line with Recommendation 18, it is now proposed to publish cinema and video classification decisions electronically on the Telecom Discovery public network.

This will result in `on-line' access for subscribers to a database of classification decisions. The service will enable users to request reports for their particular needs and will overcome the difficulties associated with searching through issues of Gazettes. The Gazettal of decisions will be discontinued once the services goes live in the last quarter of 1990.

The changes have been discussed in some detail with the different segments of the film and video industry and with the States and Territories. The rights of members of the public to inquire about the classification of films and videos from the State offices or from the Office of Film and Literature Classification will remain the same. As the Discovery system becomes more widely known, it is hoped that members of the public might be able to use the network directly or the outlet at the local video store or public library to obtain more information.
OTHER MEASURES

Legislation is now in place in the Australian Capital Territory, Victoria and Tasmania and is planned for the other States and the Northern Territory to give effect to Recommendation 8 that videotapes do not contain trailer advertisements for titles classified higher than the featured title on that videotape. While the legislation is still pending in some States, the video industry has complied voluntarily with this recommendation.

The States and Territories have agreed to extend up to 60 days, instead of the present 14, the period within which police may obtain certificates from the Chief Censor as prima facie evidence before a court (Recommendation 23).

The Federal and State Ministers have also agreed, as suggested in Recommendation 17, that videos referred to the Federal Attorney-General by a State censorship Minister will be passed on automatically to the Film Censorship Board for reassessment. This means that the reassessment by the Film Censorship Board will have an Australia wide application.
AUSTRALIAN LAW REFORM COMMISSION

The Australian Law Reform Commission was requested by the Attorney-General on 10 May 1990, following consultation with State and Territory censorship Ministers, to examine and revise censorship laws and report by 2 June 1991. A copy of the reference is attached marked `C'.
The aim is to formulate model Commonwealth legislation which will retain existing standards and arrangements but will simplify and co-ordinate censorship practice and procedure throughout Australia.

Recommendation 19, dealing with closing the gap between the criteria for prohibition contained in the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations and the criteria to refuse classification contained in Section 25 of the Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance, 1983, and Recommendation 29, that Commonwealth censorship legislation be dealt with by substantive legislation, are matters referred to the Law Reform Commission.
EXISTING PRACTICE

The Committee made a number of recommendations which support or modify slightly existing practices within the Board or about the composition of the Board or the Film and Literature Board of Review. Thus the recommendations which favour a single classification system, the value of part-time appointees to the Film Censorship Board, the retention of the Film and Literature Board of Review and the lengths of appointment to the Film Censorship Board and the Film and Literature Board of Review (Recommendations 14, 15, 26 and 27) all reflect current practice.
In addition, a reorganisation of the Office of Film and Literature Classification has provided for a modest research capacity for the Office as envisaged by Recommendation 16.

Further, the Director of Public Prosecutions already has the necessary delegation to prosecute under the Ordinance, a delegation which conforms with the general Commonwealth prosecution policy (Recommendation 22).
RECOMMENDATIONS NOT APPROVED

Several of the recommendations made by the Committee did not meet with the approval of all of the Governments. In some matters the Ministers agreed that the subject matter need not necessarily be dealt with on a uniform basis but would be for each individual State and Territory to make up its own mind on the matter.

The Ministers did not approve the creation of a new `Non-Violent Erotica' category as suggested in Recommendation 1 by the Committee to replace the present `X' classification. The question of the content of the proposed new category (Recommendation 2) therefore did not arise.

The Ministers also rejected the recommendations that hard-top cinemas be permitted to show material classified `NVE' (Recommendation 12); that video outlets, including mail order video outlets should be registered (Recommendation 20) and the recommendation that the language criteria for `PG' be the same as for `G' (Recommendation 24).

The Ministers considered the question of display of `R'-rated material in a separate room in video outlets. They decided this was not a matter where it was necessary for uniformity and that it would be for each State and Territory to consider what measures were appropriate.

New requirements for cinema and video advertising, effective from 1 May 1989, apply to all cinema and video releases classified after that date. The requirements deal with advertising on the front and back of video covers, video cassettes, posters, newspaper advertisements and other material, advertising films or videos.
The classification categories, the symbols, the age information and the category descriptions are as follows:

GUIDELINES FOR THE CLASSIFICATION OF FILMS, VIDEOTAPES AND PRINTED MATTER
PREAMBLE
Adults in a free society should be allowed as far as possible to see what they wish, and creative artists, including filmmakers, to depict what they please without fear of intervention by the State.
It is generally accepted, however, that the exercise of these rights carries certain responsibilities and must be subject to a number of constraints for the good of society as a whole.

Our right to see what we please cannot be allowed to infringe the rights of others. Children and young people, in particular, must be adequately protected from material likely to harm or disturb them, and people who may be offended by certain material have a right to expect that it will not be thrust upon them against their will or without warning.

Equally, the community has the right to ban material considered likely to endanger public health or safety, or grossly to offend accepted standards of public decency. Thus, films depicting child sexual abuse or bestiality, for example, or offering guidance or instruction in methods of terrorism, military subversion or drug abuse will be refused classification.

The attention given to acts of violence in modern society, especially sexual violence, has created a justifiable concern among many people that the depiction of violence in popular entertainment will encourage acts of imitation. Even if it could be shown that this was unlikely to occur, the feelings of those who abhor violence of any kind and consider its depiction in extreme forms degrading deserve respect. Any depiction of violence in films and videos must therefore be subject to careful scrutiny, and reserved, where appropriate, for mature and/or adult audiences.

The primary responsibility for protecting children and young people from harmful material rests with their parents or guardians. In discharging that responsibility they have a right to expect assistance from the State, especially as films and videos are so readily accessible. They must be confident that material to which children may be exposed has been carefully examined and appropriately classified.

The classification of films and videos is intended, therefore, both to protect children and young people, and to respect the sensibilities of adults who are concerned about violence and its effect on the community, and would consider certain kinds of material personally offensive.
GENERAL PRINCIPLES APPLYING TO THE GUIDELINES INCLUDE
* Adults should be free to see what they wish provided there is sufficient protection for young people, and those people who do not wish to see certain material should not have it thrust upon them.
* The classification should reflect what a reasonable adult person would consider within the acceptable limits of community standards for that age group.
* The closest attention is paid to the portrayal of violence and, in particular, sexual violence.
* Certain classes of activity, such as child sexual abuse, bestiality, and the incitement or encouragement of terrorism are refused classification.
ADDITIONAL CONSUMER INFORMATION

Films and videos in the upper limits of the `PG', `M' and `R' categories will carry, in addition to the classification symbols, consumer advice and, where necessary, a warning as to possibly offensive content.
This advice will appear prominently on the cover of each video, on the cassette itself and in all advertising material.
GUILDELINES FOR FILMS AND VIDEOTAPES
G General (suitable for all ages)
Parents should feel confident that children may view material in this classification without supervision, knowing that no distress or harm is likely to be caused.
The following are permissible-
Language:
The mildest expletives, but only if infrequent and used in exceptional and justifiable circumstances.
Sex:
Very discreet verbal references or implications, provided they are justified by the narrative or other context.
Violence
Minimal, mild and incidental depictions, provided they are justified by the context.
PG Parental Guidance (parental guidance recommended for persons under 15)
Films in this classification may contain adult themes or concepts which, when viewed by those under 15 years, require the guidance of a parent or guardian.
The following are permissible-
Language:
Low level coarse language is acceptable, provided its use is not excessive.
Sex:
Discreet verbal and/or visual depictions, and references to sexual matters.
Violence:
Depictions of violence must be mild in their impact, and/or presented in a stylized or theatrical fashion, or in an historical context.
Other:
Discreet informational and/or anti-drug references. Mild supernatural or ``horror'' themes may warrant `PG'. Minimal nudity if in a justifiable context.
M Mature (suitable only for persons 15 years and over)

Material which is considered likely to disturb, harm or offend those under the age of 15 years will be classified `M'. While most adult themes may be dealt with, the degree of explicitness and intensity of treatment will determine what can be accommodated in this classification.
Language:
Crude language may be used, but not when it is excessive, unduly assaultive, or sexually explicit.
Sex:
Sexual intercourse or other sexual activity may be discreetly implied or simulated.
Violence:
Realistic violence of medium intensity may be depicted, but violent depictions with a high degree of realism or impact are acceptable only if contextually justified.
Other:
Drug use may be depicted, but not in an advocatory manner. Supernatural and ``horror'' special effects usually warrant an `M' classification.
R Restricted (18 years and over)
Material considered likely to be harmful to those under 18 years and possibly offensive to some sections of the adult community warrants an `R' classification.
Language:
There are virtually no restrictions on language in `R' films.
Sex:

Sexual intercourse or other sexual activity may be realistically implied or simulated. Depictions of sexual violence are acceptable only to the extent that they are necessary to the narrative and not exploitative.
Violence:
Highly realistic and explicit depictions of violence may be shown, but not if unduly detailed, relished or cruel.
Other:
Drug abuse may be depicted, but not in an advocatory manner.
Extreme ``horror'' special effects usually warrant an `R'.
X Non Violent Erotica (18 years and over)

No depiction of sexual violence, coercion or non-consent of any kind is permitted in this classification. Material which can be accommodated in this classification includes explicit depictions of sexual acts between consenting adults and mild non-violent fetishes.
Refused Classification
Any film or video which includes any of the following will be refused classification:
(a) depictions of child sexual abuse, bestiality, sexual acts accompanied by offensive fetishes, or exploitative incest fantasies
(b) unduly detailed and/or relished acts of extreme violence or cruelty; explicit or unjustifiable depictions of sexual violence against non-consenting persons
(c) detailed instruction or encouragement in:
(i) the use of terrorist-type weapons and terrorist acts
(ii) the abuse of prescribed drugs.

In speaking to this report I wish to reflect on a news item in Saturday's Adelaide Advertiser which pointed out that a number of railway lines in South Australia have recently been closed and consequently a great deal of heavy freight has turned up on the roads. The article in question mentioned that in some country towns considerable amounts of money had been spent recently on rebuilding and repairing roads and they were rapidly falling into decay because of the closure of railway lines and the consequent heavy traffic being put onto the roads.

Interestingly, the comment from an ANL spokesman was that ANL had no public responsibilities or liabilities in this respect. It had no public service responsibilities and its direction was merely to ensure that it was as profitable as possible within the narrow confines of its balance sheet. It is very concerning to those of us in South Australia to observe that this is the case and that there is not some total social costing being done in respect of the cost of providing roads and services for roads as well as the cost of the provision of services for rail. I point out to the Senate that, since ANL has commenced this process of closure of country lines in South Australia, something like 350,000 tonnes of wheat from the 1989-90 harvest, which is currently stored in silos, is now to be transported by road rather than by rail.

These centres include Wilmington, Melrose, Booleroo Centre, Wirrabara, Gladstone, Gulnare, Yacka, Brinkworth, Blyth, Hoyleton, Snowtown, Bute, Paskeville, Andrews, Orroroo, Hallett, Robertstown, Stockwell, Cambari, Strathalbyn, Waikerie and Millicent. In all of those areas, some 350,000 tonnes of grain will now be transported by road at roughly 25 tonnes per truck load. It does not require very much knowledge of mathematics to work out how many trucks that means will be passing over the roads, compared with transporting the same amount of grain by train at some 2,000 tonnes per train load. Nor does the situation stop there. Silos presently served by rail are expected, within the next two years, to be shut and will therefore have to be served by road.
