SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has responded to the Joint Select Committee on Video Material and assures the Senate that it has either implemented or set in train many of the recommendations made by the Committee which, I might add, reported to the Parliament in 1988. It is now 1990 and we find that the Government has not responded to the major recommendations of that Committee in any way at all. I quote from the Government's response:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has wholeheartedly supported what it considers to be the two most important recommendations made by the Joint Select Committee.

It claims that the two most important recommendations were the labelling of films and the heightening of the awareness of people in the community of the kinds of films that they and their children might see in each of the categories. These were recommendations of the Committee, but they were minor recommendations considering the ones that this Committee made. The Government assures the Senate that it has tightened guidelines on violence. I again quote from the Government's response:

New guidelines were approved by Censorship Ministers in June 1988 and adopted by the Office of Film and Literature Classification. These guidelines accommodate the concerns of the Committee, especially in relation to violent material . . . The new guidelines implement the suggestions in Recommendation 25.

That is, of course, a lot of rubbish. They do not implement the guidelines put down by the Committee. I read from the Government's own document in attachment B regarding R-rated videos and what is permitted under violence:
Highly realistic and explicit depictions of violence may be shown, but not if unduly detailed, relished or cruel.

The unanimous recommendation of the Committee was that the current guidelines for R violence be altered. The R violence guidelines should now read-and I stress this- `Explicit depictions of violence but not detailed', and then the new word being put in on the recommendation of the Committee, `relished'. So it reads, ` . . . but not detailed, relished or gratuitous depictions of acts of considerable violence or cruelty'.

The Government's new violence criteria is a long way short of that recommended by the Committee. I will again compare the two, because there is a great deal of difference. What the Government permits now is `highly realistic and explicit depictions of violence', but what we recommended were not `highly' but just `explicit depictions of violence'. Then we go on, `but not detailed, relished or gratuitous depictions of acts of considerable violence or cruelty'. The Government states, `Highly realistic and explicit depictions of violence may be shown, but not if unduly detailed, relished or cruel'.
The Government makes sure that it adds the word `unduly'. So it is absolute rubbish for the Government to claim, as it says:
The new guidelines implement the suggestions in Recommendation 25'.

That is certainly not the case. It is of great concern to me that the Government, through its Minister, Senator Tate, would put down such untrue statements and try to fool the people in the community that it is abiding by the recommendations of the Committee in this regard.

The Government's statement goes on that it met with Ministers from all the States, and it assures us that the Ministers did not approve of the creation of a new non-violent erotica (NVE) category, as suggested by recommendation I. The first recommendation of the Senate Committee was that there be a new category of NVE. The Government says that because the Ministers did not approve the creation of a new non-violent erotica category, as suggested in recommendation I by the Committee, to replace the present X classification, the question of recommendation II did not occur.

There was never a recommendation by the Committee that X-rated videos should be replaced by non-violent erotica. The minority of the Committee recommended that, but it was not the recommendation of the Committee, which is always considered to be the majority. I am at a loss to understand why the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) has permitted this response to be read under his name; it is not a truthful document. It says that recommendation I of the Committee is that non-violent erotica be replaced by the present X-rated videos. Recommendation I does not suggest that, and it is completely untruthful of the Government to put down such a report on our Committee, making false accusations. The Government's response states further that, because the Ministers-these are the various Ministers of State-did not agree with that supposed recommendation, the question of the content of the proposed new category, recommendation II, did not arise. Recommendation II states:
The Committee draws attention-
that is, to the non-violent erotica, which would contain the material defined under the current classification of X-rated videos-
to the fact that the majority of the Committee disagrees with the proposal . . .

So it was not the recommendation of the majority of the Committee but of the minority and, as such, it is a pity that the Government cannot be truthful in its documents. I am very concerned that this has occurred. That leads us to the fact that the Government did not pick up the fact that the majority of the Committee recommended that X-rated videos be abolished. In its report, the Government states:
The Commonwealth, under its Customs powers, controls the importation of censorable goods.

With this power the Government could certainly make sure that no X-rated videos were allowed in this country. We have recently seen that the New South Wales Government has stopped the production of X-rated videos in that State. I welcome that decision by the New South Wales Government because it is in line with its legislation prohibiting the sale of X-rated videos. We all know that this debate has gone on for a considerable time. We are fully aware that the Government has frustrated the will of every State in this country. By allowing X-rated videos to be sold and rented in this Territory, it has frustrated the decision of the Attorneys-General of all the States to abolish X-rated videos. Every State can buy X-rated videos from Canberra quite legally because of the free trade between States clause in the Constitution.

I would like to read a very short passage from the speech I made when I brought down a private member's Bill with the aim of downgrading violence in videos and abolishing X-rated videos. In part, I stated:

On 30 June this year following the tabling of our report all the Australian Attorneys-General met and as a result of that meeting a unanimous agreement was reached between the States and Commonwealth Attorneys-General. It was agreed that most Australians wanted ` `X'' rated and excessively violent videos outlawed and that the way to accomplish this was that there should be a National approach on the issue. This was necessary . . . because while all the States have for some time banned the sale or hire of ``X'' rated videos under their jurisdiction, the Commonwealth had refused to do so in the territories, resulting in the free trade of these videos being carried out between the States and Territories and so thwarting the States legislation . . . the Government had so strongly supported these ``X'' rated videos that over a period of 4 years it has delayed time and time again any action being taken to support the States in this area.
I continued:

Many Government members claim adults should be able to see and read whatever they choose, believing that there should not be any censorship. However, they happily go along with the need for censorship of child pornography, bestiality, etc . . . It is really only a matter of where the censorship line is drawn not whether there should be censorship or not.

During the Committee hearings, evidence was given to the Committee by many Social and Behavioural Science Researchers that they believed prolonged viewing of ``X'' rated videos can have very detrimental effects on certain individuals with aggressive tendencies.
But perhaps the evidence I appreciated most was given by Professor Sheehan at the Queensland University when he said:
. . . the critical thing in whether or not there will be these so-called effects of sexually explicit material is how aggressive the person is in the first place . . .

There is no question that a lot of people are stimulated mildly or strongly by seeing sexually explicit material. When one is aroused one tends to behave as a consequence of that arousal and I think if the person is aggressive aggression will out . . . In and of itself, I do not think that sexually explicit material divorced from aggression leads to strong negative effects. Once you combine sexually explicit material with aggression you have a different kettle of fish . . . The critical thing is how much someone is aroused and how aggressive he is in the first place.
I was quoting that from our Committee report. My speech continued:

When you consider that evidence in conjunction with other evidence we received . . . and you look at it in the light of the latest Australian survey on domestic violence which shows that 22% (or 1 in 5) of Australian men are so aggressive that they believe it is acceptable for a man to use physical force against his female partner then we have a potentially explosive situation. Females of all ages feel threatened and are becoming increasingly concerned for their personal safety.

I went on to explain how women's groups throughout Australia have expressed their concern. Women's groups throughout Australia have unanimously joined together and begged the Government to make sure that X-rated videos are banned. The Government has said that it is too degrading to allow them to be shown in cinemas, but it is content to allow them to be seen as home entertainment.

I suppose that I should not be disappointed in the Government's response, but I am extremely disappointed that Senator Tate, the Minister in charge of this response, is not in the chamber. I am considerably disappointed that the Government has not seen fit to tell the truth in its report and that it has, indeed, misquoted the Senate Committee's report and attributed recommendations that the minority Committee put up as recommendations of the Committee.

The Government has done this not only with regard to the supposed downgrading of violence, as I have already described-which the Committee certainly has not done-but also with regard to the X-rated videos. But I suppose that the women of Australia, who have deserted the Government in their droves, will just have to wait until we are in government, which will be not too long, before their concerns are addressed. The Government should realise that this is what is happening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters has pointed clearly to a number of the inadequacies in the Government's response to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. First and foremost, this is a response by the Government to a joint select committee report which was tabled in the Parliament in April 1988, over two years ago. The Government, only now, makes its response to the Parliament on that report.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Walters said, the response is shamefully inadequate-I do not know whether she said `shamefully', but no doubt that is what she meant-in a number of other respects. She has pointed very clearly to its inadequacy in relation to the recommendation of the majority of the Joint Select Committee when it came to the question of violence. She has indicted quite definitively how the response of the Government, as contained in its paper, does not match up with the response that is contained in the actual guidelines.

In other words, what the Government seems to be telling all and sundry in this response is that yes, it has accepted the recommendations of the Committee so far as tightening up guidelines on violence is concerned. Yet, if one looks at the way that the guidelines have been reframed, in effect it means that they have not been tightened but have been loosened. That is a shameful thing. It is doubly shameful because the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material made the specific recommendation in respect of violence.

I might say that as one of the majority of that Committee I was amused, to put it mildly, to hear the allegations made both inside and outside this Parliament, and carried on through the press, that whereas the majority of the Committee were very strict on sex that meant that they were not concerned about violence. We heard that come out of the mouths of the video porn merchants here in Canberra time after time. Yet it was the majority of the Committee who did the work on violence.

I do not know whether I am out of order, Mr Deputy President-and you will correct me if I am-but the draft on violence of the Chairman, Dr Klugman, was pitifully small whereas our draft, considering the time that was given to us, was a substantial consideration of the question of violence. If it were not for the majority, who were led by Senator Walters as Deputy Chair, I doubt whether there would have been the attention given to violence that was ultimately given to it by this Committee.

As Senator Walters has said, the response ignores the fact that, besides the violence question, the majority of the Committee strongly opposed the proposition that there be a new NVE category which would contain the material as defined in the current classification of X.
Concerning that recommendation, the majority of the Committee said this:
It would entrench X-rated video pornography (described officially as `hard core pornography' . . . in the community under the guise of the misleading title of NVE.

The proposal runs counter to the overwhelming burden of evidence submitted to the Committee concerning the harmful effects of this material and is inconsistent with the findings of the Committee thereon.

Almost all of the current X-rated video pornography (and their R equivalents) fall within Category II Non Violent Degrading Pornography and some in Category III (see paragraphs 13.46-13.51 of the Report). Rather than entrenching this material into the community we recommend that the Commonwealth Government introduce substantive legislation to ensure that this material is refused classification for the purposes of Commonwealth laws.
That was the recommendation of the majority of the Committee. Where is the response of the Government to that recommendation?

As Senator Walters has indicated, all of the States requested that this material be refused classification. The Federal Government, and the Federal Government alone, is responsible for the appalling situation that now exists in Australia in respect of this material. The weakness with which it has approached this-its intellectual bankruptcy about this question-is absolutely appalling. I think history will show when a true study is done of the work that was undertaken by the majority of that Joint Select Committee, that we were the ones who put forward a consistent, valid approach, based on principles which demanded implementation by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I rise to speak on the adjournment in respect of remarks attributed to Senator Grant Chapman in the 4 December edition of the Adelaide Advertiser concerning our commitment to the Gulf, our naval personnel and the attitude of Australian families whose loved ones are serving with the Royal Australian Navy in the Gulf region.

SPEECH.PARA: Three remarks in particular took me aback. I believe they will also take the Senate aback. They were observations made about the Gulf. The article was entitled, `Navy families whingers: MP'. The article begins by saying:
A South Australian senator has attacked ``whingeing'' families for ``bleating'' about the possibility that Australian sailors in the Gulf may not be home for Christmas.
It then attributes remarks to Senator Chapman directly. He is reported as saying:
The continual publicity given to whingeing family members does nothing to bolster our image overseas as an elite fighting force but, rather, shows us up to be a pack of wimps.
He continues:
Most Australians must be heartily sick of hearing the constant bleating from families of sailors who are serving on our ships in the Gulf.
This constant bleating from sailors' families does nothing for the morale of the country or, for that matter, the sailors themselves.

I found those remarks extraordinary. I informed Senator Chapman earlier this evening that I would be speaking on this matter on the adjournment as I believed those observations should not go either unacknowledged in the Senate or without answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike with the NCA, when you didn't inform anyone that you were going to give it a spray.
— I will always respond when criticised. I invite Senator Knowles--
—Order!
— I would be more than happy to hear Senator Knowles defend Senator Chapman's remarks and thereby endorse them.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I did not defend Senator Chapman's remarks. Senator Loosely knows that, and I ask him to withdraw.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I draw your attention to what was actually said.
—Order! I have just come into the chair this second. If Senator Knowles claims to have been misrepresented, she can seek leave to make a personal explanation. It is not a point of order.

—Mr President, can I then take a point of order. Senator Loosley was in the process of criticising Senator Chapman. He had the grace to say that he had earlier this evening notified Senator Chapman that he would be making these comments. Senator Knowles then said, `Why didn't you do the same thing in relation to the National Crime Authority?', to which both Senators Cook and Loosley replied that that constituted a defence of Senator Chapman's position. I accept that you might not have been in a position to have heard the interchange. But having heard it relayed by me-and if there is any dispute that point can be taken-I would think that it was part of your responsibility to ensure that those remarks do not go unnoticed during the debate and not merely corrected after the event.

—There is no point of order because there was no imputation of an improper motive. If somebody feels that he or she wants to make a statement later, he or she can seek to do so in the appropriate way.

— Our naval forces in the Gulf are entitled to our support; they are entitled to the support of every member of parliament and of every honourable senator. The Australian people expect nothing less. That has been very much in the national tradition throughout this century. It is not only a matter of patriotism regarding the service of our armed forces and the duties they are performing but also a commitment on behalf of the country to our international obligations built around a United Nations resolution based on a principle in concert with our allies. Given that, our servicemen are entitled to our support.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at Senator Chapman's remarks in the Adelaide Advertiser we can only conclude that it is an extraordinarily brave statement demonstrating real courage and resolution! At a time when their men are away serving their country, the honourable senator is critical of their women and children. That is really being in touch with public opinion! That is showing one's colours and demonstrating audacity. I doubt that a single Australian would endorse the honourable senator's remarks. It begs the question: for whom does the honourable senator speak? He certainly does not speak for the families. Does he speak for the Navy? I doubt it. Does he speak for Australians generally? I doubt it. Does he speak for the Opposition? We will wait and see the consequences. Senator Chapman is safe and comfortable. He is protected and privileged. Not since Douglas Haig committed the British Army to the Somme have we witnessed front-line daring of this nature. This country's history has not been characterised by anything other than solid support for our service men and women abroad. These remarks break that tradition. From time to time it has been said that we, as a government, are out of touch and that we are distant. Perhaps sometimes that is true. But not on this issue. Judging by Senator Chapman's remarks, he is out of touch-absolutely and embarrassingly out of touch.

We have had a degree of bipartisanship on the Gulf issue. That is welcome. It should be continued and, wherever possible, it should be extended. Given that, we should have bipartisan rejection of these arrogant and foolish remarks, which constitute sexist nonsense. No-one wants this kind of indulgence to jeopardise Australian policy on the Gulf, international cooperation and our determination in the face of aggression. It is Senator Chapman's remarks, not the remarks of the families, that could damage morale if they were left unanswered. They could damage morale on the ships and at home. They are nothing other than divisive.

I say just a brief word about our naval personnel serving in the Gulf of Oman and shortly in the Persian Gulf. We are talking about 372 officers and men on the two frigates; we are talking about several hundred dependants. The three ships currently involved-HMAS Darwin, HMAS Adelaide and HMAS Success-left on 13 August. The frigates return to Darwin on 14 December. We are talking about these people spending four months away in a war zone. The families are entitled to be concerned about the safety of their loved ones. They are certainly entitled to want their loved ones home, and home for Christmas. The families are entitled to be spared the stupidity inherent in these remarks as reported. They are entitled to be angry, as they have shown by their response.

Given the courage that the families of the naval personnel have demonstrated to date, and given their commitment, indeed their stoicism, they are entitled to have a defence made of them in the Senate this evening. The families of the naval personnel have put personal interest to one side in the national interest; indeed, in our international interest. As I said earlier, I cannot foresee anyone endorsing these remarks. I hope no honourable senator would.

There is now an obligation before the Opposition, squarely before Dr Hewson and certainly before Senator Hill and Senator Durack. They can remain silent and thereby endorse Senator Chapman's remarks, they can ignore the remarks and thereby give them tacit approval or they can do what I hope they will and publicly repudiate the remarks. The simple choice is theirs. As for Senator Chapman, he can salvage his position by withdrawing the remarks and apologising without reservation. That, too, is his choice tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Senator Loosely made a statement that it was interesting that I had supported the statement that he had alleged had been made by Senator Chapman. —In other words, you cannot understand the English that the Minister used today? I was wondering whether you could just explain what those words meant.
—I will find out.
—Mr President, I think that the Minister was possibly at a disadvantage because he was laughing, joking and talking with a few of his colleagues. Perhaps he would like me to repeat it.
—Order! Senator Walters, address your remarks through the Chair.

— Mr President, I was. I said that the Minister was at a disadvantage because he was laughing, joking and talking with his colleagues, so he did not hear what I said. I did address my remarks to you, particularly, Mr President. If Senator Richardson will listen for a minute, I will repeat Senator Tate's answer:

SPEECH.PARA: Peat Marwick Hungerfords Management Consultants has been asked to investigate the factors leading to the laundry's operating losses and strategies to secure the viability of the laundry. I believe that the particular strategy coming out of that consultancy will need considerable financial support from the Federal Government, and that support will be forthcoming. I am very confident that funds to implement that rehabilitation of the Bay View laundry service and to secure its viability will come by the end of this month in order to ensure that the consultancy recommendations can be carried through in a way which will support the activity of that very fine institution in Hobart.

I ask whether that means that the $183,000, as originally promised by the Minister and the Department just a couple of weeks before the election, will be paid minus the $45,000 it received today to help its cash flow, or whether it means something totally different. I do not know what it means. I hope that Senator Richardson can help me because the group of people who are supporting, as Senator Tate says, this very worthy and fine institution in Hobart are desperately in need of the advice as to whether they will be able to continue supporting disabled working people in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very appropriate that Senator Walters flagged a possible broken promise because I want to speak about a promise that certainly was broken. I propose to speak on an issue which has been termed `The politics of the big lie'. I refer to the promise by Mr Hawke in his 1987 policy speech that, by 1990, no Australian child will be living in poverty. It is regrettable that Mr Hawke did not learn the lessons from 1987. Just last week, we learned that the big lie of the 1990 elections was confirmed. I refer to Mr Hawke's promise that `We won't let there be a recession'.

SPEECH.PARA: I propose this evening to summarise the history of Mr Hawke's broken promise on child poverty from the time he decided to include it in his 1987 policy speech to the present day. It demonstrates, I believe, the style that Mr Hawke has brought into public life in Australia-a cynicism not matched by any other Prime Minister in memory. What distinguishes this Prime Minister, indeed, this Government, is a willingness to give explicit commitments about profound and complex issues which are breathtaking, initially in their boldness but ultimately in their deceit-false commitments relating to matters of great moment which greatly trouble this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the taxation promises.

—I know Senator Richardson is excited about it; the Prime Minister gets excited about it every time we mention it. He should just sit there quietly and listen. This, after all, is the very essence of the big lie, a lie so big that others come to believe the statement simply because they do not believe that anyone would be cynical enough to make it unless, of course, it were true.

SPEECH.PARA: This notorious broken promise by Mr Hawke continues to be a public issue some three years after it was made. Just a fortnight ago, Mr Hawke wrote to Mr Alasdair Webster, the honourable member for Macquarie, following a question raised by Mr Webster in the Parliament. In this letter, Mr Hawke makes the staggering admission that the Government did not have an accepted measure of poverty. How then, we may ask, could he promise that no Australian child would live in poverty when, by his own admission, the Government did not have a measure of poverty? Sir Walter Scott's famous quotation is well illustrated by Mr Hawke on the issue of child poverty. Sir Walter Scott said this:
O what a tangled web we weave,
When first we practise to deceive!

Mr President, I wish to place on record some of the deceptions, obfuscations and buck passing that Mr Hawke has indulged in in an attempt to explain away his broken promise. The first point of note is that it was apparently Mr Hawke's decision, and Mr Hawke's decision alone, to make his unequivocal, unqualified statement in the 1987 policy speech that:
By 1990, no Australian child will be living in poverty.

Senator Richardson can confirm, when he stands up to speak, that there was apparently no Cabinet submission or document which would form the basis for this policy announcement. After all, as I have just noted, the Government does not have a definition of poverty. Richard Farmer, the well-known journalist and occasional Labor Party adviser, has informed us that the first version of the 1987 policy speech said:
No child shall be consigned by the community to a lifetime of poverty.
The second draft of the speech said:
No child should be consigned to poverty.

These are statements and sentiments which we can all have great sympathy with, but Mr Hawke had to go further. He wanted to capture the newspaper headlines with a dramatic statement. With a stroke of his pen, Mr Hawke changed a sensible and commendable statement to an unqualified promise that:
By 1990, no Australian child will be living in poverty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he get the advice from the Right?

—Who knows? He might have got it from Senator Richardson, who is sitting here. He could confirm that. Mr Farmer says it was changed because it had `a more rhetorical ring to it'. There is no sign here of any strong commitment backed by detailed policy advice. It has to be said, and it has to be said truly, that Mr Hawke's initial aim was certainly achieved. Newspaper headlines and radio bulletins featured the promise on child poverty that Mr Hawke had made before the nation. Mr Hawke reaffirmed this commitment all through the subsequent 1987 election campaign. On 1 July, just 10 days before the election, Mr Hawke said:

SPEECH.PARA: There will be no watering down of the pledge that was made.

Of even greater significance, Mr Hawke made this statement on the following day, 2 July 1987, in answer to a question on whether all families with children would be lifted above the Henderson poverty line. Mr Hawke replied:
That is right.

TALK.START.PARA: —He knew what the poverty line was.

—He knew what poverty line he was talking about. Let us contrast this statement with the recent letter to Mr Webster in which he argued that the Government `has never accepted the Henderson poverty line as a yardstick for determining the number of people in poverty'. Yet, as I have just said, before the 1987 election Mr Hawke certainly accepted the Henderson poverty line as an appropriate measure.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go back a few steps in order to examine Mr Hawke's other deceptions. Since the initial promise, Mr Hawke has been asked numerous questions in the Parliament and in the media about the numbers of Australian children in poverty. Mr Hawke has tried a number of tactics in an attempt to extract himself from this commitment. The first tactic was the tactic I have called redefining the promise. First, Mr Hawke tried to change the promise by undertaking a remarkable series of semantic games and back flips. For example, in the Parliament in April 1988, just 10 months after the policy speech, Mr Hawke said this:
How can I say at any time that no child will live in poverty?

The answer to that is that he can say it, he did say it, and he said it in the 1987 election speech. He tried to refer us to the small print, saying the real promise was contained in the attachments to the policy speech, which said:
There will be no need for any Australian child to live in poverty by 1990.

This ploy did not work. The public naturally regarded that the overriding commitment was contained in the policy speech televised to the nation on 23 June 1987. The newspaper headlines of the time convey the contempt with which Mr Hawke's effort to redefine the promise was treated. The Canberra Times said: `Hawke back-pedals on election promise'. The Adelaide Advertiser said: `Hawke hit by loss of memory'. Most devastating of all was the headline in the Australian: `Poor children need not depend on Hawkespeak'. It did not work, and so another tactic had to be adopted and this tactic was to blame the parents. This was tactic No. 2. On 23 February 1998, Mr Hawke berated parents who forced poor children out of home. One month later he argued:
I can't dictate that no parents will behave awfully to lead kids to run away from home.
This tactic proved as unconvincing to the public as his earlier attempt to redefine the promise.

Tactic No. 3 was worked out. I do not know whether the honourable senators in the chamber on the Labor side were involved in this. Tactic No. 3 was another bold stroke. It was called: `I've kept my promise'. As the political pressure mounted, Mr Hawke and his advisers announced this new strategy. The tactic was to claim that the promise had been kept-not only kept, but delivered early, before the 1990 deadline. On 13 April 1989, Mr Hawke arranged to have a dorothy dixer asked by the honourable member for Petrie, Mr Johns. Mr Hawke answered:
I am proud to say I lead a Government which has not waited until 1990 to deliver on its promises. In 1989 we have delivered on that promise to the benefit of 3.8 million children.

As usual, Mr Hawke indulged in a massive overstatement. Tactic No. 3 reached its peak in September 1989 when Mr Hawke said at a speech to the annual conference of the Australian Council of Social Service in Melbourne:

At the outset of the last election campaign, I committed a re-elected Labor Government to an ambitious and proud goal: the elimination of child poverty in Australia. Since the re-election we have acted with determination to reach that goal-and we reached it ahead of target.
Let us remember that this is the man who told Mr Webster just two weeks ago that he could not define poverty. In the next part of his speech Mr Hawke again attempted to qualify his big statement:
We made it clear that our pledge in this matter was to do what was in our power to do-that is, to create the situation where there was no financial need for a child to live in poverty.
The newspaper headlines reflected the cynicism of the nation. The Sydney Morning Herald's headlines summed up the nation's response:
PM's poverty claim rouses angry chorus.
Tactic three, `I've kept my promise', collapsed within days as welfare lobbies and others pointed out the absurdity of the Prime Minister's claim.

Tactic four is what I have called `I'm (a little bit) sorry'. Within days the backtracking started again. With the election looming, Mr Hawke and his advisers decided that a degree of contrition might restore the credibility of the Prime Minister. Tactic four was to admit a slight error-a drafting error. On 29 October 1989, Mr Hawke said:
The shorthand phrase in the speech I consider, in retrospect, was unfortunate.
On the following day he said:
No government in a democracy can ensure there will be no children living in poverty.

That statement at least is correct. Nevertheless, the debate continued with major welfare agencies demanding action on Mr Hawke's child poverty promise. The election was looming and another tactic was required. With 18 days to go to the beginning of 1990, when it should be remembered that no child should be living in poverty, Mr Hawke adopted an old tactic-call a summit. Undoubtedly this strategy was aimed to divert the attention of the public, welfare agencies and the press with yet another talkfest. Financial assistance, it was argued, was not the only way to eliminate child poverty. What was needed were better services, and the summit of Federal and State governments would help tackle this goal.

Nevertheless, all through the 1989 election campaign Mr Hawke was continually pressed on his broken promise, which showed every sign of becoming one of the most infamous statements in Australian history. Tactic six I have called, `Blame the punctuation'-or, more specifically, `Blame the colon'. Some 29 days before the 1990 election was called, Richard Farmer suggested another approach. Calling Hawke's broken promise in 1987 a `mock controversy', he argued that the colon in Mr Hawke's policy speech had caused all the trouble. He urged:
. . . politicians should never read a sentence with a colon in it.
He pointed out that the previous sentence read as follows:
So we set ourselves this first goal: by 1990, no Australian child will be living in poverty.
Mr Hawke, it has to be said, unlike Mr Farmer, has never blamed the colon. Tactic six therefore argues that the promise was never a promise but only a goal. Richard Farmer continued:
It is quite possible to chide a Prime Minister for not achieving his goal but it is quite a different thing in claiming that he has broken a promise.

That is what the journalist and occasional Labor Party adviser wrote. In the post-March election period Mr Hawke has continued to be questioned on his promise to eliminate child poverty. Newspaper articles and accompanying cartoons continue to keep Mr Hawke's promise before the public. As noted by Richard Farmer in June, the promises become the brunt of jokes in the schoolyard.

Welfare agencies and church leaders continue to call for action on child poverty. Archbishop Hollingworth has been viciously attacked by the Prime Minister, we can all recall, because of his concern about the effect Government policies were having on child poverty. Still the questions in Parliament continue. Straightforward questions on 13 and 14 November by Ken Aldred, the honourable member for Deakin, and Alasdair Webster, the honourable member for Macquarie, on the number of children in poverty indicated that the Prime Minister had no idea of the numbers of children in poverty three years after the promise was made.
However-and this is quite important-in answer to those two questions he did accept that the numbers could be estimated. For example, he told Mr Aldred that he would have to do the following:
. . . refer to my colleague, the Minister for Social Security, to give the precise number that he would use in answer to the specific questions.

Finally, we reach tactic seven: the sterile debate. What could Mr Hawke and his advisers do? Was there another way of getting Mr Hawke off the hook? I do not know if Senator Richardson was involved in this stunt, but maybe he can tell us the answers. The first step was not to provide an answer to Parliament, but to provide a written response away from the glare of the press gallery. Mr President, I now seek leave to table the letter from Mr Hawke to Mr Webster.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the letter, as I have mentioned, Mr Hawke said that there was no widely accepted measure of poverty. That is correct; on the other hand, no other politician goes around promising to eliminate something he is not prepared to define. But Mr Hawke and his advisers had clearly forgotten Mr Hawke's comments early in July 1987 that families with children would be lifted above the Henderson poverty line.

SPEECH.PARA: The letter called the whole issue `a sterile debate'. In other words, people should stop talking about the numbers of children in poverty. Anyone who is concerned about the numbers of children in poverty is, according to Mr Hawke, only indulging in a sterile debate. This strategy is likely to prove as unsuccessful as all his previous attempts.

Archbishop Hollingworth is quoted in the Age in October as having estimated that 500,000 children were living in poverty. He spoke of what he called Mr Hawke's `unfinished business'. He warned of the adverse economic effects of the Government's high interest rate policies.

This is where the `big lie' of the 1987 election joins hands with the `big lie' of the 1990 election. In 1990, Mr Hawke said that he would not let there be a recession. Today in the Parliament, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) indicated that the Government had engineered a recession. The Treasurer has engineered the collapse of tens of thousands of small businesses, and he is engineering hundreds of thousands of Australians into unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —And bankruptcy.
—And bankruptcy, as Senator O'Chee has said. Mr Keating said some years ago:

SPEECH.PARA: The greatest cause of poverty in this country is undoubtedly unemployment.

By 1990 Mr Hawke has not eliminated child poverty. Instead, by 1990 he has delivered the most savage recession since the 1930s. As a result, poverty in Australia-including child poverty-will be increasing. No wonder this Government stands condemned as the Government of the `big lie'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not speak for very long. I think it is only the second time I have spoken on the adjournment debate. The reason I am doing so is that I am concerned, as Senator Walters was concerned, about an answer that the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, gave today concerning the Bay View laundry. When I perused the answer that was given and compared it with the press release that Senator Tate put out, certainly I found some matters of concern.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at the answer that was given by Senator Tate today, one would believe that this matter had just been raised and that Senator Tate had dealt with it very speedily. He said that he had undertaken to give speedy consideration to the matter; his was a great government, and it had come up with $45,000. As Senator Walters has already said, the promise was made to those people before the election in March that they would receive $183,000.

I believe that in desperation, after getting nowhere with anybody, those people involved approached members of the Opposition, such as Senator Walters and me, and possibly Senator Harradine. I know that Senator Tate was not very happy about that, but I believe that by doing so the people involved certainly brought the matter to a head. I am pleased to see that something has been done immediately, that is, that they have $45,000. I notice that in the press statement, which does give me a little more faith in the Minister's credentials, he says that further funds will be provided this month to implement certain recommendations.

At the end of the statement the Minister says that as a result of this process the laundry will survive so that employment can be provided. I am rather amazed to see that in the answer to the question, Senator Tate said that Peat Marwick Hungerfords management consultants had been asked to investigate the factors leading to the laundry's operating losses. He knows, I know and I think everybody else in Tasmania knows what caused that problem-it was the airlines strike.

The Bay View laundry principally relies on laundry supplied by the hotel trade in Hobart. The disastrous airline strike and the downturn in tourism in Tasmania is the reason that the laundry ran into trouble. The Government did not need Peat Marwick Hungerfords to tell it that. I am surprised that the Government had to go to all this trouble. I suppose it has had to do so to justify the amount of money that is going to be paid. I hope the amount of money that will be paid will be the $183,000.

As I said earlier, I have always had a lot of faith in Senator Tate. I have trusted and believed in him. I do not know who made the promise back in February-March. But whoever made it, those people, in good faith, have believed that this Government would provide assistance to them. This genuine case has been caused by the airline strike. We see that the quick fix today is $45,000 and `We will wait and see what else we can dish out to you to help you out'.

I do not think that is good enough. A promise was made. As the previous speaker-Senator Kemp-said, this Government is very good at breaking promises. I just hope that this promise is not broken and that that very worthy fabricare laundry in Hobart, the Bay View laundry, does receive the moneys it was promised and that the matter will be settled in a very short time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of the Bay View laundry was raised in the adjournment debate tonight by Senator Walters. The speaker immediately preceding me, Senator Calvert, also dealt with that question. I am quite familiar with the Bay View laundry which employs quite a number of people with disabilities and provides a very important service to various organisations, institutions and individuals.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned, as were the other two senators who have spoken and, I assume, the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, that the money that was promised will be forthcoming. I received from Senator Tate's office a copy of the press statement with a note acknowledging my support for the laundry. The press statement refers to the matter of payments being made-or words to that effect-prior to the end of this month.

I expect that that will occur. I know that Senator Tate will appreciate that, if it does not occur, there will be a number of very disappointed people-a number of people prepared to roast the Government from one end of Tasmania to the other because of a broken commitment. I am prepared to leave it now on the basis of the Minister's statement, in the expectation that not only will the promised amount of money be there but also that there will be a guarantee for the future viability of this laundry which, as I say, provides so many jobs for people with disabilities and provides such a good service to Hobart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is no wonder that this Hawke Labor Government is in deep trouble. As we are all aware, it is in complete disarray with regard to its economic management. Despite lengthy debate in both Houses today on the Gulf crisis and Australia's involvement there, Senator Loosley's remarks earlier tonight demonstrate that the Government is also in some disarray on this very important issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has clearly supported the Government's initiatives concerning the Gulf crisis. It was in that spirit of bipartisanship that my statement-which was reported in today's edition of the Adelaide Advertiser, and which Senator Loosley has attacked tonight-was released yesterday. This Government needs full community support for the decisions it has to take with regard to the Gulf crisis, provided it justifies those decisions with evidence and valid argument. In my view it has justified the possibility that operational requirements may involve our sailors remaining in the Gulf over Christmas rather than returning home for normal family celebrations.

If that is a decision which has to be taken in the interests of Australia's role in the Gulf then, harsh as it may seem, we should all support it. However, yesterday's Adelaide Advertiser reported as follows on its front page:
The wives and girlfriends of sailors aboard the frigates Adelaide and Darwin last night made a plea to the Federal Government to bring their men home for Christmas as promised.
Later, the article referred to one particular wife and quoted her as follows:
. . . she was filled with anger at the news her husband . . . might not be home for Christmas.

By attacking me tonight, Senator Loosley is adding his voice to those pleas. He is seeking the popularity of some sailors' families-families whom I believe would be in the minority as against the total number of sailors' families-at the cost of undermining the operational efficiency of our naval commitment to the Gulf crisis; at the cost of undermining decisions which his own Labor Government may need to take, thereby demonstrating to all the extent of the divisions now evident in this failed Government even on issues of fundamental importance such as our Gulf commitment; and at the cost of undermining the total commitment required from the whole Australian community if our involvement in the Gulf is to be successful.

As I said in several media interviews yesterday on this issue, one can well understand families wanting these sailors to be home to share Christmas together; one can certainly sympathise with that desire. One can accept families privately commenting that they wished that their spouses or children could be home for Christmas; that is only normal, and indeed such private comment would be acceptable.
In today's Adelaide Advertiser the sister of one of the sailors, in response to my comments, said:
We all know they have to go but to say that we miss them and want them home is not whingeing . . . it's just having human feelings.

That is certainly very true, but it is not the sort of comment to which I was referring. The sort of comment to which I was referring was the report in the Adelaide Advertiser of the previous day where a group of sailors' families was making a public plea to the Government to bring the sailors home for Christmas against what may well be contrary operational requirements. That is an entirely different matter from some private expression of a wish that people's sailor spouses or children should be home for Christmas. It is an entirely different matter to seek to bring public pressure on the Government through media statements complaining about a possible change in operational requirements.

Unlike Senator Loosley, I was prepared to support publicly his Government's decision on this matter; unlike Senator Loosley, I was prepared to speak out for those sailors' families who, whatever their private anguish about the dangers to the sailors, are willing to accept bravely and quietly the need for them to fulfil the task they were sent to do. It is my belief that those families are in the majority and it is only a minority making public complaint-a minority with which Senator Loosley has aligned himself thus undermining his Government's policies and the efforts of our sailors in the Gulf.

When someone joins our Services, let us remember that he does so on an entirely voluntary basis. Fortunately we no longer have conscription in this country, which we had some years ago, so people who join our services-whether it is the Royal Australian Army, the Royal Australian Navy, or the Royal Australian Air Force-do so voluntarily in the full knowledge that they may well be sent anywhere in the world at any time and at short notice to defend Australia's interests. One assumes their families also have full knowledge of that requirement and share that decision with them.

In this instance our sailors have been sent to do a job in Australia's interests in the Gulf. As was earlier indicated, they may well have been expected home for Christmas, but if a change in operational requirements makes that impossible, it must be accepted. Public complaint against such a change in operational decisions is highly damaging to their morale. Our sailors need total commitment and support from every Australian and most importantly from their own families to stay and complete the job they were sent to do and then to return home in the knowledge they have been successful and have successfully done the job we sent them to do.

A tug of war between their families and the Government to bring them home before the job is completed will severely undermine their morale. Such public pleas will also give Saddam Hussein wonderful comfort. Let us not forget that the Vietnam War, whatever the rights or wrongs of that war, was in large measure lost at home because of the loss of will to fight and continual calls to bring our boys home. Seeing reports such as that in yesterday's Adelaide Advertiser will only encourage Saddam Hussein to the view that he has only to wait long enough and pressure will build in the home countries of the United Nations forces to bring the boys home. It will give him much comfort to see reports of that nature in the media.

From a strategic viewpoint every encouragement must be given to our servicemen to stay and finish the job. Did the families of servicemen in World War I, World War II and in the Korean War demand to have their boys sent home for Christmas? Of course not; indeed, they were away for several Christmases without public complaint from their families, and so it must be if that is the operational requirement in this situation, as difficult as that may be for the families involved.

In his remarks tonight Senator Loosley referred to public opinion. Despite the fact that my comments were reported in a front page article in the Adelaide Advertiser, a relatively small number of people have reacted by calling my office. About 20 people did so, and the majority of them support my stand. That is despite the fact that, in a situation such as this, it would be more likely that those hostile to such a statement from me would contact my office to express their opposition to it. In other words, one is more likely to be contacted by people reacting negatively rather than positively to such a comment.

It is Senator Loosley who is out of touch with the public and indeed with the majority of families of personnel serving in the Gulf. I am confident that the majority of those servicemen's families want their relatives serving there to stay and finish the job and not to come home with the job half done. It is those families who are prepared to quietly bear the burden of anguish, which I share with them should the worst happen. It is they who are showing bravery and fortitude, along with their relatives at the front line. It is on their behalf that I spoke out yesterday, so let Senator Loosley speak out for the vocal minority and let their comments, which were blown up by the media, undermine the morale of those with serving relatives and undermine the efforts of Australia to evict this madman, Hussein, from Kuwait.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seeing as Senator Chapman has given such a spirited speech, I feel that I cannot stay silent. I do not particularly want to undermine the morale of any service men or women in the Gulf. They have been sent there to do a dreadful job by our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) without the consent of many Australians. Seeing as they are doing that job, yes, they need our support. But surely Senator Chapman does not expect every Australian who disagrees with the Government to stay silent. In a democracy we have the ability to speak and we need to speak. If our version of the truth is different from the Government's, then we are morally bound to speak, particularly in a matter like this where Australians are possibly being committed to a war.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not agree with the situation. I did not agree with it on 10 August when the Prime Minister sent the original deployment. I still do not agree with it, notwithstanding the United Nations resolutions. I share the sympathy that has been expressed for the service men and women there and for their families, as I said earlier today.

As for Senator Chapman's rhetoric about a job half done, it sounds as though he just cannot wait for the weapons to start to fly. The job, in his estimation, is obviously to blast the hell out of the Iraqi military regime. That is a deplorable attitude. We should be talking about a negotiated settlement and mediation to avert a war situation, not champing at the bit to get in there and start the firing. I can hardly believe, except that I have just sat here and heard it, that somebody would speak in those terms about the deployment of Australian naval officers in the Gulf. It is just terrible to think that they are being so strongly supported to get on and do the fighting because they have not finished the job. I do not think that the original job was intended to be one of fighting, though unfortunately that may have changed somewhat in the last few days.

Talking about a dereliction of duty, Senator Button, in his effort in the Parliament today, did not have the guts, the temerity or the interest in the issue to deliver the Prime Minister's speech. When he was called upon to do so, he consistently refused. The words need to be said because if a war follows in the Gulf, in history the Prime Minister's statement will be seen as the document which will have committed Australian men and women to that war situation.

When I asked Senator Button, `Why didn't you just read the statement; it would have taken a lot less time than all the argument about it?', he said words to the effect that he could not be bothered, that he was sick of reading speeches. That is truly outrageous. He is the Leader of the Government in this chamber. This is the only chamber where there will be any debate on this subject. There was no debate in the House of Representatives about it whatsoever because there is concurrence between the two major parties on this issue.

So this is the statement which will be referred to in future years, if a war breaks out, as the one that committed this country to war, yet the Leader of the Government in the Senate did not have the guts or the interest to even read it. This is the most significant statement that has been made in this Parliament certainly since I have been here, and I would argue in the life of any sitting member of parliament in either the House of Representatives or the Senate. The significance seems to have been lost on most members of parliament. I find it truly a contempt of the Senate that Senator Button could not be bothered to read the statement. Even when he was asked to do so, he consistently refused. It was very pig-headed behaviour.

I believe that on the 7.30 Report tonight the Prime Minister stated that the Government will consider any request for increased commitment. Again, it fills me with great sorrow to hear that the Prime Minister has made that kind of statement.

Alan Ramsey, on ABC radio a short time ago, said that there was no real dissent detected within Australian Labor Party ranks in Canberra today. That is from the media's point of view. I know that that is not true. There are people who are very concerned about this statement and, as I suggested earlier, I wish that, for their own integrity, they would speak out about this. Voters need to know who in the Government ranks is supporting this slide towards war and who is not supporting it. Alan Ramsey also said that the Prime Minister got what he wanted after the various factional meetings yesterday and that he has not had his wings clipped in terms of extra deployment of forces. I think that is pathetic, but that is too mild a word to use.

It is like the slide into any war. There is just a little bit of an engagement and then a little bit more as it is requested. By whom it will be requested we are not told. Presumably it will be by the United States military command because there is no United Nations military command; it does not exist. The Prime Minister did not even need to be invited to do so when he contributed the Australian force so generously in early August. No doubt as the opportunity arises in future he will make further commitments. I do not know whether anybody in the Labor Party has said to him, `We won't wear it. We won't let you get away with it'. But that is what has to be said. The Prime Minister's stand at the moment is like being a little bit pregnant. He is saying, `Well, we are just committing a little bit here. We are not really going to get involved'. Of course, if the shooting starts there is no way that the Australian forces will be able to get out and the Prime Minister will not even want them to get out. He is more concerned about supporting the Americans in this than anything else, and that includes the lack of concern about the Australian hostages.

I have said before but I think it needs to be said again that war will not solve the problems in the Middle East. The roots of the problems lie in colonialism, complicated by oil. Iraq was created by the British out of three Ottoman provinces with nothing in common and denied open access to the sea to prevent it from becoming too strong. During the war with Iran, Iraq was supported by the Saudis in the west to oppose the power of Iran and Islamic fundamentalism. Weapons poured in. For that, 30 countries were responsible. They included the United Kingdom, the United States, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, France and China, the latter three being the main arms suppliers. Saddam Hussein ran up terrible debts in order to pay for these weapons and resents the oil states with wealth not letting him off the hook now. That is largely what the dispute with Kuwait, which led to its invasion, was all about-not that I am excusing it and I do not want to be misinterpreted as doing so because it was not excusable.

Dispute over the oil field on the Iraq-Kuwait border, along with frustration at the lack of access to the open sea from the port of Umm Qasr past two uninhabited islands that are part of Kuwait, reflects this. These two islands could be part of a negotiated settlement, and this is one of the things that Saddam Hussein has been calling for. But his calls for talks have until now met with a stony silence from the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The honourable senator is here in this chamber offering Saddam Hussein a reward for invading a country and holding hostages.
—That is not a point of order.
—She should be ruled out of order, sat down and told not to read her speech.
—There is no point of order in the first comment. I shall watch to see whether Senator Vallentine is referring to copious notes.

—I think all of the issues of the Middle East should be put on the international agenda and the way to proceed is through a negotiated and mediated settlement. War should not be considered at any stage, particularly at this stage when sanctions are just beginning to bite. As I said earlier, it took 12 years for sanctions to be effective in the case of South Africa, and it took four short months in this situation before the initiative of the United States started drumming up the noises about oil and, in so doing, jeopardising the chance for a peaceful and negotiated settlement.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a way out that is possible, but to be honest it is unlikely that the United States will remove its massive forces without actually using them-and I regret to have to acknowledge that. The only thing to make that possible is to remove what support there is in the multinational force, and it is very interesting to observe that there are many chinks appearing in this multinational force for which Mr Baker and President Bush have been trying to gear up support in the lead-up to the United Nations resolution last week.
As has been said-and I am quoting Malcolm Booker from the Canberra Times today:

Perhaps the most important aspect of last week's resolution is that instead of consolidating the anti-Iraqi alliance it has virtually isolated the US. The members of the Security Council have in effect said to the Americans, ` `Go ahead and attack the Iraqis, if you dare, but it is your responsibility''. Britain is still pledged to go along, but there is no sign that the French have changed their stand that their forces will not be placed under US command and that they will make their own decision as to whether they will be used. And no-one now expects that either the Syrians or the Egyptians would join in a US-led attack on Iraq.

Neither would the Soviets. The Soviets are too mindful of the pain that they caused their own citizens, to say nothing of the Afghan people, in the Afghan war just a short time ago. They will not get engaged in the fighting.

So it seems to me as though the administration of the Government of the United States, not the people, could be likened to military junkies. They have refused to talk up till now, and they should have started the talking months ago. We need to remove the support system, and that is the only way to wean them off the drug of militarism. They cannot fight alone, so if various nations withdraw the support from them a war will not happen. That is why I argue for Australia to be out of the Gulf region. That is why I argue for the Australian Government to reassess its commitment and to get out now while it can.

I totally deplore the statement made today by the Prime Minister because I think it is this slide towards war which we have seen happen before. The supreme irony is that it was the Australian Labor Party that got us out of the Vietnam debacle and it is the Australian Labor Party which is now getting us into the Gulf war. There is a real danger of the 15 January deadline. War could begin before that time via a deliberate concocted ploy-and we must not rule out that possibility.

I will suggest a hypothetical scenario to the Senate: there is a big loser in this issue if a negotiated settlement is found and if war is averted-which we all surely fervently hope for-and that big loser would be Israel. The United States would look very silly continuing to veto United Nations resolutions in future calling on Israel to get out of occupied territories, because the veto has not been used in this situation. The fact that the veto is not being used is meant to be a new dimension in international politics. So it is not beyond the bounds of possibility that under some concocted pretext, the truth of which may never be revealed, missiles could start to fly.

So we could slide into this war, notwithstanding United Nations resolutions, and the 15 January deadline could be pre-empted. It will be virtually impossible for Australia to withdraw once we are closely engaged and under US command. Australia would therefore find itself in an undeclared war, as it did in Vietnam-a war with enormous consequences. My strong belief is that Australia should have no part in this slide towards war.

I, as a representative of the Greens, Western Australia, in concert with the Australian Democrats, speak for millions of Australians who say, `Not in my name'. Let us consider who wants to gear up for war in the Gulf. It is not the people of the world; not the veterans of previous wars. It is the old men and politicians, with the exception of Mrs Thatcher when she was still Prime Minister of Great Britain.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, may I seek your clarification on a point of order? I understand that while on a motion to close this sitting an honourable senator is at liberty to speak on matters relevant to the motion, an honourable senator is not entitled to refer to matters otherwise not in order, and honourable senators should not attempt to revive earlier debates of the session. I know that Senator Vallentine would say that Senator Loosley and Senator Chapman had previously revived the debate of today, but they were actually specifically referring to a press article that was in the Adelaide Advertiser. I ask for your ruling as to whether Senator Vallentine is in order or out of order by reviving a debate that was conducted earlier today.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: — In reply to the point of order, I would like to quote a section from Australian Senate Practice which says:

INTERJECT.PARA: The subject matter of an Order of the Day cannot be discussed on the motion to adjourn the Senate as so doing would anticipate the discussion on the Order of the Day. Senators should not attempt to revive earlier debates of the session. They may, nevertheless, allude to earlier debates for the purpose of making explanations or correcting misunderstandings, or where the allusion is relevant to a new aspect or matter which has been raised. It is to be noted that there is no restriction on references to previous adjournment debates.

I suppose that places me in a very difficult situation where I have to try to rule on whether Senator Valentine is introducing new material that has not been discussed today. I will allow her to continue at this stage, but I would remind her of the ruling that I have just read.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. You will be pleased to know, and I am sure other honourable senators will be too, that I have almost finished my remarks, and I will be saying something quite different from what was said earlier today. It is the politicians, and generally men-as I said, with the exception of Mrs Thatcher-who make the preparations for war. They will not have to fight it and they will not suffer directly. They will remain aloof from the carnage they are creating. A very popular musical which has been seen by many thousands of Australians around the country, Les Miserables, says it all. I will quote this in conclusion:

SPEECH.PARA: Do you see them
lying where they died?
Someone used to cradle them
and kiss them when they cried.
Do you see them lying side by side?
Who will wake them?
No-one ever will.
No-one ever told them
that a summer day can kill.
They were schoolboys,
never held a gun.
Fighting for a new world
that would rise up like the sun.
Where's that new world now the fighting's done?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall briefly respond to some of the matters raised in the debate. Senator Walters, Senator Calvert and Senator Harradine all referred to an answer which Senator Tate gave today in Question Time concerning the Bay View laundry. I have no specific facts to add to what Senator Tate said today, but I understand that the Bay View laundry is an enterprise conducted by a group of disabled people and it is indeed a worthy cause. Therefore, I treat the remarks of the honourable senators seriously. I will follow the matter up with Senator Tate in the morning and I hope to get some more information for honourable senators on that tomorrow. I cannot add anything specifically to what Peat Marwick Hungerfords have been asked to investigate or to whether or not that means $183,000. I do not know the status of the investigation or how far it has gone, so that is something I will have to check in the morning.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not propose to respond to Senator Kemp's performance on child poverty. I have answered questions on the matter here before. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has answered questions several times on the error that he made in the speech in 1987; so have I. So I do not propose to do it again.
Senator Alston interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Sometimes these withering attacks from the other side simply bear no response-they are so weak. We have seen the Prime Minister answer this a dozen times. I recall answering it myself at a Press Club speech that I made and at Question Time after it last year, some 18 months ago, when I was not in this portfolio. It is something the Government has responded to many times. It is so old and so tired-a bit like Senator Alston-that we just do not see it necessary to answer.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of Senator Chapman, we probably have not heard the last of the reaction to his comments in the Advertiser. I can say quite categorically that the Government is appalled by Senator Chapman's efforts. One wonders how one silences the cry of a wife or a child for a husband who will not be there at Christmas. Whether one has to accede to the request is another matter, but how anyone can attempt to criticise the women or the children for even being upset is beyond my comprehension. Nonetheless, it is a question that will have to be answered by Dr Hewson and the Liberal Party of Australia, not just by Senator Chapman, because the Government will be keen to learn of the Liberal Party's response to Senator Chapman's extraordinary and rather silly call.

Finally, in response to Senator Vallentine, I can understand how bitterly disappointed she may have been when the Security Council carried the resolution it did the other day, but at some point in time those who seek to invade neighbouring countries, to murder and pillage and then to keep hostages will have to know that there is a price to pay, that the world will no longer tolerate that kind of behaviour. The fact that finally we are seeing an active and effective United Nations is, I think, to the benefit of the world as a whole. Far from saying that Senator Vallentine represents millions of Australians, I believe that on this particular question she represents very few.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.45 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 June 1990 (Hansard page 1734) Senator Hill asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Given that in most cases the costs incurred in preparing environmental impact studies of major new developments are not tax-deductible, does the Minister agree that the taxation law is lagging behind community concern and the requirements of government concerning environmental protection? Will the Government include this issue in the current review of taxation arrangements applying to mine-site rehabilitation and removal of offshore petroleum platforms?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Environmental impact studies for new projects are not generally tax deductible as they are considered to be capital in nature. In the case of some mining operations however, environmental impact statements may form part of exploration and prospecting expenditure and such expenditure is deductible under the mining provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

This Government has a strong commitment to environmental protection and sustainable development. In furtherance of this commitment, the 1990-91 Budget Statement included an announcement that capital expenditure on mine site rehabilitation is, subject to some minor limitations, to be fully tax deductible.

The Budget also contained an announcement that a review is to be undertaken by Treasury into the taxation treatment generally of capital expenditure incurred by business in relation to the environment. The scope of this review will include consideration of the taxation treatment of environmental impact studies.
It is anticipated that the results of this review will be announced in the 1991-92 Budget.
